<div class="speech"><span class="ref">058</span> <div class="sentence">  Thus we have arrived at the end of the writings of Plato, and at the last stage of philosophy which was really his.</div><div class="sentence"> For in what followed, which we chiefly gather from the uncertain intimations of Aristotle, the spirit of the master no longer survived.</div><div class="sentence"> The doctrine of Ideas passed into one of numbers; instead of advancing from the abstract to the concrete, the theories of Plato were taken out of their context, and either asserted or refuted with a provoking literalism; the Socratic or Platonic element in his teaching was absorbed into the Pythagorean or Megarian.</div><div class="sentence"> His poetry was converted into mysticism; his unsubstantial visions were assailed secundum artem by the rules of logic.</div><div class="sentence"> His political speculations lost their interest when the freedom of Hellas had passed away.</div><div class="sentence"> Of all his writings the Laws were the furthest removed from the traditions of the Platonic school in the next generation.</div><div class="sentence"> Both his political and his metaphysical philosophy are for the most part misinterpreted by Aristotle.</div><div class="sentence"> The best of him—his love of truth, and his 'contemplation of all time and all existence,' was soonest lost; and some of his greatest thoughts have slept in the ear of mankind almost ever since they were first uttered.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">059</span> <div class="sentence">  We have followed him during his forty or fifty years of authorship, from the beginning when he first attempted to depict the teaching of Socrates in a dramatic form, down to the time at which the character of Socrates had disappeared, and we have the latest reflections of Plato's own mind upon Hellas and upon philosophy.</div><div class="sentence"> He, who was 'the last of the poets,' in his book of Laws writes prose only; he has himself partly fallen under the rhetorical influences which in his earlier dialogues he was combating.</div><div class="sentence"> The progress of his writings is also the history of his life; we have no other authentic life of him.</div><div class="sentence"> They are the true self of the philosopher, stripped of the accidents of time and place.</div><div class="sentence"> The great effort which he makes is, first, to realize abstractions, secondly, to connect them.</div><div class="sentence"> In the attempt to realize them, he was carried into a transcendental region in which he isolated them from experience, and we pass out of the range of science into poetry or fiction.</div><div class="sentence"> The fancies of mythology for a time cast a veil over the gulf which divides phenomena from onta (Meno, Phaedrus, Symposium, Phaedo).</div><div class="sentence"> In his return to earth Plato meets with a difficulty which has long ceased to be a difficulty to us.</div><div class="sentence"> He cannot understand how these obstinate, unmanageable ideas, residing alone in their heaven of abstraction, can be either combined with one another, or adapted to phenomena (Parmenides, Philebus, Sophist).</div><div class="sentence"> That which is the most familiar process of our own minds, to him appeared to be the crowning achievement of the dialectical art.</div><div class="sentence"> The difficulty which in his own generation threatened to be the destruction of philosophy, he has rendered unmeaning and ridiculous.</div><div class="sentence"> For by his conquests in the world of mind our thoughts are widened, and he has furnished us with new dialectical instruments which are of greater compass and power.</div><div class="sentence"> We have endeavoured to see him as he truly was, a great original genius struggling with unequal conditions of knowledge, not prepared with a system nor evolving in a series of dialogues ideas which he had long conceived, but contradictory, enquiring as he goes along, following the argument, first from one point of view and then from another, and therefore arriving at opposite conclusions, hovering around the light, and sometimes dazzled with excess of light, but always moving in the same element of ideal truth.</div><div class="sentence"> We have seen him also in his decline, when the wings of his imagination have begun to droop, but his experience of life remains, and he turns away from the contemplation of the eternal to take a last sad look at human affairs.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">060</span> <div class="sentence">  ...</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">061</span> <div class="sentence">  And so having brought into the world 'noble children' (Phaedr.</div><div class="sentence"> ), he rests from the labours of authorship.</div><div class="sentence"> More than two thousand two hundred years have passed away since he returned to the place of Apollo and the Muses.</div><div class="sentence"> Yet the echo of his words continues to be heard among men, because of all philosophers he has the most melodious voice.</div><div class="sentence"> He is the inspired prophet or teacher who can never die, the only one in whom the outward form adequately represents the fair soul within; in whom the thoughts of all who went before him are reflected and of all who come after him are partly anticipated.</div><div class="sentence"> Other teachers of philosophy are dried up and withered,—after a few centuries they have become dust; but he is fresh and blooming, and is always begetting new ideas in the minds of men.</div><div class="sentence"> They are one-sided and abstract; but he has many sides of wisdom.</div><div class="sentence"> Nor is he always consistent with himself, because he is always moving onward, and knows that there are many more things in philosophy than can be expressed in words, and that truth is greater than consistency.</div><div class="sentence"> He who approaches him in the most reverent spirit shall reap most of the fruit of his wisdom; he who reads him by the light of ancient commentators will have the least understanding of him.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">062</span> <div class="sentence">  We may see him with the eye of the mind in the groves of the Academy, or on the banks of the Ilissus, or in the streets of Athens, alone or walking with Socrates, full of those thoughts which have since become the common possession of mankind.</div><div class="sentence"> Or we may compare him to a statue hid away in some temple of Zeus or Apollo, no longer existing on earth, a statue which has a look as of the God himself.</div><div class="sentence"> Or we may once more imagine him following in another state of being the great company of heaven which he beheld of old in a vision (Phaedr.).</div><div class="sentence"> So, 'partly trifling, but with a certain degree of seriousness' (Symp.</div><div class="sentence"> ), we linger around the memory of a world which has passed away (Phaedr.</div><div class="sentence"> ).</div></div>

</div><div id="link2H_4_0003" class="book_section">
<h2>LAWS</h2>

</div><div id="link2H_4_0004" class="book_section">
<h2>BOOK I.</h2>


<div class="description">
<div class="book_description">PERSONS OF THE DIALOGUE:</div> An Athenian Stranger, Cleinias (a Cretan), Megillus (a Lacedaemonian). 
</div><div class="speech"><span class="ref">001</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Tell me, Strangers, is a God or some man supposed to be the author of your laws?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">002</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  A God, Stranger; in very truth a God:  among us Cretans he is said to have been Zeus, but in Lacedaemon, whence our friend here comes, I believe they would say that Apollo is their lawgiver:  would they not, Megillus?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">003</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">004</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And do you, Cleinias, believe, as Homer tells, that every ninth year Minos went to converse with his Olympian sire, and was inspired by him to make laws for your cities?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">005</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, that is our tradition; and there was Rhadamanthus, a brother of his, with whose name you are familiar; he is reputed to have been the justest of men, and we Cretans are of opinion that he earned this reputation from his righteous administration of justice when he was alive.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">006</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, and a noble reputation it was, worthy of a son of Zeus.</div><div class="sentence"> As you and Megillus have been trained in these institutions, I dare say that you will not be unwilling to give an account of your government and laws; on our way we can pass the time pleasantly in talking about them, for I am told that the distance from Cnosus to the cave and temple of Zeus is considerable; and doubtless there are shady places under the lofty trees, which will protect us from this scorching sun.</div><div class="sentence"> Being no longer young, we may often stop to rest beneath them, and get over the whole journey without difficulty, beguiling the time by conversation.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">007</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, Stranger, and if we proceed onward we shall come to groves of cypresses, which are of rare height and beauty, and there are green meadows, in which we may repose and converse.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">008</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Very good.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">009</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very good, indeed; and still better when we see them; let us move on cheerily.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">010</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I am willing—And first, I want to know why the law has ordained that you shall have common meals and gymnastic exercises, and wear arms.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">011</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I think, Stranger, that the aim of our institutions is easily intelligible to any one.</div><div class="sentence"> Look at the character of our country:  Crete is not like Thessaly, a large plain; and for this reason they have horsemen in Thessaly, and we have runners—the inequality of the ground in our country is more adapted to locomotion on foot; but then, if you have runners you must have light arms—no one can carry a heavy weight when running, and bows and arrows are convenient because they are light.</div><div class="sentence"> Now all these regulations have been made with a view to war, and the legislator appears to me to have looked to this in all his arrangements: —the common meals, if I am not mistaken, were instituted by him for a similar reason, because he saw that while they are in the field the citizens are by the nature of the case compelled to take their meals together for the sake of mutual protection.</div><div class="sentence"> He seems to me to have thought the world foolish in not understanding that all men are always at war with one another; and if in war there ought to be common meals and certain persons regularly appointed under others to protect an army, they should be continued in peace.</div><div class="sentence"> For what men in general term peace would be said by him to be only a name; in reality every city is in a natural state of war with every other, not indeed proclaimed by heralds, but everlasting.</div><div class="sentence"> And if you look closely, you will find that this was the intention of the Cretan legislator; all institutions, private as well as public, were arranged by him with a view to war; in giving them he was under the impression that no possessions or institutions are of any value to him who is defeated in battle; for all the good things of the conquered pass into the hands of the conquerors.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">012</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  You appear to me, Stranger, to have been thoroughly trained in the Cretan institutions, and to be well informed about them; will you tell me a little more explicitly what is the principle of government which you would lay down?</div><div class="sentence"> You seem to imagine that a well-governed state ought to be so ordered as to conquer all other states in war:  am I right in supposing this to be your meaning?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">013</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly; and our Lacedaemonian friend, if I am not mistaken, will agree with me.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">014</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Why, my good friend, how could any Lacedaemonian say anything else?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">015</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And is what you say applicable only to states, or also to villages?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">016</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To both alike.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">017</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The case is the same?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">018</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">019</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And in the village will there be the same war of family against family, and of individual against individual?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">020</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  The same.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">021</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And should each man conceive himself to be his own enemy: —what shall we say?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">022</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  O Athenian Stranger—inhabitant of Attica I will not call you, for you seem to deserve rather to be named after the goddess herself, because you go back to first principles,—you have thrown a light upon the argument, and will now be better able to understand what I was just saying,—that all men are publicly one another's enemies, and each man privately his own.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">023</span> <div class="sentence">  (ATHENIAN: My good sir, what do you mean?</div><div class="sentence"> )—</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">024</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence"> ...Moreover, there is a victory and defeat—the first and best of victories, the lowest and worst of defeats—which each man gains or sustains at the hands, not of another, but of himself; this shows that there is a war against ourselves going on within every one of us.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">025</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us now reverse the order of the argument:  Seeing that every individual is either his own superior or his own inferior, may we say that there is the same principle in the house, the village, and the state?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">026</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You mean that in each of them there is a principle of superiority or inferiority to self?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">027</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">028</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You are quite right in asking the question, for there certainly is such a principle, and above all in states; and the state in which the better citizens win a victory over the mob and over the inferior classes may be truly said to be better than itself, and may be justly praised, where such a victory is gained, or censured in the opposite case.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">029</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Whether the better is ever really conquered by the worse, is a question which requires more discussion, and may be therefore left for the present.</div><div class="sentence"> But I now quite understand your meaning when you say that citizens who are of the same race and live in the same cities may unjustly conspire, and having the superiority in numbers may overcome and enslave the few just; and when they prevail, the state may be truly called its own inferior and therefore bad; and when they are defeated, its own superior and therefore good.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">030</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Your remark, Stranger, is a paradox, and yet we cannot possibly deny it.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">031</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Here is another case for consideration;—in a family there may be several brothers, who are the offspring of a single pair; very possibly the majority of them may be unjust, and the just may be in a minority.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">032</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very possibly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">033</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And you and I ought not to raise a question of words as to whether this family and household are rightly said to be superior when they conquer, and inferior when they are conquered; for we are not now considering what may or may not be the proper or customary way of speaking, but we are considering the natural principles of right and wrong in laws.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">034</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What you say, Stranger, is most true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">035</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Quite excellent, in my opinion, as far as we have gone.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">036</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Again; might there not be a judge over these brethren, of whom we were speaking?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">037</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">038</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Now, which would be the better judge—one who destroyed the bad and appointed the good to govern themselves; or one who, while allowing the good to govern, let the bad live, and made them voluntarily submit?</div><div class="sentence"> Or third, I suppose, in the scale of excellence might be placed a judge, who, finding the family distracted, not only did not destroy any one, but reconciled them to one another for ever after, and gave them laws which they mutually observed, and was able to keep them friends.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">039</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  The last would be by far the best sort of judge and legislator.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">040</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And yet the aim of all the laws which he gave would be the reverse of war.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">041</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">042</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And will he who constitutes the state and orders the life of man have in view external war, or that kind of intestine war called civil, which no one, if he could prevent, would like to have occurring in his own state; and when occurring, every one would wish to be quit of as soon as possible?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">043</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  He would have the latter chiefly in view.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">044</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And would he prefer that this civil war should be terminated by the destruction of one of the parties, and by the victory of the other, or that peace and friendship should be re-established, and that, being reconciled, they should give their attention to foreign enemies?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">045</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Every one would desire the latter in the case of his own state.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">046</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And would not that also be the desire of the legislator?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">047</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">048</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And would not every one always make laws for the sake of the best?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">049</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To be sure.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">050</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But war, whether external or civil, is not the best, and the need of either is to be deprecated; but peace with one another, and good will, are best.</div><div class="sentence"> Nor is the victory of the state over itself to be regarded as a really good thing, but as a necessity; a man might as well say that the body was in the best state when sick and purged by medicine, forgetting that there is also a state of the body which needs no purge.</div><div class="sentence"> And in like manner no one can be a true statesman, whether he aims at the happiness of the individual or state, who looks only, or first of all, to external warfare; nor will he ever be a sound legislator who orders peace for the sake of war, and not war for the sake of peace.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">051</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I suppose that there is truth, Stranger, in that remark of yours; and yet I am greatly mistaken if war is not the entire aim and object of our own institutions, and also of the Lacedaemonian.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">052</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I dare say; but there is no reason why we should rudely quarrel with one another about your legislators, instead of gently questioning them, seeing that both we and they are equally in earnest.</div><div class="sentence"> Please follow me and the argument closely: —And first I will put forward Tyrtaeus, an Athenian by birth, but also a Spartan citizen, who of all men was most eager about war:  Well, he says,</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">053</span> <div class="sentence">  even if he were the richest of men, and possessed every good (and then he gives a whole list of them), if he be not at all times a brave warrior.'</div><div class="sentence"> I imagine that you, too, must have heard his poems; our Lacedaemonian friend has probably heard more than enough of them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">054</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">055</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  And they have found their way from Lacedaemon to Crete.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">056</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Come now and let us all join in asking this question of Tyrtaeus:  O most divine poet, we will say to him, the excellent praise which you have bestowed on those who excel in war sufficiently proves that you are wise and good, and I and Megillus and Cleinias of Cnosus do, as I believe, entirely agree with you.</div><div class="sentence"> But we should like to be quite sure that we are speaking of the same men; tell us, then, do you agree with us in thinking that there are two kinds of war; or what would you say?</div><div class="sentence"> A far inferior man to Tyrtaeus would have no difficulty in replying quite truly, that war is of two kinds,—one which is universally called civil war, and is, as we were just now saying, of all wars the worst; the other, as we should all admit, in which we fall out with other nations who are of a different race, is a far milder form of warfare.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">057</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly, far milder.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">058</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, now, when you praise and blame war in this high-flown strain, whom are you praising or blaming, and to which kind of war are you referring?</div><div class="sentence"> I suppose that you must mean foreign war, if I am to judge from expressions of yours in which you say that you abominate those</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">059</span> <div class="sentence">  'Who refuse to look upon fields of blood, and will not draw near and strike at their enemies.'</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">060</span> <div class="sentence">  And we shall naturally go on to say to him,—You, Tyrtaeus, as it seems, praise those who distinguish themselves in external and foreign war; and he must admit this.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">061</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Evidently.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">062</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  They are good; but we say that there are still better men whose virtue is displayed in the greatest of all battles.</div><div class="sentence"> And we too have a poet whom we summon as a witness, Theognis, citizen of Megara in Sicily:</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">063</span> <div class="sentence">  'Cyrnus,' he says, 'he who is faithful in a civil broil is worth his weight in gold and silver.'</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">064</span> <div class="sentence">  And such an one is far better, as we affirm, than the other in a more difficult kind of war, much in the same degree as justice and temperance and wisdom, when united with courage, are better than courage only; for a man cannot be faithful and good in civil strife without having all virtue.</div><div class="sentence"> But in the war of which Tyrtaeus speaks, many a mercenary soldier will take his stand and be ready to die at his post, and yet they are generally and almost without exception insolent, unjust, violent men, and the most senseless of human beings.</div><div class="sentence"> You will ask what the conclusion is, and what I am seeking to prove: I maintain that the divine legislator of Crete, like any other who is worthy of consideration, will always and above all things in making laws have regard to the greatest virtue; which, according to Theognis, is loyalty in the hour of danger, and may be truly called perfect justice.</div><div class="sentence"> Whereas, that virtue which Tyrtaeus highly praises is well enough, and was praised by the poet at the right time, yet in place and dignity may be said to be only fourth rate (i.e., it ranks after justice, temperance, and wisdom.</div><div class="sentence"> ).</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">065</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Stranger, we are degrading our inspired lawgiver to a rank which is far beneath him.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">066</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Nay, I think that we degrade not him but ourselves, if we imagine that Lycurgus and Minos laid down laws both in Lacedaemon and Crete mainly with a view to war.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">067</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What ought we to say then?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">068</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  What truth and what justice require of us, if I am not mistaken, when speaking in behalf of divine excellence;—that the legislator when making his laws had in view not a part only, and this the lowest part of virtue, but all virtue, and that he devised classes of laws answering to the kinds of virtue; not in the way in which modern inventors of laws make the classes, for they only investigate and offer laws whenever a want is felt, and one man has a class of laws about allotments and heiresses, another about assaults; others about ten thousand other such matters.</div><div class="sentence"> But we maintain that the right way of examining into laws is to proceed as we have now done, and I admired the spirit of your exposition; for you were quite right in beginning with virtue, and saying that this was the aim of the giver of the law, but I thought that you went wrong when you added that all his legislation had a view only to a part, and the least part of virtue, and this called forth my subsequent remarks.</div><div class="sentence"> Will you allow me then to explain how I should have liked to have heard you expound the matter?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">069</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  By all means.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">070</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  You ought to have said, Stranger—The Cretan laws are with reason famous among the Hellenes; for they fulfil the object of laws, which is to make those who use them happy; and they confer every sort of good.</div><div class="sentence"> Now goods are of two kinds:  there are human and there are divine goods, and the human hang upon the divine; and the state which attains the greater, at the same time acquires the less, or, not having the greater, has neither.</div><div class="sentence"> Of the lesser goods the first is health, the second beauty, the third strength, including swiftness in running and bodily agility generally, and the fourth is wealth, not the blind god (Pluto), but one who is keen of sight, if only he has wisdom for his companion.</div><div class="sentence"> For wisdom is chief and leader of the divine class of goods, and next follows temperance; and from the union of these two with courage springs justice, and fourth in the scale of virtue is courage.</div><div class="sentence"> All these naturally take precedence of the other goods, and this is the order in which the legislator must place them, and after them he will enjoin the rest of his ordinances on the citizens with a view to these, the human looking to the divine, and the divine looking to their leader mind.</div><div class="sentence"> Some of his ordinances will relate to contracts of marriage which they make one with another, and then to the procreation and education of children, both male and female; the duty of the lawgiver will be to take charge of his citizens, in youth and age, and at every time of life, and to give them punishments and rewards; and in reference to all their intercourse with one another, he ought to consider their pains and pleasures and desires, and the vehemence of all their passions; he should keep a watch over them, and blame and praise them rightly by the mouth of the laws themselves.</div><div class="sentence"> Also with regard to anger and terror, and the other perturbations of the soul, which arise out of misfortune, and the deliverances from them which prosperity brings, and the experiences which come to men in diseases, or in war, or poverty, or the opposite of these; in all these states he should determine and teach what is the good and evil of the condition of each.</div><div class="sentence"> In the next place, the legislator has to be careful how the citizens make their money and in what way they spend it, and to have an eye to their mutual contracts and dissolutions of contracts, whether voluntary or involuntary:  he should see how they order all this, and consider where justice as well as injustice is found or is wanting in their several dealings with one another; and honour those who obey the law, and impose fixed penalties on those who disobey, until the round of civil life is ended, and the time has come for the consideration of the proper funeral rites and honours of the dead.</div><div class="sentence"> And the lawgiver reviewing his work, will appoint guardians to preside over these things,—some who walk by intelligence, others by true opinion only, and then mind will bind together all his ordinances and show them to be in harmony with temperance and justice, and not with wealth or ambition.</div><div class="sentence"> This is the spirit, Stranger, in which I was and am desirous that you should pursue the subject.</div><div class="sentence"> And I want to know the nature of all these things, and how they are arranged in the laws of Zeus, as they are termed, and in those of the Pythian Apollo, which Minos and Lycurgus gave; and how the order of them is discovered to his eyes, who has experience in laws gained either by study or habit, although they are far from being self-evident to the rest of mankind like ourselves.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">071</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How shall we proceed, Stranger?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">072</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I think that we must begin again as before, and first consider the habit of courage; and then we will go on and discuss another and then another form of virtue, if you please.</div><div class="sentence"> In this way we shall have a model of the whole; and with these and similar discourses we will beguile the way.</div><div class="sentence"> And when we have gone through all the virtues, we will show, by the grace of God, that the institutions of which I was speaking look to virtue.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">073</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Very good; and suppose that you first criticize this praiser of Zeus and the laws of Crete.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">074</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I will try to criticize you and myself, as well as him, for the argument is a common concern.</div><div class="sentence"> Tell me,—were not first the syssitia, and secondly the gymnasia, invented by your legislator with a view to war?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">075</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">076</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And what comes third, and what fourth?</div><div class="sentence"> For that, I think, is the sort of enumeration which ought to be made of the remaining parts of virtue, no matter whether you call them parts or what their name is, provided the meaning is clear.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">077</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Then I, or any other Lacedaemonian, would reply that hunting is third in order.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">078</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us see if we can discover what comes fourth and fifth.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">079</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  I think that I can get as far as the fourth head, which is the frequent endurance of pain, exhibited among us Spartans in certain hand-to-hand fights; also in stealing with the prospect of getting a good beating; there is, too, the so-called Crypteia, or secret service, in which wonderful endurance is shown,—our people wander over the whole country by day and by night, and even in winter have not a shoe to their foot, and are without beds to lie upon, and have to attend upon themselves.</div><div class="sentence"> Marvellous, too, is the endurance which our citizens show in their naked exercises, contending against the violent summer heat; and there are many similar practices, to speak of which in detail would be endless.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">080</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Excellent, O Lacedaemonian Stranger.</div><div class="sentence"> But how ought we to define courage?</div><div class="sentence"> Is it to be regarded only as a combat against fears and pains, or also against desires and pleasures, and against flatteries; which exercise such a tremendous power, that they make the hearts even of respectable citizens to melt like wax?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">081</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  I should say the latter.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">082</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In what preceded, as you will remember, our Cnosian friend was speaking of a man or a city being inferior to themselves: —Were you not, Cleinias?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">083</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I was.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">084</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Now, which is in the truest sense inferior, the man who is overcome by pleasure or by pain?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">085</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I should say the man who is overcome by pleasure; for all men deem him to be inferior in a more disgraceful sense, than the other who is overcome by pain.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">086</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But surely the lawgivers of Crete and Lacedaemon have not legislated for a courage which is lame of one leg, able only to meet attacks which come from the left, but impotent against the insidious flatteries which come from the right?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">087</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Able to meet both, I should say.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">088</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then let me once more ask, what institutions have you in either of your states which give a taste of pleasures, and do not avoid them any more than they avoid pains; but which set a person in the midst of them, and compel or induce him by the prospect of reward to get the better of them?</div><div class="sentence"> Where is an ordinance about pleasure similar to that about pain to be found in your laws?</div><div class="sentence"> Tell me what there is of this nature among you: —What is there which makes your citizen equally brave against pleasure and pain, conquering what they ought to conquer, and superior to the enemies who are most dangerous and nearest home?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">089</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  I was able to tell you, Stranger, many laws which were directed against pain; but I do not know that I can point out any great or obvious examples of similar institutions which are concerned with pleasure; there are some lesser provisions, however, which I might mention.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">090</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Neither can I show anything of that sort which is at all equally prominent in the Cretan laws.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">091</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  No wonder, my dear friends; and if, as is very likely, in our search after the true and good, one of us may have to censure the laws of the others, we must not be offended, but take kindly what another says.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">092</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You are quite right, Athenian Stranger, and we will do as you say.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">093</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  At our time of life, Cleinias, there should be no feeling of irritation.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">094</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly not.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">095</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I will not at present determine whether he who censures the Cretan or Lacedaemonian polities is right or wrong.</div><div class="sentence"> But I believe that I can tell better than either of you what the many say about them.</div><div class="sentence"> For assuming that you have reasonably good laws, one of the best of them will be the law forbidding any young men to enquire which of them are right or wrong; but with one mouth and one voice they must all agree that the laws are all good, for they came from God; and any one who says the contrary is not to be listened to.</div><div class="sentence"> But an old man who remarks any defect in your laws may communicate his observation to a ruler or to an equal in years when no young man is present.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">096</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Exactly so, Stranger; and like a diviner, although not there at the time, you seem to me quite to have hit the meaning of the legislator, and to say what is most true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">097</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  As there are no young men present, and the legislator has given old men free licence, there will be no impropriety in our discussing these very matters now that we are alone.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">098</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div><div class="sentence"> And therefore you may be as free as you like in your censure of our laws, for there is no discredit in knowing what is wrong; he who receives what is said in a generous and friendly spirit will be all the better for it.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">099</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Very good; however, I am not going to say anything against your laws until to the best of my ability I have examined them, but I am going to raise doubts about them.</div><div class="sentence"> For you are the only people known to us, whether Greek or barbarian, whom the legislator commanded to eschew all great pleasures and amusements and never to touch them; whereas in the matter of pains or fears which we have just been discussing, he thought that they who from infancy had always avoided pains and fears and sorrows, when they were compelled to face them would run away from those who were hardened in them, and would become their subjects.</div><div class="sentence"> Now the legislator ought to have considered that this was equally true of pleasure; he should have said to himself, that if our citizens are from their youth upward unacquainted with the greatest pleasures, and unused to endure amid the temptations of pleasure, and are not disciplined to refrain from all things evil, the sweet feeling of pleasure will overcome them just as fear would overcome the former class; and in another, and even a worse manner, they will be the slaves of those who are able to endure amid pleasures, and have had the opportunity of enjoying them, they being often the worst of mankind.</div><div class="sentence"> One half of their souls will be a slave, the other half free; and they will not be worthy to be called in the true sense men and freemen.</div><div class="sentence"> Tell me whether you assent to my words?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">100</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  On first hearing, what you say appears to be the truth; but to be hasty in coming to a conclusion about such important matters would be very childish and simple.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">101</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Suppose, Cleinias and Megillus, that we consider the virtue which follows next of those which we intended to discuss (for after courage comes temperance), what institutions shall we find relating to temperance, either in Crete or Lacedaemon, which, like your military institutions, differ from those of any ordinary state.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">102</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  That is not an easy question to answer; still I should say that the common meals and gymnastic exercises have been excellently devised for the promotion both of temperance and courage.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">103</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There seems to be a difficulty, Stranger, with regard to states, in making words and facts coincide so that there can be no dispute about them.</div><div class="sentence"> As in the human body, the regimen which does good in one way does harm in another; and we can hardly say that any one course of treatment is adapted to a particular constitution.</div><div class="sentence"> Now the gymnasia and common meals do a great deal of good, and yet they are a source of evil in civil troubles; as is shown in the case of the Milesian, and Boeotian, and Thurian youth, among whom these institutions seem always to have had a tendency to degrade the ancient and natural custom of love below the level, not only of man, but of the beasts.</div><div class="sentence"> The charge may be fairly brought against your cities above all others, and is true also of most other states which especially cultivate gymnastics.</div><div class="sentence"> Whether such matters are to be regarded jestingly or seriously, I think that the pleasure is to be deemed natural which arises out of the intercourse between men and women; but that the intercourse of men with men, or of women with women, is contrary to nature, and that the bold attempt was originally due to unbridled lust.</div><div class="sentence"> The Cretans are always accused of having invented the story of Ganymede and Zeus because they wanted to justify themselves in the enjoyment of unnatural pleasures by the practice of the god whom they believe to have been their lawgiver.</div><div class="sentence"> Leaving the story, we may observe that any speculation about laws turns almost entirely on pleasure and pain, both in states and in individuals:  these are two fountains which nature lets flow, and he who draws from them where and when, and as much as he ought, is happy; and this holds of men and animals—of individuals as well as states; and he who indulges in them ignorantly and at the wrong time, is the reverse of happy.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">104</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  I admit, Stranger, that your words are well spoken, and I hardly know what to say in answer to you; but still I think that the Spartan lawgiver was quite right in forbidding pleasure.</div><div class="sentence"> Of the Cretan laws, I shall leave the defence to my Cnosian friend.</div><div class="sentence"> But the laws of Sparta, in as far as they relate to pleasure, appear to me to be the best in the world; for that which leads mankind in general into the wildest pleasure and licence, and every other folly, the law has clean driven out; and neither in the country nor in towns which are under the control of Sparta, will you find revelries and the many incitements of every kind of pleasure which accompany them; and any one who meets a drunken and disorderly person, will immediately have him most severely punished, and will not let him off on any pretence, not even at the time of a Dionysiac festival; although I have remarked that this may happen at your performances 'on the cart,' as they are called; and among our Tarentine colonists I have seen the whole city drunk at a Dionysiac festival; but nothing of the sort happens among us.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">105</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  O Lacedaemonian Stranger, these festivities are praiseworthy where there is a spirit of endurance, but are very senseless when they are under no regulations.</div><div class="sentence"> In order to retaliate, an Athenian has only to point out the licence which exists among your women.</div><div class="sentence"> To all such accusations, whether they are brought against the Tarentines, or us, or you, there is one answer which exonerates the practice in question from impropriety.</div><div class="sentence"> When a stranger expresses wonder at the singularity of what he sees, any inhabitant will naturally answer him: —Wonder not, O stranger; this is our custom, and you may very likely have some other custom about the same things.</div><div class="sentence"> Now we are speaking, my friends, not about men in general, but about the merits and defects of the lawgivers themselves.</div><div class="sentence"> Let us then discourse a little more at length about intoxication, which is a very important subject, and will seriously task the discrimination of the legislator.</div><div class="sentence"> I am not speaking of drinking, or not drinking, wine at all, but of intoxication.</div><div class="sentence"> Are we to follow the custom of the Scythians, and Persians, and Carthaginians, and Celts, and Iberians, and Thracians, who are all warlike nations, or that of your countrymen, for they, as you say, altogether abstain?</div><div class="sentence"> But the Scythians and Thracians, both men and women, drink unmixed wine, which they pour on their garments, and this they think a happy and glorious institution.</div><div class="sentence"> The Persians, again, are much given to other practices of luxury which you reject, but they have more moderation in them than the Thracians and Scythians.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">106</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  O best of men, we have only to take arms into our hands, and we send all these nations flying before us.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">107</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Nay, my good friend, do not say that; there have been, as there always will be, flights and pursuits of which no account can be given, and therefore we cannot say that victory or defeat in battle affords more than a doubtful proof of the goodness or badness of institutions.</div><div class="sentence"> For when the greater states conquer and enslave the lesser, as the Syracusans have done the Locrians, who appear to be the best-governed people in their part of the world, or as the Athenians have done the Ceans (and there are ten thousand other instances of the same sort of thing), all this is not to the point; let us endeavour rather to form a conclusion about each institution in itself and say nothing, at present, of victories and defeats.</div><div class="sentence"> Let us only say that such and such a custom is honourable, and another not.</div><div class="sentence"> And first permit me to tell you how good and bad are to be estimated in reference to these very matters.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">108</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  How do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">109</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  All those who are ready at a moment's notice to praise or censure any practice which is matter of discussion, seem to me to proceed in a wrong way.</div><div class="sentence"> Let me give you an illustration of what I mean: —You may suppose a person to be praising wheat as a good kind of food, whereupon another person instantly blames wheat, without ever enquiring into its effect or use, or in what way, or to whom, or with what, or in what state and how, wheat is to be given.</div><div class="sentence"> And that is just what we are doing in this discussion.</div><div class="sentence"> At the very mention of the word intoxication, one side is ready with their praises and the other with their censures; which is absurd.</div><div class="sentence"> For either side adduce their witnesses and approvers, and some of us think that we speak with authority because we have many witnesses; and others because they see those who abstain conquering in battle, and this again is disputed by us.</div><div class="sentence"> Now I cannot say that I shall be satisfied, if we go on discussing each of the remaining laws in the same way.</div><div class="sentence"> And about this very point of intoxication I should like to speak in another way, which I hold to be the right one; for if number is to be the criterion, are there not myriads upon myriads of nations ready to dispute the point with you, who are only two cities?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">110</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  I shall gladly welcome any method of enquiry which is right.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">111</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let me put the matter thus: —Suppose a person to praise the keeping of goats, and the creatures themselves as capital things to have, and then some one who had seen goats feeding without a goatherd in cultivated spots, and doing mischief, were to censure a goat or any other animal who has no keeper, or a bad keeper, would there be any sense or justice in such censure?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">112</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly not.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">113</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Does a captain require only to have nautical knowledge in order to be a good captain, whether he is sea-sick or not?</div><div class="sentence"> What do you say?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">114</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  I say that he is not a good captain if, although he have nautical skill, he is liable to sea-sickness.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">115</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And what would you say of the commander of an army?</div><div class="sentence"> Will he be able to command merely because he has military skill if he be a coward, who, when danger comes, is sick and drunk with fear?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">116</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Impossible.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">117</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And what if besides being a coward he has no skill?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">118</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  He is a miserable fellow, not fit to be a commander of men, but only of old women.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">119</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And what would you say of some one who blames or praises any sort of meeting which is intended by nature to have a ruler, and is well enough when under his presidency?</div><div class="sentence"> The critic, however, has never seen the society meeting together at an orderly feast under the control of a president, but always without a ruler or with a bad one: —when observers of this class praise or blame such meetings, are we to suppose that what they say is of any value?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">120</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly not, if they have never seen or been present at such a meeting when rightly ordered.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">121</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Reflect; may not banqueters and banquets be said to constitute a kind of meeting?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">122</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Of course.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">123</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And did any one ever see this sort of convivial meeting rightly ordered?</div><div class="sentence"> Of course you two will answer that you have never seen them at all, because they are not customary or lawful in your country; but I have come across many of them in many different places, and moreover I have made enquiries about them wherever I went, as I may say, and never did I see or hear of anything of the kind which was carried on altogether rightly; in some few particulars they might be right, but in general they were utterly wrong.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">124</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you mean, Stranger, by this remark?</div><div class="sentence"> Explain.</div><div class="sentence"> For we, as you say, from our inexperience in such matters, might very likely not know, even if they came in our way, what was right or wrong in such societies.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">125</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Likely enough; then let me try to be your instructor:  You would acknowledge, would you not, that in all gatherings of mankind, of whatever sort, there ought to be a leader?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">126</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly I should.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">127</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And we were saying just now, that when men are at war the leader ought to be a brave man?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">128</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  We were.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">129</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The brave man is less likely than the coward to be disturbed by fears?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">130</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That again is true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">131</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And if there were a possibility of having a general of an army who was absolutely fearless and imperturbable, should we not by all means appoint him?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">132</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Assuredly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">133</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Now, however, we are speaking not of a general who is to command an army, when foe meets foe in time of war, but of one who is to regulate meetings of another sort, when friend meets friend in time of peace.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">134</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">135</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And that sort of meeting, if attended with drunkenness, is apt to be unquiet.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">136</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly; the reverse of quiet.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">137</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In the first place, then, the revellers as well as the soldiers will require a ruler?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">138</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To be sure; no men more so.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">139</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And we ought, if possible, to provide them with a quiet ruler?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">140</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Of course.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">141</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And he should be a man who understands society; for his duty is to preserve the friendly feelings which exist among the company at the time, and to increase them for the future by his use of the occasion.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">142</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">143</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Must we not appoint a sober man and a wise to be our master of the revels?</div><div class="sentence"> For if the ruler of drinkers be himself young and drunken, and not over-wise, only by some special good fortune will he be saved from doing some great evil.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">144</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  It will be by a singular good fortune that he is saved.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">145</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Now suppose such associations to be framed in the best way possible in states, and that some one blames the very fact of their existence—he may very likely be right.</div><div class="sentence"> But if he blames a practice which he only sees very much mismanaged, he shows in the first place that he is not aware of the mismanagement, and also not aware that everything done in this way will turn out to be wrong, because done without the superintendence of a sober ruler.</div><div class="sentence"> Do you not see that a drunken pilot or a drunken ruler of any sort will ruin ship, chariot, army—anything, in short, of which he has the direction?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">146</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  The last remark is very true, Stranger; and I see quite clearly the advantage of an army having a good leader—he will give victory in war to his followers, which is a very great advantage; and so of other things.</div><div class="sentence"> But I do not see any similar advantage which either individuals or states gain from the good management of a feast; and I want you to tell me what great good will be effected, supposing that this drinking ordinance is duly established.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">147</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  If you mean to ask what great good accrues to the state from the right training of a single youth, or of a single chorus—when the question is put in that form, we cannot deny that the good is not very great in any particular instance.</div><div class="sentence"> But if you ask what is the good of education in general, the answer is easy—that education makes good men, and that good men act nobly, and conquer their enemies in battle, because they are good.</div><div class="sentence"> Education certainly gives victory, although victory sometimes produces forgetfulness of education; for many have grown insolent from victory in war, and this insolence has engendered in them innumerable evils; and many a victory has been and will be suicidal to the victors; but education is never suicidal.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">148</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You seem to imply, my friend, that convivial meetings, when rightly ordered, are an important element of education.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">149</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly I do.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">150</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  And can you show that what you have been saying is true?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">151</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  To be absolutely sure of the truth of matters concerning which there are many opinions, is an attribute of the Gods not given to man, Stranger; but I shall be very happy to tell you what I think, especially as we are now proposing to enter on a discussion concerning laws and constitutions.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">152</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Your opinion, Stranger, about the questions which are now being raised, is precisely what we want to hear.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">153</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Very good; I will try to find a way of explaining my meaning, and you shall try to have the gift of understanding me.</div><div class="sentence"> But first let me make an apology.</div><div class="sentence"> The Athenian citizen is reputed among all the Hellenes to be a great talker, whereas Sparta is renowned for brevity, and the Cretans have more wit than words.</div><div class="sentence"> Now I am afraid of appearing to elicit a very long discourse out of very small materials.</div><div class="sentence"> For drinking indeed may appear to be a slight matter, and yet is one which cannot be rightly ordered according to nature, without correct principles of music; these are</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">154</span> <div class="sentence">  necessary to any clear or satisfactory treatment of the subject, and music again runs up into education generally, and there is much to be said about all this.</div><div class="sentence"> What would you say then to leaving these matters for the present, and passing on to some other question of law?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">155</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  O Athenian Stranger, let me tell you what perhaps you do not know, that our family is the proxenus of your state.</div><div class="sentence"> I imagine that from their earliest youth all boys, when they are told that they are the proxeni of a particular state, feel kindly towards their second country; and this has certainly been my own feeling.</div><div class="sentence"> I can well remember from the days of my boyhood, how, when any Lacedaemonians praised or blamed the Athenians, they used to say to me,—'See, Megillus, how ill or how well,' as the case might be, 'has your state treated us'; and having always had to fight your battles against detractors when I heard you assailed, I became warmly attached to you.</div><div class="sentence"> And I always like to hear the Athenian tongue spoken; the common saying is quite true, that a good Athenian is more than ordinarily good, for he is the only man who is freely and genuinely good by the divine inspiration of his own nature, and is not manufactured.</div><div class="sentence"> Therefore be assured that I shall like to hear you say whatever you have to say.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">156</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, Stranger; and when you have heard me speak, say boldly what is in your thoughts.</div><div class="sentence"> Let me remind you of a tie which unites you to Crete.</div><div class="sentence"> You must have heard here the story of the prophet Epimenides, who was of my family, and came to Athens ten years before the Persian war, in accordance with the response of the Oracle, and offered certain sacrifices which the God commanded.</div><div class="sentence"> The Athenians were at that time in dread of the Persian invasion; and he said that for ten years they would not come, and that when they came, they would go away again without accomplishing any of their objects, and would suffer more evil than they inflicted.</div><div class="sentence"> At that time my forefathers formed ties of hospitality with you; thus ancient is the friendship which I and my parents have had for you.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">157</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  You seem to be quite ready to listen; and I am also ready to perform as much as I can of an almost impossible task, which I will nevertheless attempt.</div><div class="sentence"> At the outset of the discussion, let me define the nature and power of education; for this is the way by which our argument must travel onwards to the God Dionysus.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">158</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Let us proceed, if you please.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">159</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, then, if I tell you what are my notions of education, will you consider whether they satisfy you?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">160</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Let us hear.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">161</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  According to my view, any one who would be good at anything must practise that thing from his youth upwards, both in sport and earnest, in its several branches:  for example, he who is to be a good builder, should play at building children's houses; he who is to be a good husbandman, at tilling the ground; and those who have the care of their education should provide them when young with mimic tools.</div><div class="sentence"> They should learn beforehand the knowledge which they will afterwards require for their art.</div><div class="sentence"> For example, the future carpenter should learn to measure or apply the line in play; and the future warrior should learn riding, or some other exercise, for amusement, and the teacher should endeavour to direct the children's inclinations and pleasures, by the help of amusements, to their final aim in life.</div><div class="sentence"> The most important part of education is right training in the nursery.</div><div class="sentence"> The soul of the child in his play should be guided to the love of that sort of excellence in which when he grows up to manhood he will have to be perfected.</div><div class="sentence"> Do you agree with me thus far?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">162</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">163</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then let us not leave the meaning of education ambiguous or ill-defined.</div><div class="sentence"> At present, when we speak in terms of praise or blame about the bringing-up of each person, we call one man educated and another uneducated, although the uneducated man may be sometimes very well educated for the calling of a retail trader, or of a captain of a ship, and the like.</div><div class="sentence"> For we are not speaking of education in this narrower sense, but of that other education in virtue from youth upwards, which makes a man eagerly pursue the ideal perfection of citizenship, and teaches him how rightly to rule and how to obey.</div><div class="sentence"> This is the only education which, upon our view, deserves the name; that other sort of training, which aims at the acquisition of wealth or bodily strength, or mere cleverness apart from intelligence and justice, is mean and illiberal, and is not worthy to be called education at all.</div><div class="sentence"> But let us not quarrel with one another about a word, provided that the proposition which has just been granted hold good:  to wit, that those who are rightly educated generally become good men.</div><div class="sentence"> Neither must we cast a slight upon education, which is the first and fairest thing that the best of men can ever have, and which, though liable to take a wrong direction, is capable of reformation.</div><div class="sentence"> And this work of reformation is the great business of every man while he lives.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">164</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true; and we entirely agree with you.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">165</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And we agreed before that they are good men who are able to rule themselves, and bad men who are not.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">166</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You are quite right.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">167</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let me now proceed, if I can, to clear up the subject a little further by an illustration which I will offer you.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">168</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Proceed.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">169</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Do we not consider each of ourselves to be one?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">170</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  We do.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">171</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And each one of us has in his bosom two counsellors, both foolish and also antagonistic; of which we call the one pleasure, and the other pain.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">172</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Exactly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">173</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Also there are opinions about the future, which have the general name of expectations; and the specific name of fear, when the expectation is of pain; and of hope, when of pleasure; and further, there is reflection about the good or evil of them, and this, when embodied in a decree by the State, is called Law.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">174</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I am hardly able to follow you; proceed, however, as if I were.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">175</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  I am in the like case.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">176</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us look at the matter thus:  May we not conceive each of us living beings to be a puppet of the Gods, either their plaything only, or created with a purpose—which of the two we cannot certainly know?</div><div class="sentence"> But we do know, that these affections in us are like cords and strings, which pull us different and opposite ways, and to opposite actions; and herein lies the difference between virtue and vice.</div><div class="sentence"> According to the argument there is one among these cords which every man ought to grasp and never let go, but to pull with it against all the rest; and this is the sacred and golden cord of reason, called by us the common law of the State; there are others which are hard and of iron, but this one is soft because golden; and there are several other kinds.</div><div class="sentence"> Now we ought always to cooperate with the lead of the best, which is law.</div><div class="sentence"> For inasmuch as reason is beautiful and gentle, and not violent, her rule must needs have ministers in order to help the golden principle in vanquishing the other principles.</div><div class="sentence"> And thus the moral of the tale about our being puppets will not have been lost, and the meaning of the expression 'superior or inferior to a man's self' will become clearer; and the individual, attaining to right reason in this matter of pulling the strings of the puppet, should live according to its rule; while the city, receiving the same from some god or from one who has knowledge of these things, should embody it in a law, to be her guide in her dealings with herself and with other states.</div><div class="sentence"> In this way virtue and vice will be more clearly distinguished by us.</div><div class="sentence"> And when they have become clearer, education and other institutions will in like manner become clearer; and in particular that question of convivial entertainment, which may seem, perhaps, to have been a very trifling matter, and to have taken a great many more words than were necessary.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">177</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Perhaps, however, the theme may turn out not to be unworthy of the length of discourse.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">178</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Very good; let us proceed with any enquiry which really bears on our present object.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">179</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Proceed.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">180</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Suppose that we give this puppet of ours drink,—what will be the effect on him?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">181</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Having what in view do you ask that question?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">182</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Nothing as yet; but I ask generally, when the puppet is brought to the drink, what sort of result is likely to follow.</div><div class="sentence"> I will endeavour to explain my meaning more clearly:  what I am now asking is this—Does the drinking of wine heighten and increase pleasures and pains, and passions and loves?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">183</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very greatly.</div></div>
