<div class="speech"><span class="ref">184</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And are perception and memory, and opinion and prudence, heightened and increased?</div><div class="sentence"> Do not these qualities entirely desert a man if he becomes saturated with drink?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">185</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, they entirely desert him.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">186</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Does he not return to the state of soul in which he was when a young child?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">187</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  He does.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">188</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then at that time he will have the least control over himself?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">189</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  The least.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">190</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And will he not be in a most wretched plight?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">191</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Most wretched.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">192</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then not only an old man but also a drunkard becomes a second time a child?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">193</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Well said, Stranger.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">194</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Is there any argument which will prove to us that we ought to encourage the taste for drinking instead of doing all we can to avoid it?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">195</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I suppose that there is; you at any rate, were just now saying that you were ready to maintain such a doctrine.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">196</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  True, I was; and I am ready still, seeing that you have both declared that you are anxious to hear me.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">197</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To be sure we are, if only for the strangeness of the paradox, which asserts that a man ought of his own accord to plunge into utter degradation.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">198</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Are you speaking of the soul?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">199</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">200</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And what would you say about the body, my friend?</div><div class="sentence"> Are you not surprised at any one of his own accord bringing upon himself deformity, leanness, ugliness, decrepitude?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">201</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">202</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yet when a man goes of his own accord to a doctor's shop, and takes medicine, is he not aware that soon, and for many days afterwards, he will be in a state of body which he would die rather than accept as the permanent condition of his life?</div><div class="sentence"> Are not those who train in gymnasia, at first beginning reduced to a state of weakness?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">203</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, all that is well known.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">204</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Also that they go of their own accord for the sake of the subsequent benefit?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">205</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very good.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">206</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And we may conceive this to be true in the same way of other practices?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">207</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">208</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And the same view may be taken of the pastime of drinking wine, if we are right in supposing that the same good effect follows?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">209</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To be sure.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">210</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  If such convivialities should turn out to have any advantage equal in importance to that of gymnastic, they are in their very nature to be preferred to mere bodily exercise, inasmuch as they have no accompaniment of pain.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">211</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True; but I hardly think that we shall be able to discover any such benefits to be derived from them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">212</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  That is just what we must endeavour to show.</div><div class="sentence"> And let me ask you a question: —Do we not distinguish two kinds of fear, which are very different?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">213</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What are they?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">214</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There is the fear of expected evil.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">215</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">216</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And there is the fear of an evil reputation; we are afraid of being thought evil, because we do or say some dishonourable thing, which fear we and all men term shame.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">217</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">218</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  These are the two fears, as I called them; one of which is the opposite of pain and other fears, and the opposite also of the greatest and most numerous sort of pleasures.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">219</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">220</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And does not the legislator and every one who is good for anything, hold this fear in the greatest honour?</div><div class="sentence"> This is what he terms reverence, and the confidence which is the reverse of this he terms insolence; and the latter he always deems to be a very great evil both to individuals and to states.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">221</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">222</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Does not this kind of fear preserve us in many important ways?</div><div class="sentence"> What is there which so surely gives victory and safety in war?</div><div class="sentence"> For there are two things which give victory—confidence before enemies, and fear of disgrace before friends.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">223</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  There are.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">224</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then each of us should be fearless and also fearful; and why we should be either has now been determined.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">225</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">226</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And when we want to make any one fearless, we and the law bring him face to face with many fears.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">227</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Clearly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">228</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And when we want to make him rightly fearful, must we not introduce him to shameless pleasures, and train him to take up arms against them, and to overcome them?</div><div class="sentence"> Or does this principle apply to courage only, and must he who would be perfect in valour fight against and overcome his own natural character,—since if he be unpractised and inexperienced in such conflicts, he will not be half the man which he might have been,—and are we to suppose, that with temperance it is otherwise, and that he who has never fought with the shameless and unrighteous temptations of his pleasures and lusts, and conquered them, in earnest and in play, by word, deed, and act, will still be perfectly temperate?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">229</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  A most unlikely supposition.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">230</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Suppose that some God had given a fear-potion to men, and that the more a man drank of this the more he regarded himself at every draught as a child of misfortune, and that he feared everything happening or about to happen to him; and that at last the most courageous of men utterly lost his presence of mind for a time, and only came to himself again when he had slept off the influence of the draught.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">231</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  But has such a draught, Stranger, ever really been known among men?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">232</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  No; but, if there had been, might not such a draught have been of use to the legislator as a test of courage?</div><div class="sentence"> Might we not go and say to him, 'O legislator, whether you are legislating for the Cretan, or for any other state, would you not like to have a touchstone of the courage and cowardice of your citizens?'</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">233</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  'I should,' will be the answer of every one.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">234</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  'And you would rather have a touchstone in which there is no risk and no great danger than the reverse?'</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">235</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  In that proposition every one may safely agree.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">236</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  'And in order to make use of the draught, you would lead them amid these imaginary terrors, and prove them, when the affection of fear was working upon them, and compel them to be fearless, exhorting and admonishing them; and also honouring them, but dishonouring any one who will not be persuaded by you to be in all respects such as you command him; and if he underwent the trial well and manfully, you would let him go unscathed; but if ill, you would inflict a punishment upon him?</div><div class="sentence"> Or would you abstain from using the potion altogether, although you have no reason for abstaining?'</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">237</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  He would be certain, Stranger, to use the potion.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">238</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  This would be a mode of testing and training which would be wonderfully easy in comparison with those now in use, and might be applied to a single person, or to a few, or indeed to any number; and he would do well who provided himself with the potion only, rather than with any number of other things, whether he preferred to be by himself in solitude, and there contend with his fears, because he was ashamed to be seen by the eye of man until he was perfect; or trusting to the force of his own nature and habits, and believing that he had been already disciplined sufficiently, he did not hesitate to train himself in company with any number of others, and display his power in conquering the irresistible change effected by the draught—his virtue being such, that he never in any instance fell into any great unseemliness, but was always himself, and left off before he arrived at the last cup, fearing that he, like all other men, might be overcome by the potion.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">239</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, Stranger, in that last case, too, he might equally show his self-control.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">240</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us return to the lawgiver, and say to him: —'Well, lawgiver, there is certainly no such fear-potion which man has either received from the Gods or himself discovered; for witchcraft has no place at our board.</div><div class="sentence"> But is there any potion which might serve as a test of overboldness and excessive and indiscreet boasting?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">241</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I suppose that he will say, Yes,—meaning that wine is such a potion.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">242</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Is not the effect of this quite the opposite of the effect of the other?</div><div class="sentence"> When a man drinks wine he begins to be better pleased with himself, and the more he drinks the more he is filled full of brave hopes, and conceit of his power, and at last the string of his tongue is loosened, and fancying himself wise, he is brimming over with lawlessness, and has no more fear or respect, and is ready to do or say anything.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">243</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I think that every one will admit the truth of your description.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">244</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">245</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Now, let us remember, as we were saying, that there are two things which should be cultivated in the soul:  first, the greatest courage; secondly, the greatest fear—</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">246</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Which you said to be characteristic of reverence, if I am not mistaken.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">247</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Thank you for reminding me.</div><div class="sentence"> But now, as the habit of courage and fearlessness is to be trained amid fears, let us consider whether the opposite quality is not also to be trained among opposites.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">248</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That is probably the case.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">249</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There are times and seasons at which we are by nature more than commonly valiant and bold; now we ought to train ourselves on these occasions to be as free from impudence and shamelessness as possible, and to be afraid to say or suffer or do anything that is base.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">250</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">251</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Are not the moments in which we are apt to be bold and shameless such as these?—when we are under the influence of anger, love, pride, ignorance, avarice, cowardice?</div><div class="sentence"> or when wealth, beauty, strength, and all the intoxicating workings of pleasure madden us?</div><div class="sentence"> What is better adapted than the festive use of wine, in the first place to test, and in the second place to train the character of a man, if care be taken in the use of it?</div><div class="sentence"> What is there cheaper, or more innocent?</div><div class="sentence"> For do but consider which is the greater risk: —Would you rather test a man of a morose and savage nature, which is the source of ten thousand acts of injustice, by making bargains with him at a risk to yourself, or by having him as a companion at the festival of Dionysus?</div><div class="sentence"> Or would you, if you wanted to apply a touchstone to a man who is prone to love, entrust your wife, or your sons, or daughters to him, perilling your dearest interests in order to have a view of the condition of his soul?</div><div class="sentence"> I might mention numberless cases, in which the advantage would be manifest of getting to know a character in sport, and without paying dearly for experience.</div><div class="sentence"> And I do not believe that either a Cretan, or any other man, will doubt that such a test is a fair test, and safer, cheaper, and speedier than any other.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">252</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That is certainly true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">253</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And this knowledge of the natures and habits of men's souls will be of the greatest use in that art which has the management of them; and that art, if I am not mistaken, is politics.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">254</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Exactly so.</div></div>

</div><div id="link2H_4_0005" class="book_section">
<h2>BOOK II.</h2>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">001</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And now we have to consider whether the insight into human nature is the only benefit derived from well-ordered potations, or whether there are not other advantages great and much to be desired.</div><div class="sentence"> The argument seems to imply that there are.</div><div class="sentence"> But how and in what way these are to be attained, will have to be considered attentively, or we may be entangled in error.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">002</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Proceed.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">003</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let me once more recall our doctrine of right education; which, if I am not mistaken, depends on the due regulation of convivial intercourse.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">004</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You talk rather grandly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">005</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Pleasure and pain I maintain to be the first perceptions of children, and I say that they are the forms under which virtue and vice are originally present to them.</div><div class="sentence"> As to wisdom and true and fixed opinions, happy is the man who acquires them, even when declining in years; and we may say that he who possesses them, and the blessings which are contained in them, is a perfect man.</div><div class="sentence"> Now I mean by education that training which is given by suitable habits to the first instincts of virtue in children;—when pleasure, and friendship, and pain, and hatred, are rightly implanted in souls not yet capable of understanding the nature of them, and who find them, after they have attained reason, to be in harmony with her.</div><div class="sentence"> This harmony of the soul, taken as a whole, is virtue; but the particular training in respect of pleasure and pain, which leads you always to hate what you ought to hate, and love what you ought to love from the beginning of life to the end, may be separated off; and, in my view, will be rightly called education.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">006</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I think, Stranger, that you are quite right in all that you have said and are saying about education.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">007</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I am glad to hear that you agree with me; for, indeed, the discipline of pleasure and pain which, when rightly ordered, is a principle of education, has been often relaxed and corrupted in human life.</div><div class="sentence"> And the Gods, pitying the toils which our race is born to undergo, have appointed holy festivals, wherein men alternate rest with labour; and have given them the Muses and Apollo, the leader of the Muses, and Dionysus, to be companions in their revels, that they may improve their education by taking part in the festivals of the Gods, and with their help.</div><div class="sentence"> I should like to know whether a common saying is in our opinion true to nature or not.</div><div class="sentence"> For men say that the young of all creatures cannot be quiet in their bodies or in their voices; they are always wanting to move and cry out; some leaping and skipping, and overflowing with sportiveness and delight at something, others uttering all sorts of cries.</div><div class="sentence"> But, whereas the animals have no perception of order or disorder in their movements, that is, of rhythm or harmony, as they are called, to us, the Gods, who, as we say, have been appointed to be our companions in the dance, have given the pleasurable sense of harmony and rhythm; and so they stir us into life, and we follow them, joining hands together in dances and songs; and these they call choruses, which is a term naturally expressive of cheerfulness.</div><div class="sentence"> Shall we begin, then, with the acknowledgment that education is first given through Apollo and the Muses?</div><div class="sentence"> What do you say?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">008</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I assent.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">009</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And the uneducated is he who has not been trained in the chorus, and the educated is he who has been well trained?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">010</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">011</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And the chorus is made up of two parts, dance and song?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">012</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">013</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then he who is well educated will be able to sing and dance well?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">014</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I suppose that he will.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">015</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us see; what are we saying?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">016</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">017</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  He sings well and dances well; now must we add that he sings what is good and dances what is good?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">018</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Let us make the addition.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">019</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  We will suppose that he knows the good to be good, and the bad to be bad, and makes use of them accordingly:  which now is the better trained in dancing and music—he who is able to move his body and to use his voice in what is understood to be the right manner, but has no delight in good or hatred of evil; or he who is incorrect in gesture and voice, but is right in his sense of pleasure and pain, and welcomes what is good, and is offended at what is evil?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">020</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  There is a great difference, Stranger, in the two kinds of education.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">021</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  If we three know what is good in song and dance, then we truly know also who is educated and who is uneducated; but if not, then we certainly shall not know wherein lies the safeguard of education, and whether there is any or not.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">022</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">023</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us follow the scent like hounds, and go in pursuit of beauty of figure, and melody, and song, and dance; if these escape us, there will be no use in talking about true education, whether Hellenic or barbarian.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">024</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">025</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And what is beauty of figure, or beautiful melody?</div><div class="sentence"> When a manly soul is in trouble, and when a cowardly soul is in similar case, are they likely to use the same figures and gestures, or to give utterance to the same sounds?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">026</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How can they, when the very colours of their faces differ?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">027</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Good, my friend; I may observe, however, in passing, that in music there certainly are figures and there are melodies:  and music is concerned with harmony and rhythm, so that you may speak of a melody or figure having good rhythm or good harmony—the term is correct enough; but to speak metaphorically of a melody or figure having a 'good colour,' as the masters of choruses do, is not allowable, although you can speak of the melodies or figures of the brave and the coward, praising the one and censuring the other.</div><div class="sentence"> And not to be tedious, let us say that the figures and melodies which are expressive of virtue of soul or body, or of images of virtue, are without exception good, and those which are expressive of vice are the reverse of good.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">028</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Your suggestion is excellent; and let us answer that these things are so.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">029</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Once more, are all of us equally delighted with every sort of dance?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">030</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Far otherwise.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">031</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  What, then, leads us astray?</div><div class="sentence"> Are beautiful things not the same to us all, or are they the same in themselves, but not in our opinion of them?</div><div class="sentence"> For no one will admit that forms of vice in the dance are more beautiful than forms of virtue, or that he himself delights in the forms of vice, and others in a muse of another character.</div><div class="sentence"> And yet most persons say, that the excellence of music is to give pleasure to our souls.</div><div class="sentence"> But this is intolerable and blasphemous; there is, however, a much more plausible account of the delusion.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">032</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">033</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The adaptation of art to the characters of men.</div><div class="sentence"> Choric movements are imitations of manners occurring in various actions, fortunes, dispositions,—each particular is imitated, and those to whom the words, or songs, or dances are suited, either by nature or habit or both, cannot help feeling pleasure in them and applauding them, and calling them beautiful.</div><div class="sentence"> But those whose natures, or ways, or habits are unsuited to them, cannot delight in them or applaud them, and they call them base.</div><div class="sentence"> There are others, again, whose natures are right and their habits wrong, or whose habits are right and their natures wrong, and they praise one thing, but are pleased at another.</div><div class="sentence"> For they say that all these imitations are pleasant, but not good.</div><div class="sentence"> And in the presence of those whom they think wise, they are ashamed of dancing and singing in the baser manner, or of deliberately lending any countenance to such proceedings; and yet, they have a secret pleasure in them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">034</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">035</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And is any harm done to the lover of vicious dances or songs, or any good done to the approver of the opposite sort of pleasure?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">036</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I think that there is.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">037</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  'I think' is not the word, but I would say, rather, 'I am certain.'</div><div class="sentence"> For must they not have the same effect as when a man associates with bad characters, whom he likes and approves rather than dislikes, and only censures playfully because he has a suspicion of his own badness?</div><div class="sentence"> In that case, he who takes pleasure in them will surely become like those in whom he takes pleasure, even though he be ashamed to praise them.</div><div class="sentence"> And what greater good or evil can any destiny ever make us undergo?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">038</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I know of none.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">039</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then in a city which has good laws, or in future ages is to have them, bearing in mind the instruction and amusement which are given by music, can we suppose that the poets are to be allowed to teach in the dance anything which they themselves like, in the way of rhythm, or melody, or words, to the young children of any well-conditioned parents?</div><div class="sentence"> Is the poet to train his choruses as he pleases, without reference to virtue or vice?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">040</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That is surely quite unreasonable, and is not to be thought of.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">041</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And yet he may do this in almost any state with the exception of Egypt.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">042</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  And what are the laws about music and dancing in Egypt?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">043</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  You will wonder when I tell you:  Long ago they appear to have recognized the very principle of which we are now speaking—that their young citizens must be habituated to forms and strains of virtue.</div><div class="sentence"> These they fixed, and exhibited the patterns of them in their temples; and no painter or artist is allowed to innovate upon them, or to leave the traditional forms and invent new ones.</div><div class="sentence"> To this day, no alteration is allowed either in these arts, or in music at all.</div><div class="sentence"> And you will find that their works of art are painted or moulded in the same forms which they had ten thousand years ago;—this is literally true and no exaggeration,—their ancient paintings and sculptures are not a whit better or worse than the work of to-day, but are made with just the same skill.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">044</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How extraordinary!</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">045</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I should rather say, How statesmanlike, how worthy of a legislator!</div><div class="sentence"> I know that other things in Egypt are not so well.</div><div class="sentence"> But what I am telling you about music is true and deserving of consideration, because showing that a lawgiver may institute melodies which have a natural truth and correctness without any fear of failure.</div><div class="sentence"> To do this, however, must be the work of God, or of a divine person; in Egypt they have a tradition that their ancient chants which have been preserved for so many ages are the composition of the Goddess Isis.</div><div class="sentence"> And therefore, as I was saying, if a person can only find in any way the natural melodies, he may confidently embody them in a fixed and legal form.</div><div class="sentence"> For the love of novelty which arises out of pleasure in the new and weariness of the old, has not strength enough to corrupt the consecrated song and dance, under the plea that they have become antiquated.</div><div class="sentence"> At any rate, they are far from being corrupted in Egypt.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">046</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Your arguments seem to prove your point.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">047</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  May we not confidently say that the true use of music and of choral festivities is as follows:  We rejoice when we think that we prosper, and again we think that we prosper when we rejoice?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">048</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Exactly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">049</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And when rejoicing in our good fortune, we are unable to be still?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">050</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">051</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Our young men break forth into dancing and singing, and we who are their elders deem that we are fulfilling our part in life when we look on at them.</div><div class="sentence"> Having lost our agility, we delight in their sports and merry-making, because we love to think of our former selves; and gladly institute contests for those who are able to awaken in us the memory of our youth.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">052</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">053</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Is it altogether unmeaning to say, as the common people do about festivals, that he should be adjudged the wisest of men, and the winner of the palm, who gives us the greatest amount of pleasure and mirth?</div><div class="sentence"> For on such occasions, and when mirth is the order of the day, ought not he to be honoured most, and, as I was saying, bear the palm, who gives most mirth to the greatest number?</div><div class="sentence"> Now is this a true way of speaking or of acting?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">054</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Possibly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">055</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But, my dear friend, let us distinguish between different cases, and not be hasty in forming a judgment:  One way of considering the question will be to imagine a festival at which there are entertainments of all sorts, including gymnastic, musical, and equestrian contests:  the citizens are assembled; prizes are offered, and proclamation is made that any one who likes may enter the lists, and that he is to bear the palm who gives the most pleasure to the spectators—there is to be no regulation about the manner how; but he who is most successful in giving pleasure is to be crowned victor, and deemed to be the pleasantest of the candidates:  What is likely to be the result of such a proclamation?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">056</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  In what respect?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">057</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There would be various exhibitions:  one man, like Homer, will exhibit a rhapsody, another a performance on the lute; one will have a tragedy, and another a comedy.</div><div class="sentence"> Nor would there be anything astonishing in some one imagining that he could gain the prize by exhibiting a puppet-show.</div><div class="sentence"> Suppose these competitors to meet, and not these only, but innumerable others as well—can you tell me who ought to be the victor?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">058</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I do not see how any one can answer you, or pretend to know, unless he has heard with his own ears the several competitors; the question is absurd.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">059</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, then, if neither of you can answer, shall I answer this question which you deem so absurd?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">060</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  By all means.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">061</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  If very small children are to determine the question, they will decide for the puppet show.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">062</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Of course.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">063</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The older children will be advocates of comedy; educated women, and young men, and people in general, will favour tragedy.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">064</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very likely.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">065</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And I believe that we old men would have the greatest pleasure in hearing a rhapsodist recite well the Iliad and Odyssey, or one of the Hesiodic poems, and would award the victory to him.</div><div class="sentence"> But, who would really be the victor?—that is the question.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">066</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">067</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Clearly you and I will have to declare that those whom we old men adjudge victors ought to win; for our ways are far and away better than any which at present exist anywhere in the world.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">068</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">069</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Thus far I too should agree with the many, that the excellence of music is to be measured by pleasure.</div><div class="sentence"> But the pleasure must not be that of chance persons; the fairest music is that which delights the best and best educated, and especially that which delights the one man who is pre-eminent in virtue and education.</div><div class="sentence"> And therefore the judges must be men of character, for they will require both wisdom and courage; the true judge must not draw his inspiration from the theatre, nor ought he to be unnerved by the clamour of the many and his own incapacity; nor again, knowing the truth, ought he through cowardice and unmanliness carelessly to deliver a lying judgment, with the very same lips which have just appealed to the Gods before he judged.</div><div class="sentence"> He is sitting not as the disciple of the theatre, but, in his proper place, as their instructor, and he ought to be the enemy of all pandering to the pleasure of the spectators.</div><div class="sentence"> The ancient and common custom of Hellas, which still prevails in Italy and Sicily, did certainly leave the judgment to the body of spectators, who determined the victor by show of hands.</div><div class="sentence"> But this custom has been the destruction of the poets; for they are now in the habit of composing with a view to please the bad taste of their judges, and the result is that the spectators instruct themselves;—and also it has been the ruin of the theatre; they ought to be having characters put before them better than their own, and so receiving a higher pleasure, but now by their own act the opposite result follows.</div><div class="sentence"> What inference is to be drawn from all this?</div><div class="sentence"> Shall I tell you?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">070</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">071</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The inference at which we arrive for the third or fourth time is, that education is the constraining and directing of youth towards that right reason, which the law affirms, and which the experience of the eldest and best has agreed to be truly right.</div><div class="sentence"> In order, then, that the soul of the child may not be habituated to feel joy and sorrow in a manner at variance with the law, and those who obey the law, but may rather follow the law and rejoice and sorrow at the same things as the aged—in order, I say, to produce this effect, chants appear to have been invented, which really enchant, and are designed to implant that harmony of which we speak.</div><div class="sentence"> And, because the mind of the child is incapable of enduring serious training, they are called plays and songs, and are performed in play; just as when men are sick and ailing in their bodies, their attendants give them wholesome diet in pleasant meats and drinks, but unwholesome diet in disagreeable things, in order that they may learn, as they ought, to like the one, and to dislike the other.</div><div class="sentence"> And similarly the true legislator will persuade, and, if he cannot persuade, will compel the poet to express, as he ought, by fair and noble words, in his rhythms, the figures, and in his melodies, the music of temperate and brave and in every way good men.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">072</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  But do you really imagine, Stranger, that this is the way in which poets generally compose in States at the present day?</div><div class="sentence"> As far as I can observe, except among us and among the Lacedaemonians, there are no regulations like those of which you speak; in other places novelties are always being introduced in dancing and in music, generally not under the authority of any law, but at the instigation of lawless pleasures; and these pleasures are so far from being the same, as you describe the Egyptian to be, or having the same principles, that they are never the same.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">073</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Most true, Cleinias; and I daresay that I may have expressed myself obscurely, and so led you to imagine that I was speaking of some really existing state of things, whereas I was only saying what regulations I would like to have about music; and hence there occurred a misapprehension on your part.</div><div class="sentence"> For when evils are far gone and irremediable, the task of censuring them is never pleasant, although at times necessary.</div><div class="sentence"> But as we do not really differ, will you let me ask you whether you consider such institutions to be more prevalent among the Cretans and Lacedaemonians than among the other Hellenes?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">074</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly they are.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">075</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And if they were extended to the other Hellenes, would it be an improvement on the present state of things?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">076</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  A very great improvement, if the customs which prevail among them were such as prevail among us and the Lacedaemonians, and such as you were just now saying ought to prevail.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">077</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us see whether we understand one another: —Are not the principles of education and music which prevail among you as follows:  you compel your poets to say that the good man, if he be temperate and just, is fortunate and happy; and this whether he be great and strong or small and weak, and whether he be rich or poor; and, on the other hand, if he have a wealth passing that of Cinyras or Midas, and be unjust, he is wretched and lives in misery?</div><div class="sentence"> As the poet says, and with truth:  I sing not, I care not about him who accomplishes all noble things, not having justice; let him who 'draws near and stretches out his hand against his enemies be a just man.'</div><div class="sentence"> But if he be unjust, I would not have him 'look calmly upon bloody death,' nor 'surpass in swiftness the Thracian Boreas;' and let no other thing that is called good ever be his.</div><div class="sentence"> For the goods of which the many speak are not really good:  first in the catalogue is placed health, beauty next, wealth third; and then innumerable others, as for example to have a keen eye or a quick ear, and in general to have all the senses perfect; or, again, to be a tyrant and do as you like; and the final consummation of happiness is to have acquired all these things, and when you have acquired them to become at once immortal.</div><div class="sentence"> But you and I say, that while to the just and holy all these things are the best of possessions, to the unjust they are all, including even health, the greatest of evils.</div><div class="sentence"> For in truth, to have sight, and hearing, and the use of the senses, or to live at all without justice and virtue, even though a man be rich in all the so-called goods of fortune, is the greatest of evils, if life be immortal; but not so great, if the bad man lives only a very short time.</div><div class="sentence"> These are the truths which, if I am not mistaken, you will persuade or compel your poets to utter with suitable accompaniments of harmony and rhythm, and in these they must train up your youth.</div><div class="sentence"> Am I not right?</div><div class="sentence"> For I plainly declare that evils as they are termed are goods to the unjust, and only evils to the just, and that goods are truly good to the good, but evil to the evil.</div><div class="sentence"> Let me ask again, Are you and I agreed about this?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">078</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I think that we partly agree and partly do not.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">079</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  When a man has health and wealth and a tyranny which lasts, and when he is pre-eminent in strength and courage, and has the gift of immortality, and none of the so-called evils which counter-balance these goods, but only the injustice and insolence of his own nature—of such an one you are, I suspect, unwilling to believe that he is miserable rather than happy.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">080</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That is quite true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">081</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Once more:  Suppose that he be valiant and strong, and handsome and rich, and does throughout his whole life whatever he likes, still, if he be unrighteous and insolent, would not both of you agree that he will of necessity live basely?</div><div class="sentence"> You will surely grant so much?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">082</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">083</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And an evil life too?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">084</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I am not equally disposed to grant that.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">085</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Will he not live painfully and to his own disadvantage?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">086</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How can I possibly say so?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">087</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  How!</div><div class="sentence"> Then may Heaven make us to be of one mind, for now we are of two.</div><div class="sentence"> To me, dear Cleinias, the truth of what I am saying is as plain as the fact that Crete is an island.</div><div class="sentence"> And, if I were a lawgiver, I would try to make the poets and all the citizens speak in this strain, and I would inflict the heaviest penalties on any one in all the land who should dare to say that there are bad men who lead pleasant lives, or that the profitable and gainful is one thing, and the just another; and there are many other matters about which I should make my citizens speak in a manner different from the Cretans and Lacedaemonians of this age, and I may say, indeed, from the world in general.</div><div class="sentence"> For tell me, my good friends, by Zeus and Apollo tell me, if I were to ask these same Gods who were your legislators,—Is not the most just life also the pleasantest?</div><div class="sentence"> or are there two lives, one of which is the justest and the other the pleasantest?—and they were to reply that there are two; and thereupon I proceeded to ask, (that would be the right way of pursuing the enquiry), Which are the happier—those who lead the justest, or those who lead the pleasantest life?</div><div class="sentence"> and they replied, Those who lead the pleasantest—that would be a very strange answer, which I should not like to put into the mouth of the Gods.</div><div class="sentence"> The words will come with more propriety from the lips of fathers and legislators, and therefore I will repeat my former questions to one of them, and suppose him to say again that he who leads the pleasantest life is the happiest.</div><div class="sentence"> And to that I rejoin: —O my father, did you not wish me to live as happily as possible?</div><div class="sentence"> And yet you also never ceased telling me that I should live as justly as possible.</div><div class="sentence"> Now, here the giver of the rule, whether he be legislator or father, will be in a dilemma, and will in vain endeavour to be consistent with himself.</div><div class="sentence"> But if he were to declare that the justest life is also the happiest, every one hearing him would enquire, if I am not mistaken, what is that good and noble principle in life which the law approves, and which is superior to pleasure.</div><div class="sentence"> For what good can the just man have which is separated from pleasure?</div><div class="sentence"> Shall we say that glory and fame, coming from Gods and men, though good and noble, are nevertheless unpleasant, and infamy pleasant?</div><div class="sentence"> Certainly not, sweet legislator.</div><div class="sentence"> Or shall we say that the not-doing of wrong and there being no wrong done is good and honourable, although there is no pleasure in it, and that the doing wrong is pleasant, but evil and base?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">088</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Impossible.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">089</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The view which identifies the pleasant and the pleasant and the just and the good and the noble has an excellent moral and religious tendency.</div><div class="sentence"> And the opposite view is most at variance with the designs of the legislator, and is, in his opinion, infamous; for no one, if he can help, will be persuaded to do that which gives him more pain than pleasure.</div><div class="sentence"> But as distant prospects are apt to make us dizzy, especially in childhood, the legislator will try to purge away the darkness and exhibit the truth; he will persuade the citizens, in some way or other, by customs and praises and words, that just and unjust are shadows only, and that injustice, which seems opposed to justice, when contemplated by the unjust and evil man appears pleasant and the just most unpleasant; but that from the just man's point of view, the very opposite is the appearance of both of them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">090</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">091</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And which may be supposed to be the truer judgment—that of the inferior or of the better soul?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">092</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Surely, that of the better soul.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">093</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then the unjust life must not only be more base and depraved, but also more unpleasant than the just and holy life?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">094</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That seems to be implied in the present argument.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">095</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And even supposing this were otherwise, and not as the argument has proven, still the lawgiver, who is worth anything, if he ever ventures to tell a lie to the young for their good, could not invent a more useful lie than this, or one which will have a better effect in making them do what is right, not on compulsion but voluntarily.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">096</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Truth, Stranger, is a noble thing and a lasting, but a thing of which men are hard to be persuaded.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">097</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And yet the story of the Sidonian Cadmus, which is so improbable, has been readily believed, and also innumerable other tales.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">098</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What is that story?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">099</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The story of armed men springing up after the sowing of teeth, which the legislator may take as a proof that he can persuade the minds of the young of anything; so that he has only to reflect and find out what belief will be of the greatest public advantage, and then use all his efforts to make the whole community utter one and the same word in their songs and tales and discourses all their life long.</div><div class="sentence"> But if you do not agree with me, there is no reason why you should not argue on the other side.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">100</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I do not see that any argument can fairly be raised by either of us against what you are now saying.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">101</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The next suggestion which I have to offer is, that all our three choruses shall sing to the young and tender souls of children, reciting in their strains all the noble thoughts of which we have already spoken, or are about to speak; and the sum of them shall be, that the life which is by the Gods deemed to be the happiest is also the best;—we shall affirm this to be a most certain truth; and the minds of our young disciples will be more likely to receive these words of ours than any others which we might address to them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">102</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I assent to what you say.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">103</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  First will enter in their natural order the sacred choir composed of children, which is to sing lustily the heaven-taught lay to the whole city.</div><div class="sentence"> Next will follow the choir of young men under the age of thirty, who will call upon the God Paean to testify to the truth of their words, and will pray him to be gracious to the youth and to turn their hearts.</div><div class="sentence"> Thirdly, the choir of elder men, who are from thirty to sixty years of age, will also sing.</div><div class="sentence"> There remain those who are too old to sing, and they will tell stories, illustrating the same virtues, as with the voice of an oracle.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">104</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Who are those who compose the third choir, Stranger?</div><div class="sentence"> for I do not clearly understand what you mean to say about them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">105</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And yet almost all that I have been saying has been said with a view to them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">106</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Will you try to be a little plainer?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">107</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I was speaking at the commencement of our discourse, as you will remember, of the fiery nature of young creatures:  I said that they were unable to keep quiet either in limb or voice, and that they called out and jumped about in a disorderly manner; and that no other animal attained to any perception of order, but man only.</div><div class="sentence"> Now the order of motion is called rhythm, and the order of the voice, in which high and low are duly mingled, is called harmony; and both together are termed choric song.</div><div class="sentence"> And I said that the Gods had pity on us, and gave us Apollo and the Muses to be our playfellows and leaders in the dance; and Dionysus, as I dare say that you will remember, was the third.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">108</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I quite remember.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">109</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Thus far I have spoken of the chorus of Apollo and the Muses, and I have still to speak of the remaining chorus, which is that of Dionysus.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">110</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How is that arranged?</div><div class="sentence"> There is something strange, at any rate on first hearing, in a Dionysiac chorus of old men, if you really mean that those who are above thirty, and may be fifty, or from fifty to sixty years of age, are to dance in his honour.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">111</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Very true; and therefore it must be shown that there is good reason for the proposal.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">112</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">113</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Are we agreed thus far?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">114</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  About what?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">115</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  That every man and boy, slave and free, both sexes, and the whole city, should never cease charming themselves with the strains of which we have spoken; and that there should be every sort of change and variation of them in order to take away the effect of sameness, so that the singers may always receive pleasure from their hymns, and may never weary of them?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">116</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Every one will agree.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">117</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Where, then, will that best part of our city which, by reason of age and intelligence, has the greatest influence, sing these fairest of strains, which are to do so much good?</div><div class="sentence"> Shall we be so foolish as to let them off who would give us the most beautiful and also the most useful of songs?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">118</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  But, says the argument, we cannot let them off.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">119</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then how can we carry out our purpose with decorum?</div><div class="sentence"> Will this be the way?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">120</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">121</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  When a man is advancing in years, he is afraid and reluctant to sing;—he has no pleasure in his own performances; and if compulsion is used, he will be more and more ashamed, the older and more discreet he grows;—is not this true?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">122</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">123</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, and will he not be yet more ashamed if he has to stand up and sing in the theatre to a mixed audience?—and if moreover when he is required to do so, like the other choirs who contend for prizes, and have been trained under a singing master, he is pinched and hungry, he will certainly have a feeling of shame and discomfort which will make him very unwilling to exhibit.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">124</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  No doubt.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">125</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  How, then, shall we reassure him, and get him to sing?</div><div class="sentence"> Shall we begin by enacting that boys shall not taste wine at all until they are eighteen years of age; we will tell them that fire must not be poured upon fire, whether in the body or in the soul, until they begin to go to work—this is a precaution which has to be taken against the excitableness of youth;—afterwards they may taste wine in moderation up to the age of thirty, but while a man is young he should abstain altogether from intoxication and from excess of wine; when, at length, he has reached forty years, after dinner at a public mess, he may invite not only the other Gods, but Dionysus above all, to the mystery and festivity of the elder men, making use of the wine which he has given men to lighten the sourness of old age; that in age we may renew our youth, and forget our sorrows; and also in order that the nature of the soul, like iron melted in the fire, may become softer and so more impressible.</div><div class="sentence"> In the first place, will not any one who is thus mellowed be more ready and less ashamed to sing—I do not say before a large audience, but before a moderate company; nor yet among strangers, but among his familiars, and, as we have often said, to chant, and to enchant?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">126</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  He will be far more ready.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">127</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There will be no impropriety in our using such a method of persuading them to join with us in song.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">128</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  None at all.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">129</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And what strain will they sing, and what muse will they hymn?</div><div class="sentence"> The strain should clearly be one suitable to them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">130</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">131</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And what strain is suitable for heroes?</div><div class="sentence"> Shall they sing a choric strain?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">132</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Truly, Stranger, we of Crete and Lacedaemon know no strain other than that which we have learnt and been accustomed to sing in our chorus.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">133</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I dare say; for you have never acquired the knowledge of the most beautiful kind of song, in your military way of life, which is modelled after the camp, and is not like that of dwellers in cities; and you have your young men herding and feeding together like young colts.</div><div class="sentence"> No one takes his own individual colt and drags him away from his fellows against his will, raging and foaming, and gives him a groom to attend to him alone, and trains and rubs him down privately, and gives him the qualities in education which will make him not only a good soldier, but also a governor of a state and of cities.</div><div class="sentence"> Such an one, as we said at first, would be a greater warrior than he of whom Tyrtaeus sings; and he would honour courage everywhere, but always as the fourth, and not as the first part of virtue, either in individuals or states.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">134</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Once more, Stranger, I must complain that you depreciate our lawgivers.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">135</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Not intentionally, if at all, my good friend; but whither the argument leads, thither let us follow; for if there be indeed some strain of song more beautiful than that of the choruses or the public theatres, I should like to impart it to those who, as we say, are ashamed of these, and want to have the best.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">136</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">137</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  When things have an accompanying charm, either the best thing in them is this very charm, or there is some rightness or utility possessed by them;—for example, I should say that eating and drinking, and the use of food in general, have an accompanying charm which we call pleasure; but that this rightness and utility is just the healthfulness of the things served up to us, which is their true rightness.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">138</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Just so.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">139</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Thus, too, I should say that learning has a certain accompanying charm which is the pleasure; but that the right and the profitable, the good and the noble, are qualities which the truth gives to it.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">140</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Exactly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">141</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And so in the imitative arts—if they succeed in making likenesses, and are accompanied by pleasure, may not their works be said to have a charm?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">142</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">143</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But equal proportions, whether of quality or quantity, and not pleasure, speaking generally, would give them truth or rightness.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">144</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">145</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then that only can be rightly judged by the standard of pleasure, which makes or furnishes no utility or truth or likeness, nor on the other hand is productive of any hurtful quality, but exists solely for the sake of the accompanying charm; and the term 'pleasure' is most appropriately applied to it when these other qualities are absent.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">146</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You are speaking of harmless pleasure, are you not?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">147</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes; and this I term amusement, when doing neither harm nor good in any degree worth speaking of.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">148</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">149</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then, if such be our principles, we must assert that imitation is not to be judged of by pleasure and false opinion; and this is true of all equality, for the equal is not equal or the symmetrical symmetrical, because somebody thinks or likes something, but they are to be judged of by the standard of truth, and by no other whatever.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">150</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Quite true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">151</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Do we not regard all music as representative and imitative?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">152</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">153</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then, when any one says that music is to be judged of by pleasure, his doctrine cannot be admitted; and if there be any music of which pleasure is the criterion, such music is not to be sought out or deemed to have any real excellence, but only that other kind of music which is an imitation of the good.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">154</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">155</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And those who seek for the best kind of song and music ought not to seek for that which is pleasant, but for that which is true; and the truth of imitation consists, as we were saying, in rendering the thing imitated according to quantity and quality.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">156</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">157</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And every one will admit that musical compositions are all imitative and representative.</div><div class="sentence"> Will not poets and spectators and actors all agree in this?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">158</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  They will.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">159</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Surely then he who would judge correctly must know what each composition is; for if he does not know what is the character and meaning of the piece, and what it represents, he will never discern whether the intention is true or false.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">160</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly not.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">161</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And will he who does not know what is true be able to distinguish what is good and bad?</div><div class="sentence"> My statement is not very clear; but perhaps you will understand me better if I put the matter in another way.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">162</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">163</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There are ten thousand likenesses of objects of sight?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">164</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">165</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And can he who does not know what the exact object is which is imitated, ever know whether the resemblance is truthfully executed?</div><div class="sentence"> I mean, for example, whether a statue has the proportions of a body, and the true situation of the parts; what those proportions are, and how the parts fit into one another in due order; also their colours and conformations, or whether this is all confused in the execution:  do you think that any one can know about this, who does not know what the animal is which has been imitated?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">166</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Impossible.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">167</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But even if we know that the thing pictured or sculptured is a man, who has received at the hand of the artist all his proper parts and colours and shapes, must we not also know whether the work is beautiful or in any respect deficient in beauty?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">168</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  If this were not required, Stranger, we should all of us be judges of beauty.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">169</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Very true; and may we not say that in everything imitated, whether in drawing, music, or any other art, he who is to be a competent judge must possess three things;—he must know, in the first place, of what the imitation is; secondly, he must know that it is true; and thirdly, that it has been well executed in words and melodies and rhythms?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">170</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">171</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then let us not faint in discussing the peculiar difficulty of music.</div><div class="sentence"> Music is more celebrated than any other kind of imitation, and therefore requires the greatest care of them all.</div><div class="sentence"> For if a man makes a mistake here, he may do himself the greatest injury by welcoming evil dispositions, and the mistake may be very difficult to discern, because the poets are artists very inferior in character to the Muses themselves, who would never fall into the monstrous error of assigning to the words of men the gestures and songs of women;
