nor after combining the melodies with the gestures of freemen would they add on the rhythms of slaves and men of the baser sort; nor, beginning with the rhythms and gestures of freemen, would they assign to them a melody or words which are of an opposite character; nor would they mix up the voices and sounds of animals and of men and instruments, and every other sort of noise, as if they were all one.</div><div class="sentence"> But human poets are fond of introducing this sort of inconsistent mixture, and so make themselves ridiculous in the eyes of those who, as Orpheus says, 'are ripe for true pleasure.'</div><div class="sentence"> The experienced see all this confusion, and yet the poets go on and make still further havoc by separating the rhythm and the figure of the dance from the melody, setting bare words to metre, and also separating the melody and the rhythm from the words, using the lyre or the flute alone.</div><div class="sentence"> For when there are no words, it is very difficult to recognize the meaning of the harmony and rhythm, or to see that any worthy object is imitated by them.</div><div class="sentence"> And we must acknowledge that all this sort of thing, which aims only at swiftness and smoothness and a brutish noise, and uses the flute and the lyre not as the mere accompaniments of the dance and song, is exceedingly coarse and tasteless.</div><div class="sentence"> The use of either instrument, when unaccompanied, leads to every sort of irregularity and trickery.</div><div class="sentence"> This is all rational enough.</div><div class="sentence"> But we are considering not how our choristers, who are from thirty to fifty years of age, and may be over fifty, are not to use the Muses, but how they are to use them.</div><div class="sentence"> And the considerations which we have urged seem to show in what way these fifty years' old choristers who are to sing, may be expected to be better trained.</div><div class="sentence"> For they need to have a quick perception and knowledge of harmonies and rhythms; otherwise, how can they ever know whether a melody would be rightly sung to the Dorian mode, or to the rhythm which the poet has assigned to it?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">172</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Clearly they cannot.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">173</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The many are ridiculous in imagining that they know what is in proper harmony and rhythm, and what is not, when they can only be made to sing and step in rhythm by force; it never occurs to them that they are ignorant of what they are doing.</div><div class="sentence"> Now every melody is right when it has suitable harmony and rhythm, and wrong when unsuitable.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">174</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That is most certain.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">175</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But can a man who does not know a thing, as we were saying, know that the thing is right?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">176</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Impossible.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">177</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then now, as would appear, we are making the discovery that our newly-appointed choristers, whom we hereby invite and, although they are their own masters, compel to sing, must be educated to such an extent as to be able to follow the steps of the rhythm and the notes of the song, that they may know the harmonies and rhythms, and be able to select what are suitable for men of their age and character to sing; and may sing them, and have innocent pleasure from their own performance, and also lead younger men to welcome with dutiful delight good dispositions.</div><div class="sentence"> Having such training, they will attain a more accurate knowledge than falls to the lot of the common people, or even of the poets themselves.</div><div class="sentence"> For the poet need not know the third point, viz., whether the imitation is good or not, though he can hardly help knowing the laws of melody and rhythm.</div><div class="sentence"> But the aged chorus must know all the three, that they may choose the best, and that which is nearest to the best; for otherwise they will never be able to charm the souls of young men in the way of virtue.</div><div class="sentence"> And now the original design of the argument which was intended to bring eloquent aid to the Chorus of Dionysus, has been accomplished to the best of our ability, and let us see whether we were right: —I should imagine that a drinking assembly is likely to become more and more tumultuous as the drinking goes on:  this, as we were saying at first, will certainly be the case.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">178</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">179</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Every man has a more than natural elevation; his heart is glad within him, and he will say anything and will be restrained by nobody at such a time; he fancies that he is able to rule over himself and all mankind.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">180</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Quite true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">181</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Were we not saying that on such occasions the souls of the drinkers become like iron heated in the fire, and grow softer and younger, and are easily moulded by him who knows how to educate and fashion them, just as when they were young, and that this fashioner of them is the same who prescribed for them in the days of their youth, viz., the good legislator; and that he ought to enact laws of the banquet, which, when a man is confident, bold, and impudent, and unwilling to wait his turn and have his share of silence and speech, and drinking and music, will change his character into the opposite—such laws as will infuse into him a just and noble fear, which will take up arms at the approach of insolence, being that divine fear which we have called reverence and shame?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">182</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">183</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And the guardians of these laws and fellow-workers with them are the calm and sober generals of the drinkers; and without their help there is greater difficulty in fighting against drink than in fighting against enemies when the commander of an army is not himself calm; and he who is unwilling to obey them and the commanders of Dionysiac feasts who are more than sixty years of age, shall suffer a disgrace as great as he who disobeys military leaders, or even greater.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">184</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Right.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">185</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  If, then, drinking and amusement were regulated in this way, would not the companions of our revels be improved?</div><div class="sentence"> they would part better friends than they were, and not, as now, enemies.</div><div class="sentence"> Their whole intercourse would be regulated by law and observant of it, and the sober would be the leaders of the drunken.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">186</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I think so too, if drinking were regulated as you propose.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">187</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us not then simply censure the gift of Dionysus as bad and unfit to be received into the State.</div><div class="sentence"> For wine has many excellences, and one pre-eminent one, about which there is a difficulty in speaking to the many, from a fear of their misconceiving and misunderstanding what is said.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">188</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To what do you refer?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">189</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There is a tradition or story, which has somehow crept about the world, that Dionysus was robbed of his wits by his stepmother Here, and that out of revenge he inspires Bacchic furies and dancing madnesses in others; for which reason he gave men wine.</div><div class="sentence"> Such traditions concerning the Gods I leave to those who think that they may be safely uttered (compare Euthyph.</div><div class="sentence"> ; Republic); I only know that no animal at birth is mature or perfect in intelligence; and in the intermediate period, in which he has not yet acquired his own proper sense, he rages and roars without rhyme or reason; and when he has once got on his legs he jumps about without rhyme or reason; and this, as you will remember, has been already said by us to be the origin of music and gymnastic.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">190</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To be sure, I remember.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">191</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And did we not say that the sense of harmony and rhythm sprang from this beginning among men, and that Apollo and the Muses and Dionysus were the Gods whom we had to thank for them?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">192</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">193</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The other story implied that wine was given man out of revenge, and in order to make him mad; but our present doctrine, on the contrary, is, that wine was given him as a balm, and in order to implant modesty in the soul, and health and strength in the body.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">194</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That, Stranger, is precisely what was said.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">195</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then half the subject may now be considered to have been discussed; shall we proceed to the consideration of the other half?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">196</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What is the other half, and how do you divide the subject?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">197</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The whole choral art is also in our view the whole of education; and of this art, rhythms and harmonies form the part which has to do with the voice.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">198</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">199</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The movement of the body has rhythm in common with the movement of the voice, but gesture is peculiar to it, whereas song is simply the movement of the voice.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">200</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Most true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">201</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And the sound of the voice which reaches and educates the soul, we have ventured to term music.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">202</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  We were right.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">203</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And the movement of the body, when regarded as an amusement, we termed dancing; but when extended and pursued with a view to the excellence of the body, this scientific training may be called gymnastic.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">204</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Exactly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">205</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Music, which was one half of the choral art, may be said to have been completely discussed.</div><div class="sentence"> Shall we proceed to the other half or not?</div><div class="sentence"> What would you like?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">206</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  My good friend, when you are talking with a Cretan and Lacedaemonian, and we have discussed music and not gymnastic, what answer are either of us likely to make to such an enquiry?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">207</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  An answer is contained in your question; and I understand and accept what you say not only as an answer, but also as a command to proceed with gymnastic.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">208</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You quite understand me; do as you say.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">209</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I will; and there will not be any difficulty in speaking intelligibly to you about a subject with which both of you are far more familiar than with music.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">210</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  There will not.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">211</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Is not the origin of gymnastics, too, to be sought in the tendency to rapid motion which exists in all animals; man, as we were saying, having attained the sense of rhythm, created and invented dancing; and melody arousing and awakening rhythm, both united formed the choral art?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">212</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">213</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And one part of this subject has been already discussed by us, and there still remains another to be discussed?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">214</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Exactly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">215</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I have first a final word to add to my discourse about drink, if you will allow me to do so.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">216</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What more have you to say?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">217</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I should say that if a city seriously means to adopt the practice of drinking under due regulation and with a view to the enforcement of temperance, and in like manner, and on the same principle, will allow of other pleasures, designing to gain the victory over them—in this way all of them may be used.</div><div class="sentence"> But if the State makes drinking an amusement only, and whoever likes may drink whenever he likes, and with whom he likes, and add to this any other indulgences, I shall never agree or allow that this city or this man should practise drinking.</div><div class="sentence"> I would go further than the Cretans and Lacedaemonians, and am disposed rather to the law of the Carthaginians, that no one while he is on a campaign should be allowed to taste wine at all, but that he should drink water during all that time, and that in the city no slave, male or female, should ever drink wine; and that no magistrates should drink during their year of office, nor should pilots of vessels or judges while on duty taste wine at all, nor any one who is going to hold a consultation about any matter of importance; nor in the day-time at all, unless in consequence of exercise or as medicine; nor again at night, when any one, either man or woman, is minded to get children.</div><div class="sentence"> There are numberless other cases also in which those who have good sense and good laws ought not to drink wine, so that if what I say is true, no city will need many vineyards.</div><div class="sentence"> Their husbandry and their way of life in general will follow an appointed order, and their cultivation of the vine will be the most limited and the least common of their employments.</div><div class="sentence"> And this, Stranger, shall be the crown of my discourse about wine, if you agree.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">218</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Excellent:  we agree.</div></div>

</div><div id="link2H_4_0006" class="book_section">
<h2>BOOK III.</h2>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">001</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Enough of this.</div><div class="sentence"> And what, then, is to be regarded as the origin of government?</div><div class="sentence"> Will not a man be able to judge of it best from a point of view in which he may behold the progress of states and their transitions to good or evil?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">002</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">003</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I mean that he might watch them from the point of view of time, and observe the changes which take place in them during infinite ages.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">004</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How so?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">005</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Why, do you think that you can reckon the time which has elapsed since cities first existed and men were citizens of them?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">006</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Hardly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">007</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But are sure that it must be vast and incalculable?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">008</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">009</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And have not thousands and thousands of cities come into being during this period and as many perished?</div><div class="sentence"> And has not each of them had every form of government many times over, now growing larger, now smaller, and again improving or declining?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">010</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To be sure.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">011</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us endeavour to ascertain the cause of these changes; for that will probably explain the first origin and development of forms of government.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">012</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very good.</div><div class="sentence"> You shall endeavour to impart your thoughts to us, and we will make an effort to understand you.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">013</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Do you believe that there is any truth in ancient traditions?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">014</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What traditions?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">015</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The traditions about the many destructions of mankind which have been occasioned by deluges and pestilences, and in many other ways, and of the survival of a remnant?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">016</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Every one is disposed to believe them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">017</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us consider one of them, that which was caused by the famous deluge.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">018</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What are we to observe about it?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">019</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I mean to say that those who then escaped would only be hill shepherds,—small sparks of the human race preserved on the tops of mountains.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">020</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Clearly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">021</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Such survivors would necessarily be unacquainted with the arts and the various devices which are suggested to the dwellers in cities by interest or ambition, and with all the wrongs which they contrive against one another.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">022</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">023</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us suppose, then, that the cities in the plain and on the sea-coast were utterly destroyed at that time.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">024</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very good.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">025</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Would not all implements have then perished and every other excellent invention of political or any other sort of wisdom have utterly disappeared?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">026</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Why, yes, my friend; and if things had always continued as they are at present ordered, how could any discovery have ever been made even in the least particular?</div><div class="sentence"> For it is evident that the arts were unknown during ten thousand times ten thousand years.</div><div class="sentence"> And no more than a thousand or two thousand years have elapsed since the discoveries of Daedalus, Orpheus and Palamedes,—since Marsyas and Olympus invented music, and Amphion the lyre—not to speak of numberless other inventions which are but of yesterday.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">027</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Have you forgotten, Cleinias, the name of a friend who is really of yesterday?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">028</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I suppose that you mean Epimenides.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">029</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The same, my friend; he does indeed far overleap the heads of all mankind by his invention; for he carried out in practice, as you declare, what of old Hesiod (Works and Days) only preached.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">030</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, according to our tradition.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">031</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  After the great destruction, may we not suppose that the state of man was something of this sort: —In the beginning of things there was a fearful illimitable desert and a vast expanse of land; a herd or two of oxen would be the only survivors of the animal world; and there might be a few goats, these too hardly enough to maintain the shepherds who tended them?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">032</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">033</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And of cities or governments or legislation, about which we are now talking, do you suppose that they could have any recollection at all?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">034</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  None whatever.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">035</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And out of this state of things has there not sprung all that we now are and have:  cities and governments, and arts and laws, and a great deal of vice and a great deal of virtue?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">036</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">037</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Why, my good friend, how can we possibly suppose that those who knew nothing of all the good and evil of cities could have attained their full development, whether of virtue or of vice?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">038</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I understand your meaning, and you are quite right.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">039</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But, as time advanced and the race multiplied, the world came to be what the world is.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">040</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">041</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Doubtless the change was not made all in a moment, but little by little, during a very long period of time.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">042</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  A highly probable supposition.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">043</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  At first, they would have a natural fear ringing in their ears which would prevent their descending from the heights into the plain.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">044</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Of course.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">045</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The fewness of the survivors at that time would have made them all the more desirous of seeing one another; but then the means of travelling either by land or sea had been almost entirely lost, as I may say, with the loss of the arts, and there was great difficulty in getting at one another; for iron and brass and all metals were jumbled together and had disappeared in the chaos; nor was there any possibility of extracting ore from them; and they had scarcely any means of felling timber.</div><div class="sentence"> Even if you suppose that some implements might have been preserved in the mountains, they must quickly have worn out and vanished, and there would be no more of them until the art of metallurgy had again revived.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">046</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  There could not have been.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">047</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In how many generations would this be attained?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">048</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Clearly, not for many generations.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">049</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  During this period, and for some time afterwards, all the arts which require iron and brass and the like would disappear.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">050</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">051</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Faction and war would also have died out in those days, and for many reasons.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">052</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How would that be?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">053</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In the first place, the desolation of these primitive men would create in them a feeling of affection and goodwill towards one another; and, secondly, they would have no occasion to quarrel about their subsistence, for they would have pasture in abundance, except just at first, and in some particular cases; and from their pasture-land they would obtain the greater part of their food in a primitive age, having plenty of milk and flesh; moreover they would procure other food by the chase, not to be despised either in quantity or quality.</div><div class="sentence"> They would also have abundance of clothing, and bedding, and dwellings, and utensils either capable of standing on the fire or not; for the plastic and weaving arts do not require any use of iron:  and God has given these two arts to man in order to provide him with all such things, that, when reduced to the last extremity, the human race may still grow and increase.</div><div class="sentence"> Hence in those days mankind were not very poor; nor was poverty a cause of difference among them; and rich they could not have been, having neither gold nor silver: —such at that time was their condition.</div><div class="sentence"> And the community which has neither poverty nor riches will always have the noblest principles; in it there is no insolence or injustice, nor, again, are there any contentions or envyings.</div><div class="sentence"> And therefore they were good, and also because they were what is called simple-minded; and when they were told about good and evil, they in their simplicity believed what they heard to be very truth and practised it.</div><div class="sentence"> No one had the wit to suspect another of a falsehood, as men do now; but what they heard about Gods and men they believed to be true, and lived accordingly; and therefore they were in all respects such as we have described them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">054</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That quite accords with my views, and with those of my friend here.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">055</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Would not many generations living on in a simple manner, although ruder, perhaps, and more ignorant of the arts generally, and in particular of those of land or naval warfare, and likewise of other arts, termed in cities legal practices and party conflicts, and including all conceivable ways of hurting one another in word and deed;—although inferior to those who lived before the deluge, or to the men of our day in these respects, would they not, I say, be simpler and more manly, and also more temperate and altogether more just?</div><div class="sentence"> The reason has been already explained.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">056</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">057</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I should wish you to understand that what has preceded and what is about to follow, has been, and will be said, with the intention of explaining what need the men of that time had of laws, and who was their lawgiver.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">058</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  And thus far what you have said has been very well said.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">059</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  They could hardly have wanted lawgivers as yet; nothing of that sort was likely to have existed in their days, for they had no letters at this early period; they lived by habit and the customs of their ancestors, as they are called.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">060</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Probably.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">061</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But there was already existing a form of government which, if I am not mistaken, is generally termed a lordship, and this still remains in many places, both among Hellenes and barbarians (compare Arist.</div><div class="sentence"> Pol.</div><div class="sentence"> ), and is the government which is declared by Homer to have prevailed among the Cyclopes: —</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">062</span> <div class="sentence">  'They have neither councils nor judgments, but they dwell in hollow caves on the tops of high mountains, and every one gives law to his wife and children, and they do not busy themselves about one another.'</div><div class="sentence"> (Odyss.)</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">063</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That seems to be a charming poet of yours; I have read some other verses of his, which are very clever; but I do not know much of him, for foreign poets are very little read among the Cretans.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">064</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  But they are in Lacedaemon, and he appears to be the prince of them all; the manner of life, however, which he describes is not Spartan, but rather Ionian, and he seems quite to confirm what you are saying, when he traces up the ancient state of mankind by the help of tradition to barbarism.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">065</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, he does confirm it; and we may accept his witness to the fact that such forms of government sometimes arise.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">066</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  We may.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">067</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And were not such states composed of men who had been dispersed in single habitations and families by the poverty which attended the devastations; and did not the eldest then rule among them, because with them government originated in the authority of a father and a mother, whom, like a flock of birds, they followed, forming one troop under the patriarchal rule and sovereignty of their parents, which of all sovereignties is the most just?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">068</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">069</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  After this they came together in greater numbers, and increased the size of their cities, and betook themselves to husbandry, first of all at the foot of the mountains, and made enclosures of loose walls and works of defence, in order to keep off wild beasts; thus creating a single large and common habitation.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">070</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes; at least we may suppose so.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">071</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There is another thing which would probably happen.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">072</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">073</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  When these larger habitations grew up out of the lesser original ones, each of the lesser ones would survive in the larger; every family would be under the rule of the eldest, and, owing to their separation from one another, would have peculiar customs in things divine and human, which they would have received from their several parents who had educated them; and these customs would incline them to order, when the parents had the element of order in their nature, and to courage, when they had the element of courage.</div><div class="sentence"> And they would naturally stamp upon their children, and upon their children's children, their own likings; and, as we are saying, they would find their way into the larger society, having already their own peculiar laws.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">074</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">075</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And every man surely likes his own laws best, and the laws of others not so well.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">076</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">077</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then now we seem to have stumbled upon the beginnings of legislation.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">078</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Exactly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">079</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The next step will be that these persons who have met together, will select some arbiters, who will review the laws of all of them, and will publicly present such as they approve to the chiefs who lead the tribes, and who are in a manner their kings, allowing them to choose those which they think best.</div><div class="sentence"> These persons will themselves be called legislators, and will appoint the magistrates, framing some sort of aristocracy, or perhaps monarchy, out of the dynasties or lordships, and in this altered state of the government they will live.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">080</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, that would be the natural order of things.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">081</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then, now let us speak of a third form of government, in which all other forms and conditions of polities and cities concur.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">082</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What is that?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">083</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The form which in fact Homer indicates as following the second.</div><div class="sentence"> This third form arose when, as he says, Dardanus founded Dardania: —</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">084</span> <div class="sentence">  'For not as yet had the holy Ilium been built on the plain to be a city of speaking men; but they were still dwelling at the foot of many-fountained Ida.'</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">085</span> <div class="sentence">  For indeed, in these verses, and in what he said of the Cyclopes, he speaks the words of God and nature; for poets are a divine race, and often in their strains, by the aid of the Muses and the Graces, they attain truth.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">086</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">087</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then now let us proceed with the rest of our tale, which will probably be found to illustrate in some degree our proposed design: —Shall we do so?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">088</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  By all means.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">089</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Ilium was built, when they descended from the mountain, in a large and fair plain, on a sort of low hill, watered by many rivers descending from Ida.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">090</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Such is the tradition.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">091</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And we must suppose this event to have taken place many ages after the deluge?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">092</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  A marvellous forgetfulness of the former destruction would appear to have come over them, when they placed their town right under numerous streams flowing from the heights, trusting for their security to not very high hills, either.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">093</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  There must have been a long interval, clearly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">094</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And, as population increased, many other cities would begin to be inhabited.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">095</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Doubtless.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">096</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Those cities made war against Troy—by sea as well as land—for at that time men were ceasing to be afraid of the sea.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">097</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Clearly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">098</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The Achaeans remained ten years, and overthrew Troy.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">099</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">100</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And during the ten years in which the Achaeans were besieging Ilium, the homes of the besiegers were falling into an evil plight.</div><div class="sentence"> Their youth revolted; and when the soldiers returned to their own cities and families, they did not receive them properly, and as they ought to have done, and numerous deaths, murders, exiles, were the consequence.</div><div class="sentence"> The exiles came again, under a new name, no longer Achaeans, but Dorians,—a name which they derived from Dorieus; for it was he who gathered them together.</div><div class="sentence"> The rest of the story is told by you Lacedaemonians as part of the history of Sparta.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">101</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  To be sure.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">102</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Thus, after digressing from the original subject of laws into music and drinking-bouts, the argument has, providentially, come back to the same point, and presents to us another handle.</div><div class="sentence"> For we have reached the settlement of Lacedaemon; which, as you truly say, is in laws and in institutions the sister of Crete.</div><div class="sentence"> And we are all the better for the digression, because we have gone through various governments and settlements, and have been present at the foundation of a first, second, and third state, succeeding one another in infinite time.</div><div class="sentence"> And now there appears on the horizon a fourth state or nation which was once in process of settlement and has continued settled to this day.</div><div class="sentence"> If, out of all this, we are able to discern what is well or ill settled, and what laws are the salvation and what are the destruction of cities, and what changes would make a state happy, O Megillus and Cleinias, we may now begin again, unless we have some fault to find with the previous discussion.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">103</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  If some God, Stranger, would promise us that our new enquiry about legislation would be as good and full as the present, I would go a great way to hear such another, and would think that a day as long as this—and we are now approaching the longest day of the year—was too short for the discussion.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">104</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then I suppose that we must consider this subject?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">105</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">106</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us place ourselves in thought at the moment when Lacedaemon and Argos and Messene and the rest of the Peloponnesus were all in complete subjection, Megillus, to your ancestors; for afterwards, as the legend informs us, they divided their army into three portions, and settled three cities, Argos, Messene, Lacedaemon.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">107</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">108</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Temenus was the king of Argos, Cresphontes of Messene, Procles and Eurysthenes of Lacedaemon.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">109</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">110</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  To these kings all the men of that day made oath that they would assist them, if any one subverted their kingdom.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">111</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">112</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But can a kingship be destroyed, or was any other form of government ever destroyed, by any but the rulers themselves?</div><div class="sentence"> No indeed, by Zeus.</div><div class="sentence"> Have we already forgotten what was said a little while ago?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">113</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  No.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">114</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And may we not now further confirm what was then mentioned?</div><div class="sentence"> For we have come upon facts which have brought us back again to the same principle; so that, in resuming the discussion, we shall not be enquiring about an empty theory, but about events which actually happened.</div><div class="sentence"> The case was as follows: —Three royal heroes made oath to three cities which were under a kingly government, and the cities to the kings, that both rulers and subjects should govern and be governed according to the laws which were common to all of them:  the rulers promised that as time and the race went forward they would not make their rule more arbitrary; and the subjects said that, if the rulers observed these conditions, they would never subvert or permit others to subvert those kingdoms; the kings were to assist kings and peoples when injured, and the peoples were to assist peoples and kings in like manner.</div><div class="sentence"> Is not this the fact?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">115</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">116</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And the three states to whom these laws were given, whether their kings or any others were the authors of them, had therefore the greatest security for the maintenance of their constitutions?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">117</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  What security?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">118</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  That the other two states were always to come to the rescue against a rebellious third.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">119</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">120</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Many persons say that legislators ought to impose such laws as the mass of the people will be ready to receive; but this is just as if one were to command gymnastic masters or physicians to treat or cure their pupils or patients in an agreeable manner.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">121</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Exactly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">122</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Whereas the physician may often be too happy if he can restore health, and make the body whole, without any very great infliction of pain.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">123</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">124</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There was also another advantage possessed by the men of that day, which greatly lightened the task of passing laws.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">125</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  What advantage?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">126</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The legislators of that day, when they equalized property, escaped the great accusation which generally arises in legislation, if a person attempts to disturb the possession of land, or to abolish debts, because he sees that without this reform there can never be any real equality.</div><div class="sentence"> Now, in general, when the legislator attempts to make a new settlement of such matters, every one meets him with the cry, that 'he is not to disturb vested interests,'—declaring with imprecations that he is introducing agrarian laws and cancelling of debts, until a man is at his wits' end; whereas no one could quarrel with the Dorians for distributing the land,—there was nothing to hinder them; and as for debts, they had none which were considerable or of old standing.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">127</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">128</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But then, my good friends, why did the settlement and legislation of their country turn out so badly?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">129</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  How do you mean; and why do you blame them?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">130</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There were three kingdoms, and of these, two quickly corrupted their original constitution and laws, and the only one which remained was the Spartan.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">131</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  The question which you ask is not easily answered.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">132</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And yet must be answered when we are enquiring about laws, this being our old man's sober game of play, whereby we beguile the way, as I was saying when we first set out on our journey.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">133</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly; and we must find out why this was.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">134</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  What laws are more worthy of our attention than those which have regulated such cities?</div><div class="sentence"> or what settlements of states are greater or more famous?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">135</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  I know of none.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">136</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Can we doubt that your ancestors intended these institutions not only for the protection of Peloponnesus, but of all the Hellenes, in case they were attacked by the barbarian?</div><div class="sentence"> For the inhabitants of the region about Ilium, when they provoked by their insolence the Trojan war, relied upon the power of the Assyrians and the Empire of Ninus, which still existed and had a great prestige; the people of those days fearing the united Assyrian Empire just as we now fear the Great King.</div><div class="sentence"> And the second capture of Troy was a serious offence against them, because Troy was a portion of the Assyrian Empire.</div><div class="sentence"> To meet the danger the single army was distributed between three cities by the royal brothers, sons of Heracles,—a fair device, as it seemed, and a far better arrangement than the expedition against Troy.</div><div class="sentence"> For, firstly, the people of that day had, as they thought, in the Heraclidae better leaders than the Pelopidae; in the next place, they considered that their army was superior in valour to that which went against Troy; for, although the latter conquered the Trojans, they were themselves conquered by the Heraclidae—Achaeans by Dorians.</div><div class="sentence"> May we not suppose that this was the intention with which the men of those days framed the constitutions of their states?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">137</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Quite true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">138</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And would not men who had shared with one another many dangers, and were governed by a single race of royal brothers, and had taken the advice of oracles, and in particular of the Delphian Apollo, be likely to think that such states would be firmly and lastingly established?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">139</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Of course they would.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">140</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yet these institutions, of which such great expectations were entertained, seem to have all rapidly vanished away; with the exception, as I was saying, of that small part of them which existed in your land.</div><div class="sentence"> And this third part has never to this day ceased warring against the two others; whereas, if the original idea had been carried out, and they had agreed to be one, their power would have been invincible in war.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">141</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  No doubt.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">142</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But what was the ruin of this glorious confederacy?</div><div class="sentence"> Here is a subject well worthy of consideration.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">143</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly, no one will ever find more striking instances of laws or governments being the salvation or destruction of great and noble interests, than are here presented to his view.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">144</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then now we seem to have happily arrived at a real and important question.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">145</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">146</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Did you never remark, sage friend, that all men, and we ourselves at this moment, often fancy that they see some beautiful thing which might have effected wonders if any one had only known how to make a right use of it in some way; and yet this mode of looking at things may turn out after all to be a mistake, and not according to nature, either in our own case or in any other?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">147</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  To what are you referring, and what do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">148</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I was thinking of my own admiration of the aforesaid Heracleid expedition, which was so noble, and might have had such wonderful results for the Hellenes, if only rightly used; and I was just laughing at myself.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">149</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  But were you not right and wise in speaking as you did, and we in assenting to you?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">150</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Perhaps; and yet I cannot help observing that any one who sees anything great or powerful, immediately has the feeling that—'If the owner only knew how to use his great and noble possession, how happy would he be, and what great results would he achieve!'</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">151</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  And would he not be justified?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">152</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Reflect; in what point of view does this sort of praise appear just:  First, in reference to the question in hand: —If the then commanders had known how to arrange their army properly, how would they have attained success?</div><div class="sentence"> Would not this have been the way?</div><div class="sentence"> They would have bound them all firmly together and preserved them for ever, giving them freedom and dominion at pleasure, combined with the power of doing in the whole world, Hellenic and barbarian, whatever they and their descendants desired.</div><div class="sentence"> What other aim would they have had?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">153</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Very good.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">154</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Suppose any one were in the same way to express his admiration at the sight of great wealth or family honour, or the like, he would praise them under the idea that through them he would attain either all or the greater and chief part of what he desires.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">155</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  He would.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">156</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, now, and does not the argument show that there is one common desire of all mankind?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">157</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  What is it?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">158</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The desire which a man has, that all things, if possible,—at any rate, things human,—may come to pass in accordance with his soul's desire.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">159</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">160</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And having this desire always, and at every time of life, in youth, in manhood, in age, he cannot help always praying for the fulfilment of it.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">161</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  No doubt.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">162</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And we join in the prayers of our friends, and ask for them what they ask for themselves.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">163</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  We do.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">164</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Dear is the son to the father—the younger to the elder.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">165</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Of course.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">166</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And yet the son often prays to obtain things which the father prays that he may not obtain.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">167</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  When the son is young and foolish, you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">168</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes; or when the father, in the dotage of age or the heat of youth, having no sense of right and justice, prays with fervour, under the influence of feelings akin to those of Theseus when he cursed the unfortunate Hippolytus, do you imagine that the son, having a sense of right and justice, will join in his father's prayers?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">169</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  I understand you to mean that a man should not desire or be in a hurry to have all things according to his wish, for his wish may be at variance with his reason.</div><div class="sentence"> But every state and every individual ought to pray and strive for wisdom.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">170</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes; and I remember, and you will remember, what I said at first, that a statesman and legislator ought to ordain laws with a view to wisdom; while you were arguing that the good lawgiver ought to order all with a view to war.</div><div class="sentence"> And to this I replied that there were four virtues, but that upon your view one of them only was the aim of legislation; whereas you ought to regard all virtue, and especially that which comes first, and is the leader of all the rest—I mean wisdom and mind and opinion, having affection and desire in their train.</div><div class="sentence"> And now the argument returns to the same point, and I say once more, in jest if you like, or in earnest if you like, that the prayer of a fool is full of danger, being likely to end in the opposite of what he desires.</div><div class="sentence"> And if you would rather receive my words in earnest, I am willing that you should; and you will find, I suspect, as I have said already, that not cowardice was the cause of the ruin of the Dorian kings and of their whole design, nor ignorance of military matters, either on the part of the rulers or of their subjects; but their misfortunes were due to their general degeneracy, and especially to their ignorance of the most important human affairs.</div><div class="sentence"> That was then, and is still, and always will be the case, as I will endeavour, if you will allow me, to make out and demonstrate as well as I am able to you who are my friends, in the course of the argument.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">171</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Pray go on, Stranger;—compliments are troublesome, but we will show, not in word but in deed, how greatly we prize your words, for we will give them our best attention; and that is the way in which a freeman best shows his approval or disapproval.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">172</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Excellent, Cleinias; let us do as you say.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">173</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  By all means, if Heaven wills.</div><div class="sentence"> Go on.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">174</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, then, proceeding in the same train of thought, I say that the greatest ignorance was the ruin of the Dorian power, and that now, as then, ignorance is ruin.</div><div class="sentence"> And if this be true, the legislator must endeavour to implant wisdom in states, and banish ignorance to the utmost of his power.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">175</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That is evident.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">176</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then now consider what is really the greatest ignorance.</div><div class="sentence"> I should like to know whether you and Megillus would agree with me in what I am about to say; for my opinion is—</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">177</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">178</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  That the greatest ignorance is when a man hates that which he nevertheless thinks to be good and noble, and loves and embraces that which he knows to be unrighteous and evil.</div><div class="sentence"> This disagreement between the sense of pleasure and the judgment of reason in the soul is, in my opinion, the worst ignorance; and also the greatest, because affecting the great mass of the human soul; for the principle which feels pleasure and pain in the individual is like the mass or populace in a state.</div><div class="sentence"> And when the soul is opposed to knowledge, or opinion, or reason, which are her natural lords, that I call folly, just as in the state, when the multitude refuses to obey their rulers and the laws; or, again, in the individual, when fair reasonings have their habitation in the soul and yet do no good, but rather the reverse of good.</div><div class="sentence"> All these cases I term the worst ignorance, whether in individuals or in states.</div><div class="sentence"> You will understand, Stranger, that I am speaking of something which is very different from the ignorance of handicraftsmen.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">179</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, my friend, we understand and agree.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">180</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us, then, in the first place declare and affirm that the citizen who does not know these things ought never to have any kind of authority entrusted to him:  he must be stigmatized as ignorant, even though he be versed in calculation and skilled in all sorts of accomplishments, and feats of mental dexterity; and the opposite are to be called wise, even although, in the words of the proverb, they know neither how to read nor how to swim; and to them, as to men of sense, authority is to be committed.</div><div class="sentence"> For, O my friends, how can there be the least shadow of wisdom when there is no harmony?</div><div class="sentence"> There is none; but the noblest and greatest of harmonies may be truly said to be the greatest wisdom; and of this he is a partaker who lives according to reason; whereas he who is devoid of reason is the destroyer of his house and the very opposite of a saviour of the state:  he is utterly ignorant of political wisdom.</div><div class="sentence"> Let this, then, as I was saying, be laid down by us.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">181</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Let it be so laid down.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">182</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I suppose that there must be rulers and subjects in states?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">183</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">184</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And what are the principles on which men rule and obey in cities, whether great or small; and similarly in families?</div><div class="sentence"> What are they, and how many in number?</div><div class="sentence"> Is there not one claim of authority which is always just,—that of fathers and mothers and in general of progenitors to rule over their offspring?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">185</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  There is.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">186</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Next follows the principle that the noble should rule over the ignoble; and, thirdly, that the elder should rule and the younger obey?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">187</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To be sure.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">188</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And, fourthly, that slaves should be ruled, and their masters rule?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">189</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Of course.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">190</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Fifthly, if I am not mistaken, comes the principle that the stronger shall rule, and the weaker be ruled?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">191</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That is a rule not to be disobeyed.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">192</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, and a rule which prevails very widely among all creatures, and is according to nature, as the Theban poet Pindar once said; and the sixth principle, and the greatest of all, is, that the wise should lead and command, and the ignorant follow and obey; and yet, O thou most wise Pindar, as I should reply him, this surely is not contrary to nature, but according to nature, being the rule of law over willing subjects, and not a rule of compulsion.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">193</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Most true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">194</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There is a seventh kind of rule which is awarded by lot, and is dear to the Gods and a token of good fortune:  he on whom the lot falls is a ruler, and he who fails in obtaining the lot goes away and is the subject; and this we affirm to be quite just.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">195</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">196</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  'Then now,' as we say playfully to any of those who lightly undertake the making of laws, 'you see, legislator, the principles of government, how many they are, and that they are naturally opposed to each other.</div><div class="sentence"> There we have discovered a fountain-head of seditions, to which you must attend.</div><div class="sentence"> And, first, we will ask you to consider with us, how and in what respect the kings of Argos and Messene violated these our maxims, and ruined themselves and the great and famous Hellenic power of the olden time.</div><div class="sentence"> Was it because they did not know how wisely Hesiod spoke when he said that the half is often more than the whole?</div><div class="sentence"> His meaning was, that when to take the whole would be dangerous, and to take the half would be the safe and moderate course, then the moderate or better was more than the immoderate or worse.'</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">197</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">198</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And may we suppose this immoderate spirit to be more fatal when found among kings than when among peoples?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">199</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  The probability is that ignorance will be a disorder especially prevalent among kings, because they lead a proud and luxurious life.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">200</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Is it not palpable that the chief aim of the kings of that time was to get the better of the established laws, and that they were not in harmony with the principles which they had agreed to observe by word and oath?</div><div class="sentence"> This want of harmony may have had the appearance of wisdom, but was really, as we assert, the greatest ignorance, and utterly overthrew the whole empire by dissonance and harsh discord.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">201</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very likely.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">202</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Good; and what measures ought the legislator to have then taken in order to avert this calamity?</div><div class="sentence"> Truly there is no great wisdom in knowing, and no great difficulty in telling, after the evil has happened; but to have foreseen the remedy at the time would have taken a much wiser head than ours.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">203</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">204</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Any one who looks at what has occurred with you Lacedaemonians, Megillus, may easily know and may easily say what ought to have been done at that time.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">205</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Speak a little more clearly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">206</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Nothing can be clearer than the observation which I am about to make.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">207</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  What is it?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">208</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  That if any one gives too great a power to anything, too large a sail to a vessel, too much food to the body, too much authority to the mind, and does not observe the mean, everything is overthrown, and, in the wantonness of excess, runs in the one case to disorders, and in the other to injustice, which is the child of excess.</div><div class="sentence"> I mean to say, my dear friends, that there is no soul of man, young and irresponsible, who will be able to sustain the temptation of arbitrary power—no one who will not, under such circumstances, become filled with folly, that worst of diseases, and be hated by his nearest and dearest friends:  when this happens his kingdom is undermined, and all his power vanishes from him.</div><div class="sentence"> And great legislators who know the mean should take heed of the danger.</div><div class="sentence"> As far as we can guess at this distance of time, what happened was as follows: —</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">209</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  What?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">210</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  A God, who watched over Sparta, seeing into the future, gave you two families of kings instead of one; and thus brought you more within the limits of moderation.</div><div class="sentence"> In the next place, some human wisdom mingled with divine power, observing that the constitution of your government was still feverish and excited, tempered your inborn strength and pride of birth with the moderation which comes of age, making the power of your twenty-eight elders equal with that of the kings in the most important matters.</div><div class="sentence"> But your third saviour, perceiving that your government was still swelling and foaming, and desirous to impose a curb upon it, instituted the Ephors, whose power he made to resemble that of magistrates elected by lot; and by this arrangement the kingly office, being compounded of the right elements and duly moderated, was preserved, and was the means of preserving all the rest.</div><div class="sentence"> Since, if there had been only the original legislators, Temenus, Cresphontes, and their contemporaries, as far as they were concerned not even the portion of Aristodemus would have been preserved; for they had no proper experience in legislation, or they would surely not have imagined that oaths would moderate a youthful spirit invested with a power which might be converted into a tyranny.</div><div class="sentence"> Now that God has instructed us what sort of government would have been or will be lasting, there is no wisdom, as I have already said, in judging after the event; there is no difficulty in learning from an example which has already occurred.</div><div class="sentence"> But if any one could have foreseen all this at the time, and had been able to moderate the government of the three kingdoms and unite them into one, he might have saved all the excellent institutions which were then conceived; and no Persian or any other armament would have dared to attack us, or would have regarded Hellas as a power to be despised.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">211</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
