<div class="speech"><span class="ref">212</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There was small credit to us, Cleinias, in defeating them; and the discredit was, not that the conquerors did not win glorious victories both by land and sea, but what, in my opinion, brought discredit was, first of all, the circumstance that of the three cities one only fought on behalf of Hellas, and the two others were so utterly good for nothing that the one was waging a mighty war against Lacedaemon, and was thus preventing her from rendering assistance, while the city of Argos, which had the precedence at the time of the distribution, when asked to aid in repelling the barbarian, would not answer to the call, or give aid.</div><div class="sentence"> Many things might be told about Hellas in connexion with that war which are far from honourable; nor, indeed, can we rightly say that Hellas repelled the invader; for the truth is, that unless the Athenians and Lacedaemonians, acting in concert, had warded off the impending yoke, all the tribes of Hellas would have been fused in a chaos of Hellenes mingling with one another, of barbarians mingling with Hellenes, and Hellenes with barbarians; just as nations who are now subject to the Persian power, owing to unnatural separations and combinations of them, are dispersed and scattered, and live miserably.</div><div class="sentence"> These, Cleinias and Megillus, are the reproaches which we have to make against statesmen and legislators, as they are called, past and present, if we would analyse the causes of their failure, and find out what else might have been done.</div><div class="sentence"> We said, for instance, just now, that there ought to be no great and unmixed powers; and this was under the idea that a state ought to be free and wise and harmonious, and that a legislator ought to legislate with a view to this end.</div><div class="sentence"> Nor is there any reason to be surprised at our continually proposing aims for the legislator which appear not to be always the same; but we should consider when we say that temperance is to be the aim, or wisdom is to be the aim, or friendship is to be the aim, that all these aims are really the same; and if so, a variety in the modes of expression ought not to disturb us.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">213</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Let us resume the argument in that spirit.</div><div class="sentence"> And now, speaking of friendship and wisdom and freedom, I wish that you would tell me at what, in your opinion, the legislator should aim.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">214</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Hear me, then:  there are two mother forms of states from which the rest may be truly said to be derived; and one of them may be called monarchy and the other democracy:  the Persians have the highest form of the one, and we of the other; almost all the rest, as I was saying, are variations of these.</div><div class="sentence"> Now, if you are to have liberty and the combination of friendship with wisdom, you must have both these forms of government in a measure; the argument emphatically declares that no city can be well governed which is not made up of both.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">215</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Impossible.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">216</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Neither the one, if it be exclusively and excessively attached to monarchy, nor the other, if it be similarly attached to freedom, observes moderation; but your states, the Laconian and Cretan, have more of it; and the same was the case with the Athenians and Persians of old time, but now they have less.</div><div class="sentence"> Shall I tell you why?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">217</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  By all means, if it will tend to elucidate our subject.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">218</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Hear, then: —There was a time when the Persians had more of the state which is a mean between slavery and freedom.</div><div class="sentence"> In the reign of Cyrus they were freemen and also lords of many others:  the rulers gave a share of freedom to the subjects, and being treated as equals, the soldiers were on better terms with their generals, and showed themselves more ready in the hour of danger.</div><div class="sentence"> And if there was any wise man among them, who was able to give good counsel, he imparted his wisdom to the public; for the king was not jealous, but allowed him full liberty of speech, and gave honour to those who could advise him in any matter.</div><div class="sentence"> And the nation waxed in all respects, because there was freedom and friendship and communion of mind among them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">219</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That certainly appears to have been the case.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">220</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  How, then, was this advantage lost under Cambyses, and again recovered under Darius?</div><div class="sentence"> Shall I try to divine?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">221</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  The enquiry, no doubt, has a bearing upon our subject.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">222</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I imagine that Cyrus, though a great and patriotic general, had never given his mind to education, and never attended to the order of his household.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">223</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What makes you say so?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">224</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I think that from his youth upwards he was a soldier, and entrusted the education of his children to the women; and they brought them up from their childhood as the favourites of fortune, who were blessed already, and needed no more blessings.</div><div class="sentence"> They thought that they were happy enough, and that no one should be allowed to oppose them in any way, and they compelled every one to praise all that they said or did.</div><div class="sentence"> This was how they brought them up.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">225</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  A splendid education truly!</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">226</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Such an one as women were likely to give them, and especially princesses who had recently grown rich, and in the absence of the men, too, who were occupied in wars and dangers, and had no time to look after them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">227</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What would you expect?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">228</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Their father had possessions of cattle and sheep, and many herds of men and other animals, but he did not consider that those to whom he was about to make them over were not trained in his own calling, which was Persian; for the Persians are shepherds—sons of a rugged land, which is a stern mother, and well fitted to produce a sturdy race able to live in the open air and go without sleep, and also to fight, if fighting is required (compare Arist.</div><div class="sentence"> Pol.).</div><div class="sentence"> He did not observe that his sons were trained differently; through the so-called blessing of being royal they were educated in the Median fashion by women and eunuchs, which led to their becoming such as people do become when they are brought up unreproved.</div><div class="sentence"> And so, after the death of Cyrus, his sons, in the fulness of luxury and licence, took the kingdom, and first one slew the other because he could not endure a rival; and, afterwards, the slayer himself, mad with wine and brutality, lost his kingdom through the Medes and the Eunuch, as they called him, who despised the folly of Cambyses.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">229</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  So runs the tale, and such probably were the facts.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">230</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes; and the tradition says, that the empire came back to the Persians, through Darius and the seven chiefs.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">231</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">232</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us note the rest of the story.</div><div class="sentence"> Observe, that Darius was not the son of a king, and had not received a luxurious education.</div><div class="sentence"> When he came to the throne, being one of the seven, he divided the country into seven portions, and of this arrangement there are some shadowy traces still remaining; he made laws upon the principle of introducing universal equality in the order of the state, and he embodied in his laws the settlement of the tribute which Cyrus promised,—thus creating a feeling of friendship and community among all the Persians, and attaching the people to him with money and gifts.</div><div class="sentence"> Hence his armies cheerfully acquired for him countries as large as those which Cyrus had left behind him.</div><div class="sentence"> Darius was succeeded by his son Xerxes; and he again was brought up in the royal and luxurious fashion.</div><div class="sentence"> Might we not most justly say:  'O Darius, how came you to bring up Xerxes in the same way in which Cyrus brought up Cambyses, and not to see his fatal mistake?'</div><div class="sentence"> For Xerxes, being the creation of the same education, met with much the same fortune as Cambyses; and from that time until now there has never been a really great king among the Persians, although they are all called Great.</div><div class="sentence"> And their degeneracy is not to be attributed to chance, as I maintain; the reason is rather the evil life which is generally led by the sons of very rich and royal persons; for never will boy or man, young or old, excel in virtue, who has been thus educated.</div><div class="sentence"> And this, I say, is what the legislator has to consider, and what at the present moment has to be considered by us.</div><div class="sentence"> Justly may you, O Lacedaemonians, be praised, in that you do not give special honour or a special education to wealth rather than to poverty, or to a royal rather than to a private station, where the divine and inspired lawgiver has not originally commanded them to be given.</div><div class="sentence"> For no man ought to have pre-eminent honour in a state because he surpasses others in wealth, any more than because he is swift of foot or fair or strong, unless he have some virtue in him; nor even if he have virtue, unless he have this particular virtue of temperance.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">233</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you mean, Stranger?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">234</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I suppose that courage is a part of virtue?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">235</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  To be sure.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">236</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then, now hear and judge for yourself: —Would you like to have for a fellow-lodger or neighbour a very courageous man, who had no control over himself?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">237</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Heaven forbid!</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">238</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Or an artist, who was clever in his profession, but a rogue?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">239</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly not.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">240</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And surely justice does not grow apart from temperance?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">241</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Impossible.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">242</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Any more than our pattern wise man, whom we exhibited as having his pleasures and pains in accordance with and corresponding to true reason, can be intemperate?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">243</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  No.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">244</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There is a further consideration relating to the due and undue award of honours in states.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">245</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  What is it?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">246</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I should like to know whether temperance without the other virtues, existing alone in the soul of man, is rightly to be praised or blamed?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">247</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  I cannot tell.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">248</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And that is the best answer; for whichever alternative you had chosen, I think that you would have gone wrong.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">249</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  I am fortunate.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">250</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Very good; a quality, which is a mere appendage of things which can be praised or blamed, does not deserve an expression of opinion, but is best passed over in silence.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">251</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  You are speaking of temperance?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">252</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes; but of the other virtues, that which having this appendage is also most beneficial, will be most deserving of honour, and next that which is beneficial in the next degree; and so each of them will be rightly honoured according to a regular order.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">253</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">254</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And ought not the legislator to determine these classes?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">255</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly he should.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">256</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Suppose that we leave to him the arrangement of details.</div><div class="sentence"> But the general division of laws according to their importance into a first and second and third class, we who are lovers of law may make ourselves.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">257</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Very good.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">258</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  We maintain, then, that a State which would be safe and happy, as far as the nature of man allows, must and ought to distribute honour and dishonour in the right way.</div><div class="sentence"> And the right way is to place the goods of the soul first and highest in the scale, always assuming temperance to be the condition of them; and to assign the second place to the goods of the body; and the third place to money and property.</div><div class="sentence"> And if any legislator or state departs from this rule by giving money the place of honour, or in any way preferring that which is really last, may we not say, that he or the state is doing an unholy and unpatriotic thing?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">259</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes; let that be plainly declared.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">260</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The consideration of the Persian governments led us thus far to enlarge.</div><div class="sentence"> We remarked that the Persians grew worse and worse.</div><div class="sentence"> And we affirm the reason of this to have been, that they too much diminished the freedom of the people, and introduced too much of despotism, and so destroyed friendship and community of feeling.</div><div class="sentence"> And when there is an end of these, no longer do the governors govern on behalf of their subjects or of the people, but on behalf of themselves; and if they think that they can gain ever so small an advantage for themselves, they devastate cities, and send fire and desolation among friendly races.</div><div class="sentence"> And as they hate ruthlessly and horribly, so are they hated; and when they want the people to fight for them, they find no community of feeling or willingness to risk their lives on their behalf; their untold myriads are useless to them on the field of battle, and they think that their salvation depends on the employment of mercenaries and strangers whom they hire, as if they were in want of more men.</div><div class="sentence"> And they cannot help being stupid, since they proclaim by their actions that the ordinary distinctions of right and wrong which are made in a state are a trifle, when compared with gold and silver.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">261</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Quite true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">262</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And now enough of the Persians, and their present mal-administration of their government, which is owing to the excess of slavery and despotism among them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">263</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Good.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">264</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Next, we must pass in review the government of Attica in like manner, and from this show that entire freedom and the absence of all superior authority is not by any means so good as government by others when properly limited, which was our ancient Athenian constitution at the time when the Persians made their attack on Hellas, or, speaking more correctly, on the whole continent of Europe.</div><div class="sentence"> There were four classes, arranged according to a property census, and reverence was our queen and mistress, and made us willing to live in obedience to the laws which then prevailed.</div><div class="sentence"> Also the vastness of the Persian armament, both by sea and on land, caused a helpless terror, which made us more and more the servants of our rulers and of the laws; and for all these reasons an exceeding harmony prevailed among us.</div><div class="sentence"> About ten years before the naval engagement at Salamis, Datis came, leading a Persian host by command of Darius, which was expressly directed against the Athenians and Eretrians, having orders to carry them away captive; and these orders he was to execute under pain of death.</div><div class="sentence"> Now Datis and his myriads soon became complete masters of Eretria, and he sent a fearful report to Athens that no Eretrian had escaped him; for the soldiers of Datis had joined hands and netted the whole of Eretria.</div><div class="sentence"> And this report, whether well or ill founded, was terrible to all the Hellenes, and above all to the Athenians, and they dispatched embassies in all directions, but no one was willing to come to their relief, with the exception of the Lacedaemonians; and they, either because they were detained by the Messenian war, which was then going on, or for some other reason of which we are not told, came a day too late for the battle of Marathon.</div><div class="sentence"> After a while, the news arrived of mighty preparations being made, and innumerable threats came from the king.</div><div class="sentence"> Then, as time went on, a rumour reached us that Darius had died, and that his son, who was young and hot-headed, had come to the throne and was persisting in his design.</div><div class="sentence"> The Athenians were under the impression that the whole expedition was directed against them, in consequence of the battle of Marathon; and hearing of the bridge over the Hellespont, and the canal of Athos, and the host of ships, considering that there was no salvation for them either by land or by sea, for there was no one to help them, and remembering that in the first expedition, when the Persians destroyed Eretria, no one came to their help, or would risk the danger of an alliance with them, they thought that this would happen again, at least on land; nor, when they looked to the sea, could they descry any hope of salvation; for they were attacked by a thousand vessels and more.</div><div class="sentence"> One chance of safety remained, slight indeed and desperate, but their only one.</div><div class="sentence"> They saw that on the former occasion they had gained a seemingly impossible victory, and borne up by this hope, they found that their only refuge was in themselves and in the Gods.</div><div class="sentence"> All these things created in them the spirit of friendship; there was the fear of the moment, and there was that higher fear, which they had acquired by obedience to their ancient laws, and which I have several times in the preceding discourse called reverence, of which the good man ought to be a willing servant, and of which the coward is independent and fearless.</div><div class="sentence"> If this fear had not possessed them, they would never have met the enemy, or defended their temples and sepulchres and their country, and everything that was near and dear to them, as they did; but little by little they would have been all scattered and dispersed.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">265</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Your words, Athenian, are quite true, and worthy of yourself and of your country.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">266</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  They are true, Megillus; and to you, who have inherited the virtues of your ancestors, I may properly speak of the actions of that day.</div><div class="sentence"> And I would wish you and Cleinias to consider whether my words have not also a bearing on legislation; for I am not discoursing only for the pleasure of talking, but for the argument's sake.</div><div class="sentence"> Please to remark that the experience both of ourselves and the Persians was, in a certain sense, the same; for as they led their people into utter servitude, so we too led ours into all freedom.</div><div class="sentence"> And now, how shall we proceed?</div><div class="sentence"> for I would like you to observe that our previous arguments have good deal to say for themselves.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">267</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  True; but I wish that you would give us a fuller explanation.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">268</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I will.</div><div class="sentence"> Under the ancient laws, my friends, the people was not as now the master, but rather the willing servant of the laws.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">269</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  What laws do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">270</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In the first place, let us speak of the laws about music,—that is to say, such music as then existed—in order that we may trace the growth of the excess of freedom from the beginning.</div><div class="sentence"> Now music was early divided among us into certain kinds and manners.</div><div class="sentence"> One sort consisted of prayers to the Gods, which were called hymns; and there was another and opposite sort called lamentations, and another termed paeans, and another, celebrating the birth of Dionysus, called, I believe, 'dithyrambs.'</div><div class="sentence"> And they used the actual word 'laws,' or nomoi, for another kind of song; and to this they added the term 'citharoedic.'</div><div class="sentence"> All these and others were duly distinguished, nor were the performers allowed to confuse one style of music with another.</div><div class="sentence"> And the authority which determined and gave judgment, and punished the disobedient, was not expressed in a hiss, nor in the most unmusical shouts of the multitude, as in our days, nor in applause and clapping of hands.</div><div class="sentence"> But the directors of public instruction insisted that the spectators should listen in silence to the end; and boys and their tutors, and the multitude in general, were kept quiet by a hint from a stick.</div><div class="sentence"> Such was the good order which the multitude were willing to observe; they would never have dared to give judgment by noisy cries.</div><div class="sentence"> And then, as time went on, the poets themselves introduced the reign of vulgar and lawless innovation.</div><div class="sentence"> They were men of genius, but they had no perception of what is just and lawful in music; raging like Bacchanals and possessed with inordinate delights—mingling lamentations with hymns, and paeans with dithyrambs; imitating the sounds of the flute on the lyre, and making one general confusion; ignorantly affirming that music has no truth, and, whether good or bad, can only be judged of rightly by the pleasure of the hearer (compare Republic).</div><div class="sentence"> And by composing such licentious works, and adding to them words as licentious, they have inspired the multitude with lawlessness and boldness, and made them fancy that they can judge for themselves about melody and song.</div><div class="sentence"> And in this way the theatres from being mute have become vocal, as though they had understanding of good and bad in music and poetry; and instead of an aristocracy, an evil sort of theatrocracy has grown up (compare Arist.</div><div class="sentence"> Pol.).</div><div class="sentence"> For if the democracy which judged had only consisted of educated persons, no fatal harm would have been done; but in music there first arose the universal conceit of omniscience and general lawlessness;—freedom came following afterwards, and men, fancying that they knew what they did not know, had no longer any fear, and the absence of fear begets shamelessness.</div><div class="sentence"> For what is this shamelessness, which is so evil a thing, but the insolent refusal to regard the opinion of the better by reason of an over-daring sort of liberty?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">271</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">272</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Consequent upon this freedom comes the other freedom, of disobedience to rulers (compare Republic); and then the attempt to escape the control and exhortation of father, mother, elders, and when near the end, the control of the laws also; and at the very end there is the contempt of oaths and pledges, and no regard at all for the Gods,—herein they exhibit and imitate the old so-called Titanic nature, and come to the same point as the Titans when they rebelled against God, leading a life of endless evils.</div><div class="sentence"> But why have I said all this?</div><div class="sentence"> I ask, because the argument ought to be pulled up from time to time, and not be allowed to run away, but held with bit and bridle, and then we shall not, as the proverb says, fall off our ass.</div><div class="sentence"> Let us then once more ask the question, To what end has all this been said?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">273</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Very good.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">274</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  This, then, has been said for the sake—</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">275</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Of what?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">276</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  We were maintaining that the lawgiver ought to have three things in view:  first, that the city for which he legislates should be free; and secondly, be at unity with herself; and thirdly, should have understanding;—these were our principles, were they not?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">277</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">278</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  With a view to this we selected two kinds of government, the one the most despotic, and the other the most free; and now we are considering which of them is the right form:  we took a mean in both cases, of despotism in the one, and of liberty in the other, and we saw that in a mean they attained their perfection; but that when they were carried to the extreme of either, slavery or licence, neither party were the gainers.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">279</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">280</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And that was our reason for considering the settlement of the Dorian army, and of the city built by Dardanus at the foot of the mountains, and the removal of cities to the seashore, and of our mention of the first men, who were the survivors of the deluge.</div><div class="sentence"> And all that was previously said about music and drinking, and what preceded, was said with the view of seeing how a state might be best administered, and how an individual might best order his own life.</div><div class="sentence"> And now, Megillus and Cleinias, how can we put to the proof the value of our words?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">281</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Stranger, I think that I see how a proof of their value may be obtained.</div><div class="sentence"> This discussion of ours appears to me to have been singularly fortunate, and just what I at this moment want; most auspiciously have you and my friend Megillus come in my way.</div><div class="sentence"> For I will tell you what has happened to me; and I regard the coincidence as a sort of omen.</div><div class="sentence"> The greater part of Crete is going to send out a colony, and they have entrusted the management of the affair to the Cnosians; and the Cnosian government to me and nine others.</div><div class="sentence"> And they desire us to give them any laws which we please, whether taken from the Cretan model or from any other; and they do not mind about their being foreign if they are better.</div><div class="sentence"> Grant me then this favour, which will also be a gain to yourselves: —Let us make a selection from what has been said, and then let us imagine a State of which we will suppose ourselves to be the original founders.</div><div class="sentence"> Thus we shall proceed with our enquiry, and, at the same time, I may have the use of the framework which you are constructing, for the city which is in contemplation.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">282</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Good news, Cleinias; if Megillus has no objection, you may be sure that I will do all in my power to please you.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">283</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Thank you.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">284</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  And so will I.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">285</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Excellent; and now let us begin to frame the State.</div></div>

</div><div id="link2H_4_0007" class="book_section">
<h2>BOOK IV.</h2>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">001</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And now, what will this city be?</div><div class="sentence"> I do not mean to ask what is or will hereafter be the name of the place; that may be determined by the accident of locality or of the original settlement—a river or fountain, or some local deity may give the sanction of a name to the newly-founded city; but I do want to know what the situation is, whether maritime or inland.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">002</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I should imagine, Stranger, that the city of which we are speaking is about eighty stadia distant from the sea.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">003</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And are there harbours on the seaboard?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">004</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Excellent harbours, Stranger; there could not be better.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">005</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Alas!</div><div class="sentence"> what a prospect!</div><div class="sentence"> And is the surrounding country productive, or in need of importations?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">006</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Hardly in need of anything.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">007</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And is there any neighbouring State?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">008</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  None whatever, and that is the reason for selecting the place; in days of old, there was a migration of the inhabitants, and the region has been deserted from time immemorial.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">009</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And has the place a fair proportion of hill, and plain, and wood?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">010</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Like the rest of Crete in that.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">011</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  You mean to say that there is more rock than plain?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">012</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Exactly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">013</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then there is some hope that your citizens may be virtuous:  had you been on the sea, and well provided with harbours, and an importing rather than a producing country, some mighty saviour would have been needed, and lawgivers more than mortal, if you were ever to have a chance of preserving your state from degeneracy and discordance of manners (compare Ar.</div><div class="sentence"> Pol.).</div><div class="sentence"> But there is comfort in the eighty stadia; although the sea is too near, especially if, as you say, the harbours are so good.</div><div class="sentence"> Still we may be content.</div><div class="sentence"> The sea is pleasant enough as a daily companion, but has indeed also a bitter and brackish quality; filling the streets with merchants and shopkeepers, and begetting in the souls of men uncertain and unfaithful ways—making the state unfriendly and unfaithful both to her own citizens, and also to other nations.</div><div class="sentence"> There is a consolation, therefore, in the country producing all things at home; and yet, owing to the ruggedness of the soil, not providing anything in great abundance.</div><div class="sentence"> Had there been abundance, there might have been a great export trade, and a great return of gold and silver; which, as we may safely affirm, has the most fatal results on a State whose aim is the attainment of just and noble sentiments:  this was said by us, if you remember, in the previous discussion.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">014</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I remember, and am of opinion that we both were and are in the right.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">015</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, but let me ask, how is the country supplied with timber for ship-building?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">016</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  There is no fir of any consequence, nor pine, and not much cypress; and you will find very little stone-pine or plane-wood, which shipwrights always require for the interior of ships.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">017</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  These are also natural advantages.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">018</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Why so?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">019</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Because no city ought to be easily able to imitate its enemies in what is mischievous.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">020</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How does that bear upon any of the matters of which we have been speaking?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">021</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Remember, my good friend, what I said at first about the Cretan laws, that they looked to one thing only, and this, as you both agreed, was war; and I replied that such laws, in so far as they tended to promote virtue, were good; but in that they regarded a part only, and not the whole of virtue, I disapproved of them.</div><div class="sentence"> And now I hope that you in your turn will follow and watch me if I legislate with a view to anything but virtue, or with a view to a part of virtue only.</div><div class="sentence"> For I consider that the true lawgiver, like an archer, aims only at that on which some eternal beauty is always attending, and dismisses everything else, whether wealth or any other benefit, when separated from virtue.</div><div class="sentence"> I was saying that the imitation of enemies was a bad thing; and I was thinking of a case in which a maritime people are harassed by enemies, as the Athenians were by Minos (I do not speak from any desire to recall past grievances); but he, as we know, was a great naval potentate, who compelled the inhabitants of Attica to pay him a cruel tribute; and in those days they had no ships of war as they now have, nor was the country filled with ship-timber, and therefore they could not readily build them.</div><div class="sentence"> Hence they could not learn how to imitate their enemy at sea, and in this way, becoming sailors themselves, directly repel their enemies.</div><div class="sentence"> Better for them to have lost many times over the seven youths, than that heavy-armed and stationary troops should have been turned into sailors, and accustomed to be often leaping on shore, and again to come running back to their ships; or should have fancied that there was no disgrace in not awaiting the attack of an enemy and dying boldly; and that there were good reasons, and plenty of them, for a man throwing away his arms, and betaking himself to flight,—which is not dishonourable, as people say, at certain times.</div><div class="sentence"> This is the language of naval warfare, and is anything but worthy of extraordinary praise.</div><div class="sentence"> For we should not teach bad habits, least of all to the best part of the citizens.</div><div class="sentence"> You may learn the evil of such a practice from Homer, by whom Odysseus is introduced, rebuking Agamemnon, because he desires to draw down the ships to the sea at a time when the Achaeans are hard pressed by the Trojans,—he gets angry with him, and says:</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">022</span> <div class="sentence">  'Who, at a time when the battle is in full cry, biddest to drag the well-benched ships into the sea, that the prayers of the Trojans may be accomplished yet more, and high ruin fall upon us.</div><div class="sentence"> For the Achaeans will not maintain the battle, when the ships are drawn into the sea, but they will look behind and will cease from strife; in that the counsel which you give will prove injurious.'</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">023</span> <div class="sentence">  You see that he quite knew triremes on the sea, in the neighbourhood of fighting men, to be an evil;—lions might be trained in that way to fly from a herd of deer.</div><div class="sentence"> Moreover, naval powers which owe their safety to ships, do not give honour to that sort of warlike excellence which is most deserving of it.</div><div class="sentence"> For he who owes his safety to the pilot and the captain, and the oarsman, and all sorts of rather inferior persons, cannot rightly give honour to whom honour is due.</div><div class="sentence"> But how can a state be in a right condition which cannot justly award honour?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">024</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  It is hardly possible, I admit; and yet, Stranger, we Cretans are in the habit of saying that the battle of Salamis was the salvation of Hellas.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">025</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Why, yes; and that is an opinion which is widely spread both among Hellenes and barbarians.</div><div class="sentence"> But Megillus and I say rather, that the battle of Marathon was the beginning, and the battle of Plataea the completion, of the great deliverance, and that these battles by land made the Hellenes better; whereas the sea-fights of Salamis and Artemisium—for I may as well put them both together—made them no better, if I may say so without offence about the battles which helped to save us.</div><div class="sentence"> And in estimating the goodness of a state, we regard both the situation of the country and the order of the laws, considering that the mere preservation and continuance of life is not the most honourable thing for men, as the vulgar think, but the continuance of the best life, while we live; and that again, if I am not mistaken, is a remark which has been made already.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">026</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">027</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then we have only to ask, whether we are taking the course which we acknowledge to be the best for the settlement and legislation of states.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">028</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  The best by far.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">029</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And now let me proceed to another question:  Who are to be the colonists?</div><div class="sentence"> May any one come out of all Crete; and is the idea that the population in the several states is too numerous for the means of subsistence?</div><div class="sentence"> For I suppose that you are not going to send out a general invitation to any Hellene who likes to come.</div><div class="sentence"> And yet I observe that to your country settlers have come from Argos and Aegina and other parts of Hellas.</div><div class="sentence"> Tell me, then, whence do you draw your recruits in the present enterprise?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">030</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  They will come from all Crete; and of other Hellenes, Peloponnesians will be most acceptable.</div><div class="sentence"> For, as you truly observe, there are Cretans of Argive descent; and the race of Cretans which has the highest character at the present day is the Gortynian, and this has come from Gortys in the Peloponnesus.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">031</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Cities find colonization in some respects easier if the colonists are one race, which like a swarm of bees is sent out from a single country, either when friends leave friends, owing to some pressure of population or other similar necessity, or when a portion of a state is driven by factions to emigrate.</div><div class="sentence"> And there have been whole cities which have taken flight when utterly conquered by a superior power in war.</div><div class="sentence"> This, however, which is in one way an advantage to the colonist or legislator, in another point of view creates a difficulty.</div><div class="sentence"> There is an element of friendship in the community of race, and language, and laws, and in common temples and rites of worship; but colonies which are of this homogeneous sort are apt to kick against any laws or any form of constitution differing from that which they had at home; and although the badness of their own laws may have been the cause of the factions which prevailed among them, yet from the force of habit they would fain preserve the very customs which were their ruin, and the leader of the colony, who is their legislator, finds them troublesome and rebellious.</div><div class="sentence"> On the other hand, the conflux of several populations might be more disposed to listen to new laws; but then, to make them combine and pull together, as they say of horses, is a most difficult task, and the work of years.</div><div class="sentence"> And yet there is nothing which tends more to the improvement of mankind than legislation and colonization.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">032</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  No doubt; but I should like to know why you say so.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">033</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  My good friend, I am afraid that the course of my speculations is leading me to say something depreciatory of legislators; but if the word be to the purpose, there can be no harm.</div><div class="sentence"> And yet, why am I disquieted, for I believe that the same principle applies equally to all human things?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">034</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To what are you referring?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">035</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I was going to say that man never legislates, but accidents of all sorts, which legislate for us in all sorts of ways.</div><div class="sentence"> The violence of war and the hard necessity of poverty are constantly overturning governments and changing laws.</div><div class="sentence"> And the power of disease has often caused innovations in the state, when there have been pestilences, or when there has been a succession of bad seasons continuing during many years.</div><div class="sentence"> Any one who sees all this, naturally rushes to the conclusion of which I was speaking, that no mortal legislates in anything, but that in human affairs chance is almost everything.</div><div class="sentence"> And this may be said of the arts of the sailor, and the pilot, and the physician, and the general, and may seem to be well said; and yet there is another thing which may be said with equal truth of all of them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">036</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What is it?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">037</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  That God governs all things, and that chance and opportunity co-operate with Him in the government of human affairs.</div><div class="sentence"> There is, however, a third and less extreme view, that art should be there also; for I should say that in a storm there must surely be a great advantage in having the aid of the pilot's art.</div><div class="sentence"> You would agree?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">038</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">039</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And does not a like principle apply to legislation as well as to other things:  even supposing all the conditions to be favourable which are needed for the happiness of the state, yet the true legislator must from time to time appear on the scene?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">040</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Most true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">041</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In each case the artist would be able to pray rightly for certain conditions, and if these were granted by fortune, he would then only require to exercise his art?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">042</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">043</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And all the other artists just now mentioned, if they were bidden to offer up each their special prayer, would do so?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">044</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Of course.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">045</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And the legislator would do likewise?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">046</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I believe that he would.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">047</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  'Come, legislator,' we will say to him; 'what are the conditions which you require in a state before you can organize it?'</div><div class="sentence"> How ought he to answer this question?</div><div class="sentence"> Shall I give his answer?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">048</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">049</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  He will say—'Give me a state which is governed by a tyrant, and let the tyrant be young and have a good memory; let him be quick at learning, and of a courageous and noble nature; let him have that quality which, as I said before, is the inseparable companion of all the other parts of virtue, if there is to be any good in them.'</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">050</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I suppose, Megillus, that this companion virtue of which the Stranger speaks, must be temperance?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">051</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, Cleinias, temperance in the vulgar sense; not that which in the forced and exaggerated language of some philosophers is called prudence, but that which is the natural gift of children and animals, of whom some live continently and others incontinently, but when isolated, was, as we said, hardly worth reckoning in the catalogue of goods.</div><div class="sentence"> I think that you must understand my meaning.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">052</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">053</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then our tyrant must have this as well as the other qualities, if the state is to acquire in the best manner and in the shortest time the form of government which is most conducive to happiness; for there neither is nor ever will be a better or speedier way of establishing a polity than by a tyranny.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">054</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  By what possible arguments, Stranger, can any man persuade himself of such a monstrous doctrine?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">055</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There is surely no difficulty in seeing, Cleinias, what is in accordance with the order of nature?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">056</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You would assume, as you say, a tyrant who was young, temperate, quick at learning, having a good memory, courageous, of a noble nature?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">057</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes; and you must add fortunate; and his good fortune must be that he is the contemporary of a great legislator, and that some happy chance brings them together.</div><div class="sentence"> When this has been accomplished, God has done all that he ever does for a state which he desires to be eminently prosperous; He has done second best for a state in which there are two such rulers, and third best for a state in which there are three.</div><div class="sentence"> The difficulty increases with the increase, and diminishes with the diminution of the number.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">058</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You mean to say, I suppose, that the best government is produced from a tyranny, and originates in a good lawgiver and an orderly tyrant, and that the change from such a tyranny into a perfect form of government takes place most easily; less easily when from an oligarchy; and, in the third degree, from a democracy:  is not that your meaning?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">059</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Not so; I mean rather to say that the change is best made out of a tyranny; and secondly, out of a monarchy; and thirdly, out of some sort of democracy:  fourth, in the capacity for improvement, comes oligarchy, which has the greatest difficulty in admitting of such a change, because the government is in the hands of a number of potentates.</div><div class="sentence"> I am supposing that the legislator is by nature of the true sort, and that his strength is united with that of the chief men of the state; and when the ruling element is numerically small, and at the same time very strong, as in a tyranny, there the change is likely to be easiest and most rapid.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">060</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How?</div><div class="sentence"> I do not understand.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">061</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And yet I have repeated what I am saying a good many times; but I suppose that you have never seen a city which is under a tyranny?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">062</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  No, and I cannot say that I have any great desire to see one.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">063</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And yet, where there is a tyranny, you might certainly see that of which I am now speaking.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">064</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">065</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I mean that you might see how, without trouble and in no very long period of time, the tyrant, if he wishes, can change the manners of a state:  he has only to go in the direction of virtue or of vice, whichever he prefers, he himself indicating by his example the lines of conduct, praising and rewarding some actions and reproving others, and degrading those who disobey.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">066</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  But how can we imagine that the citizens in general will at once follow the example set to them; and how can he have this power both of persuading and of compelling them?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">067</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let no one, my friends, persuade us that there is any quicker and easier way in which states change their laws than when the rulers lead:  such changes never have, nor ever will, come to pass in any other way.</div><div class="sentence"> The real impossibility or difficulty is of another sort, and is rarely surmounted in the course of ages; but when once it is surmounted, ten thousand or rather all blessings follow.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">068</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Of what are you speaking?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">069</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The difficulty is to find the divine love of temperate and just institutions existing in any powerful forms of government, whether in a monarchy or oligarchy of wealth or of birth.</div><div class="sentence"> You might as well hope to reproduce the character of Nestor, who is said to have excelled all men in the power of speech, and yet more in his temperance.</div><div class="sentence"> This, however, according to the tradition, was in the times of Troy; in our own days there is nothing of the sort; but if such an one either has or ever shall come into being, or is now among us, blessed is he and blessed are they who hear the wise words that flow from his lips.</div><div class="sentence"> And this may be said of power in general:  When the supreme power in man coincides with the greatest wisdom and temperance, then the best laws and the best constitution come into being; but in no other way.</div><div class="sentence"> And let what I have been saying be regarded as a kind of sacred legend or oracle, and let this be our proof that, in one point of view, there may be a difficulty for a city to have good laws, but that there is another point of view in which nothing can be easier or sooner effected, granting our supposition.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">070</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">071</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us try to amuse ourselves, old boys as we are, by moulding in words the laws which are suitable to your state.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">072</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Let us proceed without delay.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">073</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then let us invoke God at the settlement of our state; may He hear and be propitious to us, and come and set in order the State and the laws!</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">074</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  May He come!</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">075</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But what form of polity are we going to give the city?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">076</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Tell us what you mean a little more clearly.</div><div class="sentence"> Do you mean some form of democracy, or oligarchy, or aristocracy, or monarchy?</div><div class="sentence"> For we cannot suppose that you would include tyranny.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">077</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Which of you will first tell me to which of these classes his own government is to be referred?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">078</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Ought I to answer first, since I am the elder?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">079</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Perhaps you should.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">080</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  And yet, Stranger, I perceive that I cannot say, without more thought, what I should call the government of Lacedaemon, for it seems to me to be like a tyranny,—the power of our Ephors is marvellously tyrannical; and sometimes it appears to me to be of all cities the most democratical; and who can reasonably deny that it is an aristocracy (compare Ar.</div><div class="sentence"> Pol.)?</div><div class="sentence"> We have also a monarchy which is held for life, and is said by all mankind, and not by ourselves only, to be the most ancient of all monarchies; and, therefore, when asked on a sudden, I cannot precisely say which form of government the Spartan is.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">081</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I am in the same difficulty, Megillus; for I do not feel confident that the polity of Cnosus is any of these.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">082</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The reason is, my excellent friends, that you really have polities, but the states of which we were just now speaking are merely aggregations of men dwelling in cities who are the subjects and servants of a part of their own state, and each of them is named after the dominant power; they are not polities at all.</div><div class="sentence"> But if states are to be named after their rulers, the true state ought to be called by the name of the God who rules over wise men.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">083</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  And who is this God?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">084</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  May I still make use of fable to some extent, in the hope that I may be better able to answer your question:  shall I?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">085</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  By all means.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">086</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In the primeval world, and a long while before the cities came into being whose settlements we have described, there is said to have been in the time of Cronos a blessed rule and life, of which the best-ordered of existing states is a copy (compare Statesman).</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">087</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  It will be very necessary to hear about that.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">088</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I quite agree with you; and therefore I have introduced the subject.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">089</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Most appropriately; and since the tale is to the point, you will do well in giving us the whole story.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">090</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I will do as you suggest.</div><div class="sentence"> There is a tradition of the happy life of mankind in days when all things were spontaneous and abundant.</div><div class="sentence"> And of this the reason is said to have been as follows: —Cronos knew what we ourselves were declaring, that no human nature invested with supreme power is able to order human affairs and not overflow with insolence and wrong.</div><div class="sentence"> Which reflection led him to appoint not men but demigods, who are of a higher and more divine race, to be the kings and rulers of our cities; he did as we do with flocks of sheep and other tame animals.</div><div class="sentence"> For we do not appoint oxen to be the lords of oxen, or goats of goats; but we ourselves are a superior race, and rule over them.</div><div class="sentence"> In like manner God, in His love of mankind, placed over us the demons, who are a superior race, and they with great ease and pleasure to themselves, and no less to us, taking care of us and giving us peace and reverence and order and justice never failing, made the tribes of men happy and united.</div><div class="sentence"> And this tradition, which is true, declares that cities of which some mortal man and not God is the ruler, have no escape from evils and toils.</div><div class="sentence"> Still we must do all that we can to imitate the life which is said to have existed in the days of Cronos, and, as far as the principle of immortality dwells in us, to that we must hearken, both in private and public life, and regulate our cities and houses according to law, meaning by the very term 'law,' the distribution of mind.</div><div class="sentence"> But if either a single person or an oligarchy or a democracy has a soul eager after pleasures and desires—wanting to be filled with them, yet retaining none of them, and perpetually afflicted with an endless and insatiable disorder; and this evil spirit, having first trampled the laws under foot, becomes the master either of a state or of an individual,—then, as I was saying, salvation is hopeless.</div><div class="sentence"> And now, Cleinias, we have to consider whether you will or will not accept this tale of mine.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">091</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly we will.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">092</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  You are aware,—are you not?—that there are often said to be as many forms of laws as there are of governments, and of the latter we have already mentioned all those which are commonly recognized.</div><div class="sentence"> Now you must regard this as a matter of first-rate importance.</div><div class="sentence"> For what is to be the standard of just and unjust, is once more the point at issue.</div><div class="sentence"> Men say that the law ought not to regard either military virtue, or virtue in general, but only the interests and power and preservation of the established form of government; this is thought by them to be the best way of expressing the natural definition of justice.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">093</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">094</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Justice is said by them to be the interest of the stronger (Republic).</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">095</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Speak plainer.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">096</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I will: —'Surely,' they say, 'the governing power makes whatever laws have authority in any state'?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">097</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">098</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  'Well,' they would add, 'and do you suppose that tyranny or democracy, or any other conquering power, does not make the continuance of the power which is possessed by them the first or principal object of their laws'?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">099</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How can they have any other?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">100</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  'And whoever transgresses these laws is punished as an evil-doer by the legislator, who calls the laws just'?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">101</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Naturally.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">102</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  'This, then, is always the mode and fashion in which justice exists.'</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">103</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly, if they are correct in their view.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">104</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Why, yes, this is one of those false principles of government to which we were referring.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">105</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Which do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">106</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Those which we were examining when we spoke of who ought to govern whom.</div><div class="sentence"> Did we not arrive at the conclusion that parents ought to govern their children, and the elder the younger, and the noble the ignoble?</div><div class="sentence"> And there were many other principles, if you remember, and they were not always consistent.</div><div class="sentence"> One principle was this very principle of might, and we said that Pindar considered violence natural and justified it.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">107</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes; I remember.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">108</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Consider, then, to whom our state is to be entrusted.</div><div class="sentence"> For there is a thing which has occurred times without number in states—</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">109</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What thing?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">110</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  That when there has been a contest for power, those who gain the upper hand so entirely monopolize the government, as to refuse all share to the defeated party and their descendants—they live watching one another, the ruling class being in perpetual fear that some one who has a recollection of former wrongs will come into power and rise up against them.</div><div class="sentence"> Now, according to our view, such governments are not polities at all, nor are laws right which are passed for the good of particular classes and not for the good of the whole state.</div><div class="sentence"> States which have such laws are not polities but parties, and their notions of justice are simply unmeaning.</div><div class="sentence"> I say this, because I am going to assert that we must not entrust the government in your state to any one because he is rich, or because he possesses any other advantage, such as strength, or stature, or again birth:  but he who is most obedient to the laws of the state, he shall win the palm; and to him who is victorious in the first degree shall be given the highest office and chief ministry of the gods; and the second to him who bears the second palm; and on a similar principle shall all the other offices be assigned to those who come next in order.</div><div class="sentence"> And when I call the rulers servants or ministers of the law, I give them this name not for the sake of novelty, but because I certainly believe that upon such service or ministry depends the well- or ill-being of the state.</div><div class="sentence"> For that state in which the law is subject and has no authority, I perceive to be on the highway to ruin; but I see that the state in which the law is above the rulers, and the rulers are the inferiors of the law, has salvation, and every blessing which the Gods can confer.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">111</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Truly, Stranger, you see with the keen vision of age.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">112</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Why, yes; every man when he is young has that sort of vision dullest, and when he is old keenest.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">113</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">114</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And now, what is to be the next step?</div><div class="sentence"> May we not suppose the colonists to have arrived, and proceed to make our speech to them?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">115</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">116</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  'Friends,' we say to them,—'God, as the old tradition declares, holding in his hand the beginning, middle, and end of all that is, travels according to His nature in a straight line towards the accomplishment of His end.</div><div class="sentence"> Justice always accompanies Him, and is the punisher of those who fall short of the divine law.</div><div class="sentence"> To justice, he who would be happy holds fast, and follows in her company with all humility and order; but he who is lifted up with pride, or elated by wealth or rank, or beauty, who is young and foolish, and has a soul hot with insolence, and thinks that he has no need of any guide or ruler, but is able himself to be the guide of others, he, I say, is left deserted of God; and being thus deserted, he takes to him others who are like himself, and dances about, throwing all things into confusion, and many think that he is a great man, but in a short time he pays a penalty which justice cannot but approve, and is utterly destroyed, and his family and city with him.</div><div class="sentence"> Wherefore, seeing that human things are thus ordered, what should a wise man do or think, or not do or think'?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">117</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Every man ought to make up his mind that he will be one of the followers of God; there can be no doubt of that.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">118</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then what life is agreeable to God, and becoming in His followers?</div><div class="sentence"> One only, expressed once for all in the old saying that 'like agrees with like, with measure measure,' but things which have no measure agree neither with themselves nor with the things which have.</div><div class="sentence"> Now God ought to be to us the measure of all things, and not man (compare Crat.</div><div class="sentence"> ; Theaet.</div><div class="sentence"> ), as men commonly say (Protagoras):  the words are far more true of Him.</div><div class="sentence"> And he who would be dear to God must, as far as is possible, be like Him and such as He is.</div><div class="sentence"> Wherefore the temperate man is the friend of God, for he is like Him; and the intemperate man is unlike Him, and different from Him, and unjust.</div><div class="sentence"> And the same applies to other things; and this is the conclusion, which is also the noblest and truest of all sayings,—that for the good man to offer sacrifice to the Gods, and hold converse with them by means of prayers and offerings and every kind of service, is the noblest and best of all things, and also the most conducive to a happy life, and very fit and meet.</div><div class="sentence"> But with the bad man, the opposite of this is true:  for the bad man has an impure soul, whereas the good is pure; and from one who is polluted, neither a good man nor God can without impropriety receive gifts.</div><div class="sentence"> Wherefore the unholy do only waste their much service upon the Gods, but when offered by any holy man, such service is most acceptable to them.</div><div class="sentence"> This is the mark at which we ought to aim.</div><div class="sentence"> But what weapons shall we use, and how shall we direct them?</div><div class="sentence"> In the first place, we affirm that next after the Olympian Gods and the Gods of the State, honour should be given to the Gods below;
