<div class="speech"><span class="ref">081</span> <div class="sentence">  Different persons have got these two different notions of slaves in their minds—some of them utterly distrust their servants, and, as if they were wild beasts, chastise them with goads and whips, and make their souls three times, or rather many times, as slavish as they were before;—and others do just the opposite.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">082</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">083</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Then what are we to do in our own country, Stranger, seeing that there are such differences in the treatment of slaves by their owners?</div></div>

<div class="speech"><span class="ref">087</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">088</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Now that each of the citizens is provided, as far as possible, with a sufficient number of suitable slaves who can help him in what he has to do, we may next proceed to describe their dwellings.</div></div>

<div class="speech"><span class="ref">090</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The city being new and hitherto uninhabited, care ought to be taken of all the buildings, and the manner of building each of them, and also of the temples and walls.</div><div class="sentence"> These, Cleinias, were matters which properly came before the marriages;—but, as we are only talking, there is no objection to changing the order.</div><div class="sentence"> If, however, our plan of legislation is ever to take effect, then the house shall precede the marriage if God so will, and afterwards we will come to the regulations about marriage; but at present we are only describing these matters in a general outline.</div></div>

<div class="speech"><span class="ref">092</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The temples are to be placed all round the agora, and the whole city built on the heights in a circle (compare Arist.</div><div class="sentence"> Pol.</div><div class="sentence"> ), for the sake of defence and for the sake of purity.</div><div class="sentence"> Near the temples are to be placed buildings for the magistrates and the courts of law; in these plaintiff and defendant will receive their due, and the places will be regarded as most holy, partly because they have to do with holy things:  and partly because they are the dwelling-places of holy Gods:  and in them will be held the courts in which cases of homicide and other trials of capital offences may fitly take place.</div><div class="sentence"> As to the walls, Megillus, I agree with Sparta in thinking that they should be allowed to sleep in the earth, and that we should not attempt to disinter them (compare Arist.</div><div class="sentence"> Pol.</div><div class="sentence"> ); there is a poetical saying, which is finely expressed, that 'walls ought to be of steel and iron, and not of earth;' besides, how ridiculous of us to be sending out our young men annually into the country to dig and to trench, and to keep off the enemy by fortifications, under the idea that they are not to be allowed to set foot in our territory, and then, that we should surround ourselves with a wall, which, in the first place, is by no means conducive to the health of cities, and is also apt to produce a certain effeminacy in the minds of the inhabitants, inviting men to run thither instead of repelling their enemies, and leading them to imagine that their safety is due not to their keeping guard day and night, but that when they are protected by walls and gates, then they may sleep in safety; <div class="speech"><span class="ref">096</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  He who imagines that he can give laws for the public conduct of states, while he leaves the private life of citizens wholly to take care of itself; who thinks that individuals may pass the day as they please, and that there is no necessity of order in all things; he, I say, who gives up the control of their private lives, and supposes that they will conform to law in their common and public life, is making a great mistake.</div><div class="sentence"> Why have I made this remark?</div><div class="sentence"> Why, because I am going to enact that the bridegrooms should live at the common tables, just as they did before marriage.</div><div class="sentence"> This was a singularity when first enacted by the legislator in your parts of the world, Megillus and Cleinias, as I should suppose, on the occasion of some war or other similar danger, which caused the passing of the law, and which would be likely to occur in thinly-peopled places, and in times of pressure.</div><div class="sentence"> But when men had once tried and been accustomed to a common table, experience showed that the institution greatly conduced to security; and in some such manner the custom of having common tables arose among you.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">097</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Likely enough.</div></div>

<div class="speech"><span class="ref">101</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  There is nothing which we should both of us like better, Stranger, than to hear what you have to say.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">102</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Very good; and you must not be surprised if I go back a little, for we have plenty of leisure, and there is nothing to prevent us from considering in every point of view the subject of law.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">103</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">104</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then let us return once more to what we were saying at first.</div><div class="sentence"> Every man should understand that the human race either had no beginning at all, and will never have an end, but always will be and has been; or that it began an immense while ago.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">105</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">106</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, and have there not been constitutions and destructions of states, and all sorts of pursuits both orderly and disorderly, and diverse desires of meats and drinks always, and in all the world, and all sorts of changes of the seasons in which animals may be expected to have undergone innumerable transformations of themselves?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">107</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  No doubt.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">108</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And may we not suppose that vines appeared, which had previously no existence, and also olives, and the gifts of Demeter and her daughter, of which one Triptolemus was the minister, and that, before these existed, animals took to devouring each other as they do still?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">109</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">110</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Again, the practice of men sacrificing one another still exists among many nations; while, on the other hand, we hear of other human beings who did not even venture to taste the flesh of a cow and had no animal sacrifices, but only cakes and fruits dipped in honey, and similar pure offerings, but no flesh of animals; from these they abstained under the idea that they ought not to eat them, and might not stain the altars of the Gods with blood.</div><div class="sentence"> For in those days men are said to have lived a sort of Orphic life, having the use of all lifeless things, but abstaining from all living things.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">111</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Such has been the constant tradition, and is very likely true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">112</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Some one might say to us, What is the drift of all this?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">113</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  A very pertinent question, Stranger.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">114</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And therefore I will endeavour, Cleinias, if I can, to draw the natural inference.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">115</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Proceed.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">116</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I see that among men all things depend upon three wants and desires, of which the end is virtue, if they are rightly led by them, or the opposite if wrongly.</div><div class="sentence"> Now these are eating and drinking, which begin at birth—every animal has a natural desire for them, and is violently excited, and rebels against him who says that he must not satisfy all his pleasures and appetites, and get rid of all the corresponding pains—and the third and greatest and sharpest want and desire breaks out last, and is the fire of sexual lust, which kindles in men every species of wantonness and madness.</div><div class="sentence"> And these three disorders we must endeavour to master by the three great principles of fear and law and right reason; turning them away from that which is called pleasantest to the best, using the Muses and the Gods who preside over contests to extinguish their increase and influx.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">117</span> <div class="sentence">  But to return:—After marriage let us speak of the birth of children, and after their birth of their nurture and education.</div><div class="sentence"> In the course of discussion the several laws will be perfected, and we shall at last arrive at the common tables.</div><div class="sentence"> Whether such associations are to be confined to men, or extended to women also, we shall see better when we approach and take a nearer view of them; and we may then determine what previous institutions are required and will have to precede them.</div><div class="sentence"> As I said before, we shall see them more in detail, and shall be better able to lay down the laws which are proper or suited to them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">118</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">119</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us keep in mind the words which have now been spoken; for hereafter there may be need of them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">120</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you bid us keep in mind?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">121</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  That which we comprehended under the three words—first, eating, secondly, drinking, thirdly, the excitement of love.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">122</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  We shall be sure to remember, Stranger.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">123</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Very good.</div><div class="sentence"> Then let us now proceed to marriage, and teach persons in what way they shall beget children, threatening them, if they disobey, with the terrors of the law.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">124</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">125</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The bride and bridegroom should consider that they are to produce for the state the best and fairest specimens of children which they can.</div><div class="sentence"> Now all men who are associated in any action always succeed when they attend and give their mind to what they are doing, but when they do not give their mind or have no mind, they fail; wherefore let the bridegroom give his mind to the bride and to the begetting of children, and the bride in like manner give her mind to the bridegroom, and particularly at the time when their children are not yet born.</div><div class="sentence"> And let the women whom we have chosen be the overseers of such matters, and let them in whatever number, large or small, and at whatever time the magistrates may command, assemble every day in the temple of Eileithyia during a third part of the day, and being there assembled, let them inform one another of any one whom they see, whether man or woman, of those who are begetting children, disregarding the ordinances given at the time when the nuptial sacrifices and ceremonies were performed.</div><div class="sentence"> Let the begetting of children and the supervision of those who are begetting them continue ten years and no longer, during the time when marriage is fruitful.</div><div class="sentence"> But if any continue without children up to this time, let them take counsel with their kindred and with the women holding the office of overseer and be divorced for their mutual benefit.</div><div class="sentence"> If, however, any dispute arises about what is proper and for the interest of either party, they shall choose ten of the guardians of the law and abide by their permission and appointment.</div><div class="sentence"> The women who preside over these matters shall enter into the houses of the young, and partly by admonitions and partly by threats make them give over their folly and error:  if they persist, let the women go and tell the guardians of the law, and the guardians shall prevent them.</div><div class="sentence"> But if they too cannot prevent them, they shall bring the matter before the people; and let them write up their names and make oath that they cannot reform such and such an one; and let him who is thus written up, if he cannot in a court of law convict those who have inscribed his name, be deprived of the privileges of a citizen in the following respects: —let him not go to weddings nor to the thanksgivings after the birth of children; and if he go, let any one who pleases strike him with impunity; and let the same regulations hold about women:  let not a woman be allowed to appear abroad, or receive honour, or go to nuptial and birthday festivals, if she in like manner be written up as acting disorderly and cannot obtain a verdict.</div><div class="sentence"> And if, when they themselves have done begetting children according to the law, a man or woman have connexion with another man or woman who are still begetting children, let the same penalties be inflicted upon them as upon those who are still having a family; and when the time for procreation has passed let the man or woman who refrains in such matters be held in esteem, and let those who do not refrain be held in the contrary of esteem—that is to say, disesteem.</div><div class="sentence"> Now, if the greater part of mankind behave modestly, the enactments of law may be left to slumber; but, if they are disorderly, the enactments having been passed, let them be carried into execution.</div><div class="sentence"> To every man the first year is the beginning of life, and the time of birth ought to be written down in the temples of their fathers as the beginning of existence to every child, whether boy or girl.</div><div class="sentence"> Let every phratria have inscribed on a whited wall the names of the successive archons by whom the years are reckoned.</div><div class="sentence"> And near to them let the living members of the phratria be inscribed, and when they depart life let them be erased.</div><div class="sentence"> The limit of marriageable ages for a woman shall be from sixteen to twenty years at the longest,—for a man, from thirty to thirty-five years; and let a woman hold office at forty, and a man at thirty years.</div><div class="sentence"> Let a man go out to war from twenty to sixty years, and for a woman, if there appear any need to make use of her in military service, let the time of service be after she shall have brought forth children up to fifty years of age; and let regard be had to what is possible and suitable to each.</div></div>

</div><div id="link2H_4_0010" class="book_section">
<h2>BOOK VII.</h2>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">001</span> <div class="sentence">  And now, assuming children of both sexes to have been born, it will be proper for us to consider, in the next place, their nurture and education; this cannot be left altogether unnoticed, and yet may be thought a subject fitted rather for precept and admonition than for law.</div><div class="sentence"> In private life there are many little things, not always apparent, arising out of the pleasures and pains and desires of individuals, which run counter to the intention of the legislator, and make the characters of the citizens various and dissimilar:—this is an evil in states; for by reason of their smallness and frequent occurrence, there would be an unseemliness and want of propriety in making them penal by law; and if made penal, they are the destruction of the written law because mankind get the habit of frequently transgressing the law in small matters.</div><div class="sentence"> The result is that you cannot legislate about them, and still less can you be silent.</div><div class="sentence"> I speak somewhat darkly, but I shall endeavour also to bring my wares into the light of day, for I acknowledge that at present there is a want of clearness in what I am saying.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">002</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">003</span> <div class="sentence">  ATHENIAN.</div><div class="sentence"> Am I not right in maintaining that a good education is that which tends most to the improvement of mind and body?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">004</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Undoubtedly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">005</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And nothing can be plainer than that the fairest bodies are those which grow up from infancy in the best and straightest manner?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">006</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">007</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And do we not further observe that the first shoot of every living thing is by far the greatest and fullest?</div><div class="sentence"> Many will even contend that a man at twenty-five does not reach twice the height which he attained at five.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">008</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">009</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, and is not rapid growth without proper and abundant exercise the source endless evils in the body?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">010</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">011</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And the body should have the most exercise when it receives most nourishment?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">012</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  But, Stranger, are we to impose this great amount of exercise upon newly-born infants?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">013</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Nay, rather on the bodies of infants still unborn.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">014</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you mean, my good sir?</div><div class="sentence"> In the process of gestation?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">015</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Exactly.</div><div class="sentence"> I am not at all surprised that you have never heard of this very peculiar sort of gymnastic applied to such little creatures, which, although strange, I will endeavour to explain to you.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">016</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  By all means.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">017</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The practice is more easy for us to understand than for you, by reason of certain amusements which are carried to excess by us at Athens.</div><div class="sentence"> Not only boys, but often older persons, are in the habit of keeping quails and cocks (compare Republic), which they train to fight one another.</div><div class="sentence"> And they are far from thinking that the contests in which they stir them up to fight with one another are sufficient exercise; for, in addition to this, they carry them about tucked beneath their armpits, holding the smaller birds in their hands, the larger under their arms, and go for a walk of a great many miles for the sake of health, that is to say, not their own health, but the health of the birds; whereby they prove to any intelligent person, that all bodies are benefited by shakings and movements, when they are moved without weariness, whether the motion proceeds from themselves, or is caused by a swing, or at sea, or on horseback, or by other bodies in whatever way moving, and that thus gaining the mastery over food and drink, they are able to impart beauty and health and strength.</div><div class="sentence"> But admitting all this, what follows?</div><div class="sentence"> Shall we make a ridiculous law that the pregnant woman shall walk about and fashion the embryo within as we fashion wax before it hardens, and after birth swathe the infant for two years?</div><div class="sentence"> Suppose that we compel nurses, under penalty of a legal fine, to be always carrying the children somewhere or other, either to the temples, or into the country, or to their relations' houses, until they are well able to stand, and to take care that their limbs are not distorted by leaning on them when they are too young (compare Arist.</div><div class="sentence"> Pol.</div><div class="sentence"> ),—they should continue to carry them until the infant has completed its third year; the nurses should be strong, and there should be more than one of them.</div><div class="sentence"> Shall these be our rules, and shall we impose a penalty for the neglect of them?</div><div class="sentence"> No, no; the penalty of which we were speaking will fall upon our own heads more than enough.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">018</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What penalty?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">019</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Ridicule, and the difficulty of getting the feminine and servant-like dispositions of the nurses to comply.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">020</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Then why was there any need to speak of the matter at all?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">021</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The reason is, that masters and freemen in states, when they hear of it, are very likely to arrive at a true conviction that without due regulation of private life in cities, stability in the laying down of laws is hardly to be expected (compare Republic); and he who makes this reflection may himself adopt the laws just now mentioned, and, adopting them, may order his house and state well and be happy.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">022</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Likely enough.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">023</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And therefore let us proceed with our legislation until we have determined the exercises which are suited to the souls of young children, in the same manner in which we have begun to go through the rules relating to their bodies.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">024</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  By all means.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">025</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us assume, then, as a first principle in relation both to the body and soul of very young creatures, that nursing and moving about by day and night is good for them all, and that the younger they are, the more they will need it (compare Arist.</div><div class="sentence"> Pol.</div><div class="sentence"> ); infants should live, if that were possible, as if they were always rocking at sea.</div><div class="sentence"> This is the lesson which we may gather from the experience of nurses, and likewise from the use of the remedy of motion in the rites of the Corybantes; for when mothers want their restless children to go to sleep they do not employ rest, but, on the contrary, motion—rocking them in their arms; nor do they give them silence, but they sing to them and lap them in sweet strains; and the Bacchic women are cured of their frenzy in the same manner by the use of the dance and of music.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">026</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Well, Stranger, and what is the reason of this?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">027</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The reason is obvious.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">028</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">029</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The affection both of the Bacchantes and of the children is an emotion of fear, which springs out of an evil habit of the soul.</div><div class="sentence"> And when some one applies external agitation to affections of this sort, the motion coming from without gets the better of the terrible and violent internal one, and produces a peace and calm in the soul, and quiets the restless palpitation of the heart, which is a thing much to be desired, sending the children to sleep, and making the Bacchantes, although they remain awake, to dance to the pipe with the help of the Gods to whom they offer acceptable sacrifices, and producing in them a sound mind, which takes the place of their frenzy.</div><div class="sentence"> And, to express what I mean in a word, there is a good deal to be said in favour of this treatment.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">030</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">031</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But if fear has such a power we ought to infer from these facts, that every soul which from youth upward has been familiar with fears, will be made more liable to fear (compare Republic), and every one will allow that this is the way to form a habit of cowardice and not of courage.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">032</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  No doubt.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">033</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And, on the other hand, the habit of overcoming, from our youth upwards, the fears and terrors which beset us, may be said to be an exercise of courage.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">034</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">035</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And we may say that the use of exercise and motion in the earliest years of life greatly contributes to create a part of virtue in the soul.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">036</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Quite true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">037</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Further, a cheerful temper, or the reverse, may be regarded as having much to do with high spirit on the one hand, or with cowardice on the other.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">038</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To be sure.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">039</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then now we must endeavour to show how and to what extent we may, if we please, without difficulty implant either character in the young.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">040</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">041</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There is a common opinion, that luxury makes the disposition of youth discontented and irascible and vehemently excited by trifles; that on the other hand excessive and savage servitude makes men mean and abject, and haters of their kind, and therefore makes them undesirable associates.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">042</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  But how must the state educate those who do not as yet understand the language of the country, and are therefore incapable of appreciating any sort of instruction?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">043</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I will tell you how: —Every animal that is born is wont to utter some cry, and this is especially the case with man, and he is also affected with the inclination to weep more than any other animal.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">044</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Quite true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">045</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Do not nurses, when they want to know what an infant desires, judge by these signs?—when anything is brought to the infant and he is silent, then he is supposed to be pleased, but, when he weeps and cries out, then he is not pleased.</div><div class="sentence"> For tears and cries are the inauspicious signs by which children show what they love and hate.</div><div class="sentence"> Now the time which is thus spent is no less than three years, and is a very considerable portion of life to be passed ill or well.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">046</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">047</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Does not the discontented and ungracious nature appear to you to be full of lamentations and sorrows more than a good man ought to be?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">048</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">049</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, but if during these three years every possible care were taken that our nursling should have as little of sorrow and fear, and in general of pain as was possible, might we not expect in early childhood to make his soul more gentle and cheerful?</div><div class="sentence"> (Compare Arist.</div><div class="sentence"> Pol.)</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">050</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To be sure, Stranger—more especially if we could procure him a variety of pleasures.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">051</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There I can no longer agree, Cleinias:  you amaze me.</div><div class="sentence"> To bring him up in such a way would be his utter ruin; for the beginning is always the most critical part of education.</div><div class="sentence"> Let us see whether I am right.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">052</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Proceed.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">053</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The point about which you and I differ is of great importance, and I hope that you, Megillus, will help to decide between us.</div><div class="sentence"> For I maintain that the true life should neither seek for pleasures, nor, on the other hand, entirely avoid pains, but should embrace the middle state (compare Republic), which I just spoke of as gentle and benign, and is a state which we by some divine presage and inspiration rightly ascribe to God.</div><div class="sentence"> Now, I say, he among men, too, who would be divine ought to pursue after this mean habit—he should not rush headlong into pleasures, for he will not be free from pains; nor should we allow any one, young or old, male or female, to be thus given any more than ourselves, and least of all the newly-born infant, for in infancy more than at any other time the character is engrained by habit.</div><div class="sentence"> Nay, more, if I were not afraid of appearing to be ridiculous, I would say that a woman during her year of pregnancy should of all women be most carefully tended, and kept from violent or excessive pleasures and pains, and should at that time cultivate gentleness and benevolence and kindness.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">054</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You need not ask Megillus, Stranger, which of us has most truly spoken; for I myself agree that all men ought to avoid the life of unmingled pain or pleasure, and pursue always a middle course.</div><div class="sentence"> And having spoken well, may I add that you have been well answered?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">055</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Very good, Cleinias; and now let us all three consider a further point.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">056</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What is it?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">057</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  That all the matters which we are now describing are commonly called by the general name of unwritten customs, and what are termed the laws of our ancestors are all of similar nature.</div><div class="sentence"> And the reflection which lately arose in our minds, that we can neither call these things laws, nor yet leave them unmentioned, is justified; for they are the bonds of the whole state, and come in between the written laws which are or are hereafter to be laid down; they are just ancestral customs of great antiquity, which, if they are rightly ordered and made habitual, shield and preserve the previously existing written law; but if they depart from right and fall into disorder, then they are like the props of builders which slip away out of their place and cause a universal ruin—one part drags another down, and the fair super-structure falls because the old foundations are undermined.</div><div class="sentence"> Reflecting upon this, Cleinias, you ought to bind together the new state in every possible way, omitting nothing, whether great or small, of what are called laws or manners or pursuits, for by these means a city is bound together, and all these things are only lasting when they depend upon one another; and, therefore, we must not wonder if we find that many apparently trifling customs or usages come pouring in and lengthening out our laws.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">058</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true:  we are disposed to agree with you.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">059</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Up to the age of three years, whether of boy or girl, if a person strictly carries out our previous regulations and makes them a principal aim, he will do much for the advantage of the young creatures.</div><div class="sentence"> But at three, four, five, and even six years the childish nature will require sports; now is the time to get rid of self-will in him, punishing him, but not so as to disgrace him.</div><div class="sentence"> We were saying about slaves, that we ought neither to add insult to punishment so as to anger them, nor yet to leave them unpunished lest they become self-willed; and a like rule is to be observed in the case of the free-born.</div><div class="sentence"> Children at that age have certain natural modes of amusement which they find out for themselves when they meet.</div><div class="sentence"> And all the children who are between the ages of three and six ought to meet at the temples of the villages, the several families of a village uniting on one spot.</div><div class="sentence"> The nurses are to see that the children behave properly and orderly—they themselves and all their companies are to be under the control of twelve matrons, one for each company, who are annually selected to inspect them from the women previously mentioned [i.e.</div><div class="sentence"> the women who have authority over marriage], whom the guardians of the law appoint.</div><div class="sentence"> These matrons shall be chosen by the women who have authority over marriage, one out of each tribe; all are to be of the same age; and let each of them, as soon as she is appointed, hold office and go to the temples every day, punishing all offenders, male or female, who are slaves or strangers, by the help of some of the public slaves; but if any citizen disputes the punishment, let her bring him before the wardens of the city; or, if there be no dispute, let her punish him herself.</div><div class="sentence"> After the age of six years the time has arrived for the separation of the sexes—let boys live with boys, and girls in like manner with girls.</div><div class="sentence"> Now they must begin to learn—the boys going to teachers of horsemanship and the use of the bow, the javelin, and sling, and the girls too, if they do not object, at any rate until they know how to manage these weapons, and especially how to handle heavy arms; for I may note, that the practice which now prevails is almost universally misunderstood.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">060</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  In what respect?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">061</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In that the right and left hand are supposed to be by nature differently suited for our various uses of them; whereas no difference is found in the use of the feet and the lower limbs; but in the use of the hands we are, as it were, maimed by the folly of nurses and mothers; for although our several limbs are by nature balanced, we create a difference in them by bad habit.</div><div class="sentence"> In some cases this is of no consequence, as, for example, when we hold the lyre in the left hand, and the plectrum in the right, but it is downright folly to make the same distinction in other cases.</div><div class="sentence"> The custom of the Scythians proves our error; for they not only hold the bow from them with the left hand and draw the arrow to them with their right, but use either hand for both purposes.</div><div class="sentence"> And there are many similar examples in charioteering and other things, from which we may learn that those who make the left side weaker than the right act contrary to nature.</div><div class="sentence"> In the case of the plectrum, which is of horn only, and similar instruments, as I was saying, it is of no consequence, but makes a great difference, and may be of very great importance to the warrior who has to use iron weapons, bows and javelins, and the like; above all, when in heavy armour, he has to fight against heavy armour.</div><div class="sentence"> And there is a very great difference between one who has learnt and one who has not, and between one who has been trained in gymnastic exercises and one who has not been.</div><div class="sentence"> For as he who is perfectly skilled in the Pancratium or boxing or wrestling, is not unable to fight from his left side, and does not limp and draggle in confusion when his opponent makes him change his position, so in heavy-armed fighting, and in all other things, if I am not mistaken, the like holds—he who has these double powers of attack and defence ought not in any case to leave them either unused or untrained, if he can help; and if a person had the nature of Geryon or Briareus he ought to be able with his hundred hands to throw a hundred darts.</div><div class="sentence"> Now, the magistrates, male and female, should see to all these things, the women superintending the nursing and amusements of the children, and the men superintending their education, that all of them, boys and girls alike, may be sound hand and foot, and may not, if they can help, spoil the gifts of nature by bad habits.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">062</span> <div class="sentence">  Education has two branches—one of gymnastic, which is concerned with the body, and the other of music, which is designed for the improvement of the soul.</div><div class="sentence"> And gymnastic has also two branches—dancing and wrestling; and one sort of dancing imitates musical recitation, and aims at preserving dignity and freedom, the other aims at producing health, agility, and beauty in the limbs and parts of the body, giving the proper flexion and extension to each of them, a harmonious motion being diffused everywhere, and forming a suitable accompaniment to the dance.</div><div class="sentence"> As regards wrestling, the tricks which Antaeus and Cercyon devised in their systems out of a vain spirit of competition, or the tricks of boxing which Epeius or Amycus invented, are useless and unsuitable for war, and do not deserve to have much said about them; but the art of wrestling erect and keeping free the neck and hands and sides, working with energy and constancy, with a composed strength, for the sake of health—these are always useful, and are not to be neglected, but to be enjoined alike on masters and scholars, when we reach that part of legislation; and we will desire the one to give their instructions freely, and the others to receive them thankfully.</div><div class="sentence"> Nor, again, must we omit suitable imitations of war in our choruses; here in Crete you have the armed dances of the Curetes, and the Lacedaemonians have those of the Dioscuri.</div><div class="sentence"> And our virgin lady, delighting in the amusement of the dance, thought it not fit to amuse herself with empty hands; she must be clothed in a complete suit of armour, and in this attire go through the dance; and youths and maidens should in every respect imitate her, esteeming highly the favour of the Goddess, both with a view to the necessities of war, and to festive occasions: it will be right also for the boys, until such time as they go out to war, to make processions and supplications to all the Gods in goodly array, armed and on horseback, in dances and marches, fast or slow, offering up prayers to the Gods and to the sons of Gods; and also engaging in contests and preludes of contests, if at all, with these objects.</div><div class="sentence"> For these sorts of exercises, and no others, are useful both in peace and war, and are beneficial alike to states and to private houses.</div><div class="sentence"> But other labours and sports and exercises of the body are unworthy of freemen, O Megillus and Cleinias.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">063</span> <div class="sentence">  I have now completely described the kind of gymnastic which I said at first ought to be described; if you know of any better, will you communicate your thoughts?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">064</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  It is not easy, Stranger, to put aside these principles of gymnastic and wrestling and to enunciate better ones.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">065</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Now we must say what has yet to be said about the gifts of the Muses and of Apollo:  before, we fancied that we had said all, and that gymnastic alone remained; but now we see clearly what points have been omitted, and should be first proclaimed; of these, then, let us proceed to speak.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">066</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  By all means.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">067</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let me tell you once more—although you have heard me say the same before—that caution must be always exercised, both by the speaker and by the hearer, about anything that is very singular and unusual.</div><div class="sentence"> For my tale is one which many a man would be afraid to tell, and yet I have a confidence which makes me go on.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">068</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What have you to say, Stranger?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">069</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I say that in states generally no one has observed that the plays of childhood have a great deal to do with the permanence or want of permanence in legislation.</div><div class="sentence"> For when plays are ordered with a view to children having the same plays, and amusing themselves after the same manner, and finding delight in the same playthings, the more solemn institutions of the state are allowed to remain undisturbed.</div><div class="sentence"> Whereas if sports are disturbed, and innovations are made in them, and they constantly change, and the young never speak of their having the same likings, or the same established notions of good and bad taste, either in the bearing of their bodies or in their dress, but he who devises something new and out of the way in figures and colours and the like is held in special honour, we may truly say that no greater evil can happen in a state; for he who changes the sports is secretly changing the manners of the young, and making the old to be dishonoured among them and the new to be honoured.</div><div class="sentence"> And I affirm that there is nothing which is a greater injury to all states than saying or thinking thus.</div><div class="sentence"> Will you hear me tell how great I deem the evil to be?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">070</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You mean the evil of blaming antiquity in states?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">071</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Exactly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">072</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  If you are speaking of that, you will find in us hearers who are disposed to receive what you say not unfavourably but most favourably.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">073</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I should expect so.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">074</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Proceed.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">075</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, then, let us give all the greater heed to one another's words.</div><div class="sentence"> The argument affirms that any change whatever except from evil is the most dangerous of all things; this is true in the case of the seasons and of the winds, in the management of our bodies and the habits of our minds—true of all things except, as I said before, of the bad.</div><div class="sentence"> He who looks at the constitution of individuals accustomed to eat any sort of meat, or drink any drink, or to do any work which they can get, may see that they are at first disordered by them, but afterwards, as time goes on, their bodies grow adapted to them, and they learn to know and like variety, and have good health and enjoyment of life; and if ever afterwards they are confined again to a superior diet, at first they are troubled with disorders, and with difficulty become habituated to their new food.</div><div class="sentence"> A similar principle we may imagine to hold good about the minds of men and the natures of their souls.</div><div class="sentence"> For when they have been brought up in certain laws, which by some Divine Providence have remained unchanged during long ages, so that no one has any memory or tradition of their ever having been otherwise than they are, then every one is afraid and ashamed to change that which is established.</div><div class="sentence"> The legislator must somehow find a way of implanting this reverence for antiquity, and I would propose the following way:  People are apt to fancy, as I was saying before, that when the plays of children are altered they are merely plays, not seeing that the most serious and detrimental consequences arise out of the change; and they readily comply with the child's wishes instead of deterring him, not considering that these children who make innovations in their games, when they grow up to be men, will be different from the last generation of children, and, being different, will desire a different sort of life, and under the influence of this desire will want other institutions and laws; and no one of them reflects that there will follow what I just now called the greatest of evils to states.</div><div class="sentence"> Changes in bodily fashions are no such serious evils, but frequent changes in the praise and censure of manners are the greatest of evils, and require the utmost prevision.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">076</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To be sure.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">077</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And now do we still hold to our former assertion, that rhythms and music in general are imitations of good and evil characters in men?</div><div class="sentence"> What say you?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">078</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That is the only doctrine which we can admit.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">079</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Must we not, then, try in every possible way to prevent our youth from even desiring to imitate new modes either in dance or song?</div><div class="sentence"> nor must any one be allowed to offer them varieties of pleasures.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">080</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Most true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">081</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Can any of us imagine a better mode of effecting this object than that of the Egyptians?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">082</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What is their method?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">083</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  To consecrate every sort of dance or melody.</div><div class="sentence"> First we should ordain festivals—calculating for the year what they ought to be, and at what time, and in honour of what Gods, sons of Gods, and heroes they ought to be celebrated; and, in the next place, what hymns ought to be sung at the several sacrifices, and with what dances the particular festival is to be honoured.</div><div class="sentence"> This has to be arranged at first by certain persons, and, when arranged, the whole assembly of the citizens are to offer sacrifices and libations to the Fates and all the other Gods, and to consecrate the several odes to Gods and heroes:  and if any one offers any other hymns or dances to any one of the Gods, the priests and priestesses, acting in concert with the guardians of the law, shall, with the sanction of religion and the law, exclude him, and he who is excluded, if he do not submit, shall be liable all his life long to have a suit of impiety brought against him by any one who likes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">084</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very good.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">085</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In the consideration of this subject, let us remember what is due to ourselves.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">086</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To what are you referring?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">087</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I mean that any young man, and much more any old one, when he sees or hears anything strange or unaccustomed, does not at once run to embrace the paradox, but he stands considering, like a person who is at a place where three paths meet, and does not very well know his way—he may be alone or he may be walking with others, and he will say to himself and them, 'Which is the way?'</div><div class="sentence"> and will not move forward until he is satisfied that he is going right.</div><div class="sentence"> And this is what we must do in the present instance:  A strange discussion on the subject of law has arisen, which requires the utmost consideration, and we should not at our age be too ready to speak about such great matters, or be confident that we can say anything certain all in a moment.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">088</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Most true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">089</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then we will allow time for reflection, and decide when we have given the subject sufficient consideration.</div><div class="sentence"> But that we may not be hindered from completing the natural arrangement of our laws, let us proceed to the conclusion of them in due order; for very possibly, if God will, the exposition of them, when completed, may throw light on our present perplexity.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">090</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Excellent, Stranger; let us do as you propose.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">091</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us then affirm the paradox that strains of music are our laws (nomoi), and this latter being the name which the ancients gave to lyric songs, they probably would not have very much objected to our proposed application of the word.</div><div class="sentence"> Some one, either asleep or awake, must have had a dreamy suspicion of their nature.</div><div class="sentence"> And let our decree be as follows:  No one in singing or dancing shall offend against public and consecrated models, and the general fashion among the youth, any more than he would offend against any other law.</div><div class="sentence"> And he who observes this law shall be blameless; but he who is disobedient, as I was saying, shall be punished by the guardians of the laws, and by the priests and priestesses.</div><div class="sentence"> Suppose that we imagine this to be our law.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">092</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very good.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">093</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Can any one who makes such laws escape ridicule?</div><div class="sentence"> Let us see.</div><div class="sentence"> I think that our only safety will be in first framing certain models for composers.</div><div class="sentence"> One of these models shall be as follows:  If when a sacrifice is going on, and the victims are being burnt according to law—if, I say, any one who may be a son or brother, standing by another at the altar and over the victims, horribly blasphemes, will not his words inspire despondency and evil omens and forebodings in the mind of his father and of his other kinsmen?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">094</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Of course.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">095</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And this is just what takes place in almost all our cities.</div><div class="sentence"> A magistrate offers a public sacrifice, and there come in not one but many choruses, who take up a position a little way from the altar, and from time to time pour forth all sorts of horrible blasphemies on the sacred rites, exciting the souls of the audience with words and rhythms and melodies most sorrowful to hear; and he who at the moment when the city is offering sacrifice makes the citizens weep most, carries away the palm of victory.</div><div class="sentence"> Now, ought we not to forbid such strains as these?</div><div class="sentence"> And if ever our citizens must hear such lamentations, then on some unblest and inauspicious day let there be choruses of foreign and hired minstrels, like those hirelings who accompany the departed at funerals with barbarous Carian chants.</div><div class="sentence"> That is the sort of thing which will be appropriate if we have such strains at all; and let the apparel of the singers be, not circlets and ornaments of gold, but the reverse.</div><div class="sentence"> Enough of all this.</div><div class="sentence"> I will simply ask once more whether we shall lay down as one of our principles of song—</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">096</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">097</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  That we should avoid every word of evil omen; let that kind of song which is of good omen be heard everywhere and always in our state.</div><div class="sentence"> I need hardly ask again, but shall assume that you agree with me.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">098</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  By all means; that law is approved by the suffrages of us all.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">099</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But what shall be our next musical law or type?</div><div class="sentence"> Ought not prayers to be offered up to the Gods when we sacrifice?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">100</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">101</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And our third law, if I am not mistaken, will be to the effect that our poets, understanding prayers to be requests which we make to the Gods, will take especial heed that they do not by mistake ask for evil instead of good.</div><div class="sentence"> To make such a prayer would surely be too ridiculous.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">102</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">103</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Were we not a little while ago quite convinced that no silver or golden Plutus should dwell in our state?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">104</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To be sure.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">105</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And what has it been the object of our argument to show?</div><div class="sentence"> Did we not imply that the poets are not always quite capable of knowing what is good or evil?</div><div class="sentence"> And if one of them utters a mistaken prayer in song or words, he will make our citizens pray for the opposite of what is good in matters of the highest import; than which, as I was saying, there can be few greater mistakes.</div><div class="sentence"> Shall we then propose as one of our laws and models relating to the Muses—</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">106</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What?</div><div class="sentence"> will you explain the law more precisely?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">107</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Shall we make a law that the poet shall compose nothing contrary to the ideas of the lawful, or just, or beautiful, or good, which are allowed in the state?</div><div class="sentence"> nor shall he be permitted to communicate his compositions to any private individuals, until he shall have shown them to the appointed judges and the guardians of the law, and they are satisfied with them.</div><div class="sentence"> As to the persons whom we appoint to be our legislators about music and as to the director of education, these have been already indicated.</div><div class="sentence"> Once more then, as I have asked more than once, shall this be our third law, and type, and model—What do you say?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">108</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Let it be so, by all means.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">109</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then it will be proper to have hymns and praises of the Gods, intermingled with prayers; and after the Gods prayers and praises should be offered in like manner to demigods and heroes, suitable to their several characters.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">110</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">111</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In the next place there will be no objection to a law, that citizens who are departed and have done good and energetic deeds, either with their souls or with their bodies, and have been obedient to the laws, should receive eulogies; this will be very fitting.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">112</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Quite true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">113</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But to honour with hymns and panegyrics those who are still alive is not safe; a man should run his course, and make a fair ending, and then we will praise him; and let praise be given equally to women as well as men who have been distinguished in virtue.</div><div class="sentence"> The order of songs and dances shall be as follows:  There are many ancient musical compositions and dances which are excellent, and from these the newly-founded city may freely select what is proper and suitable; and they shall choose judges of not less than fifty years of age, who shall make the selection, and any of the old poems which they deem sufficient they shall include; any that are deficient or altogether unsuitable, they shall either utterly throw aside, or examine and amend, taking into their counsel poets and musicians, and making use of their poetical genius; but explaining to them the wishes of the legislator in order that they may regulate dancing, music, and all choral strains, according to the mind of the judges; and not allowing them to indulge, except in some few matters, their individual pleasures and fancies.</div><div class="sentence"> Now the irregular strain of music is always made ten thousand times better by attaining to law and order, and rejecting the honeyed Muse—not however that we mean wholly to exclude pleasure, which is the characteristic of all music.</div><div class="sentence"> And if a man be brought up from childhood to the age of discretion and maturity in the use of the orderly and severe music, when he hears the opposite he detests it, and calls it illiberal; but if trained in the sweet and vulgar music, he deems the severer kind cold and displeasing.</div><div class="sentence"> So that, as I was saying before, while he who hears them gains no more pleasure from the one than from the other, the one has the advantage of making those who are trained in it better men, whereas the other makes them worse.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">114</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">115</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Again, we must distinguish and determine on some general principle what songs are suitable to women, and what to men, and must assign to them their proper melodies and rhythms.</div><div class="sentence"> It is shocking for a whole harmony to be inharmonical, or for a rhythm to be unrhythmical, and this will happen when the melody is inappropriate to them.</div><div class="sentence"> And therefore the legislator must assign to these also their forms.</div><div class="sentence"> Now both sexes have melodies and rhythms which of necessity belong to them; and those of women are clearly enough indicated by their natural difference.</div><div class="sentence"> The grand, and that which tends to courage, may be fairly called manly; but that which inclines to moderation and temperance, may be declared both in law and in ordinary speech to be the more womanly quality.</div><div class="sentence"> This, then, will be the general order of them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">116</span> <div class="sentence">  Let us now speak of the manner of teaching and imparting them, and the persons to whom, and the time when, they are severally to be imparted.</div><div class="sentence"> As the shipwright first lays down the lines of the keel, and thus, as it were, draws the ship in outline, so do I seek to distinguish the patterns of life, and lay down their keels according to the nature of different men's souls; seeking truly to consider by what means, and in what ways, we may go through the voyage of life best.</div><div class="sentence"> Now human affairs are hardly worth considering in earnest, and yet we must be in earnest about them—a sad necessity constrains us.</div><div class="sentence"> And having got thus far, there will be a fitness in our completing the matter, if we can only find some suitable method of doing so.</div><div class="sentence"> But what do I mean?</div><div class="sentence"> Some one may ask this very question, and quite rightly, too.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">117</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">118</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I say that about serious matters a man should be serious, and about a matter which is not serious he should not be serious; and that God is the natural and worthy object of our most serious and blessed endeavours, for man, as I said before, is made to be the plaything of God, and this, truly considered, is the best of him; wherefore also every man and woman should walk seriously, and pass life in the noblest of pastimes, and be of another mind from what they are at present.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">119</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  In what respect?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">120</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  At present they think that their serious pursuits should be for the sake of their sports, for they deem war a serious pursuit, which must be managed well for the sake of peace; but the truth is, that there neither is, nor has been, nor ever will be, either amusement or instruction in any degree worth speaking of in war, which is nevertheless deemed by us to be the most serious of our pursuits.</div><div class="sentence"> And therefore, as we say, every one of us should live the life of peace as long and as well as he can.</div><div class="sentence"> And what is the right way of living?</div><div class="sentence"> Are we to live in sports always?</div><div class="sentence"> If so, in what kind of sports?</div><div class="sentence"> We ought to live sacrificing, and singing, and dancing, and then a man will be able to propitiate the Gods, and to defend himself against his enemies and conquer them in battle.</div><div class="sentence"> The type of song or dance by which he will propitiate them has been described, and the paths along which he is to proceed have been cut for him.</div><div class="sentence"> He will go forward in the spirit of the poet:</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">121</span> <div class="sentence">  'Telemachus, some things thou wilt thyself find in thy heart, but other things God will suggest; for I deem that thou wast not born or brought up without the will of the Gods.'</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">122</span> <div class="sentence">  And this ought to be the view of our alumni; they ought to think that what has been said is enough for them, and that any other things their Genius and God will suggest to them—he will tell them to whom, and when, and to what Gods severally they are to sacrifice and perform dances, and how they may propitiate the deities, and live according to the appointment of nature; being for the most part puppets, but having some little share of reality.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">123</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  You have a low opinion of mankind, Stranger.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">124</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Nay, Megillus, be not amazed, but forgive me:  I was comparing them with the Gods; and under that feeling I spoke.</div><div class="sentence"> Let us grant, if you wish, that the human race is not to be despised, but is worthy of some consideration.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">125</span> <div class="sentence">  Next follow the buildings for gymnasia and schools open to all; these are to be in three places in the midst of the city; and outside the city and in the surrounding country, also in three places, there shall be schools for horse exercise, and large grounds arranged with a view to archery and the throwing of missiles, at which young men may learn and practise.</div><div class="sentence"> Of these mention has already been made; and if the mention be not sufficiently explicit, let us speak further of them and embody them in laws.</div><div class="sentence"> In these several schools let there be dwellings for teachers, who shall be brought from foreign parts by pay, and let them teach those who attend the schools the art of war and the art of music, and the children shall come not only if their parents please, but if they do not please; there shall be compulsory education, as the saying is, of all and sundry, as far as this is possible; and the pupils shall be regarded as belonging to the state rather than to their parents.</div><div class="sentence"> My law would apply to females as well as males; they shall both go through the same exercises.</div><div class="sentence"> I assert without fear of contradiction that gymnastic and horsemanship are as suitable to women as to men.</div><div class="sentence"> Of the truth of this I am persuaded from ancient tradition, and at the present day there are said to be countless myriads of women in the neighbourhood of the Black Sea, called Sauromatides, who not only ride on horseback like men, but have enjoined upon them the use of bows and other weapons equally with the men.</div><div class="sentence"> And I further affirm, that if these things are possible, nothing can be more absurd than the practice which prevails in our own country, of men and women not following the same pursuits with all their strength and with one mind, for thus the state, instead of being a whole, is reduced to a half, but has the same imposts to pay and the same toils to undergo; and what can be a greater mistake for any legislator to make than this?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">126</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true; yet much of what has been asserted by us, Stranger, is contrary to the custom of states; still, in saying that the discourse should be allowed to proceed, and that when the discussion is completed, we should choose what seems best, you spoke very properly, and I now feel compunction for what I have said.</div><div class="sentence"> Tell me, then, what you would next wish to say.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">127</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I should wish to say, Cleinias, as I said before, that if the possibility of these things were not sufficiently proven in fact, then there might be an objection to the argument, but the fact being as I have said, he who rejects the law must find some other ground of objection; and, failing this, our exhortation will still hold good, nor will any one deny that women ought to share as far as possible in education and in other ways with men.</div><div class="sentence"> For consider; if women do not share in their whole life with men, then they must have some other order of life.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">128</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">129</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And what arrangement of life to be found anywhere is preferable to this community which we are now assigning to them?</div><div class="sentence"> Shall we prefer that which is adopted by the Thracians and many other races who use their women to till the ground and to be shepherds of their herds and flocks, and to minister to them like slaves?</div><div class="sentence"> Or shall we do as we and people in our part of the world do—getting together, as the phrase is, all our goods and chattels into one dwelling, we entrust them to our women, who are the stewards of them, and who also preside over the shuttles and the whole art of spinning?</div><div class="sentence"> Or shall we take a middle course, as in Lacedaemon, Megillus—letting the girls share in gymnastic and music, while the grown-up women, no longer employed in spinning wool, are hard at work weaving the web of life, which will be no cheap or mean employment, and in the duty of serving and taking care of the household and bringing up the children, in which they will observe a sort of mean, not participating in the toils of war; and if there were any necessity that they should fight for their city and families, unlike the Amazons, they would be unable to take part in archery or any other skilled use of missiles, nor could they, after the example of the Goddess, carry shield or spear, or stand up nobly for their country when it was being destroyed, and strike terror into their enemies, if only because they were seen in regular order?</div><div class="sentence"> Living as they do, they would never dare at all to imitate the Sauromatides, who, when compared with ordinary women, would appear to be like men.</div><div class="sentence"> Let him who will, praise your legislators, but I must say what I think.</div><div class="sentence"> The legislator ought to be whole and perfect, and not half a man only; he ought not to let the female sex live softly and waste money and have no order of life, while he takes the utmost care of the male sex, and leaves half of life only blest with happiness, when he might have made the whole state happy.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">130</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  What shall we do, Cleinias?</div><div class="sentence"> Shall we allow a stranger to run down Sparta in this fashion?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">131</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes; for as we have given him liberty of speech we must let him go on until we have perfected the work of legislation.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">132</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">133</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then now I may proceed?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">134</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  By all means.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">135</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  What will be the manner of life among men who may be supposed to have their food and clothing provided for them in moderation, and who have entrusted the practice of the arts to others, and whose husbandry committed to slaves paying a part of the produce, brings them a return sufficient for men living temperately; who, moreover, have common tables in which the men are placed apart, and near them are the common tables of their families, of their daughters and mothers, which day by day, the officers, male and female, are to inspect—they shall see to the behaviour of the company, and so dismiss them; after which the presiding magistrate and his attendants shall honour with libations those Gods to whom that day and night are dedicated, and then go home?</div><div class="sentence"> To men whose lives are thus ordered, is there no work remaining to be done which is necessary and fitting, but shall each one of them live fattening like a beast?</div><div class="sentence"> Such a life is neither just nor honourable, nor can he who lives it fail of meeting his due;
