and that is the highest of which you now think nothing—to know the Gods rightly and to live accordingly.</div><div class="sentence"> And in the first place let me indicate to you one point which is of great importance, and about which I cannot be deceived:  You and your friends are not the first who have held this opinion about the Gods.</div><div class="sentence"> There have always been persons more or less numerous who have had the same disorder.</div><div class="sentence"> I have known many of them, and can tell you, that no one who had taken up in youth this opinion, that the Gods do not exist, ever continued in the same until he was old; the two other notions certainly do continue in some cases, but not in many; the notion, I mean, that the Gods exist, but take no heed of human things, and the other notion that they do take heed of them, but are easily propitiated with sacrifices and prayers.</div><div class="sentence"> As to the opinion about the Gods which may some day become clear to you, I advise you to wait and consider if it be true or not; ask of others, and above all of the legislator.</div><div class="sentence"> In the meantime take care that you do not offend against the Gods.</div><div class="sentence"> For the duty of the legislator is and always will be to teach you the truth of these matters.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">020</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Our address, Stranger, thus far, is excellent.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">021</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Quite true, Megillus and Cleinias, but I am afraid that we have unconsciously lighted on a strange doctrine.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">022</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What doctrine do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">023</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The wisest of all doctrines, in the opinion of many.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">024</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I wish that you would speak plainer.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">025</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The doctrine that all things do become, have become, and will become, some by nature, some by art, and some by chance.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">026</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Is not that true?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">027</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, philosophers are probably right; at any rate we may as well follow in their track, and examine what is the meaning of them and their disciples.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">028</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  By all means.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">029</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  They say that the greatest and fairest things are the work of nature and of chance, the lesser of art, which, receiving from nature the greater and primeval creations, moulds and fashions all those lesser works which are generally termed artificial.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">030</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How is that?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">031</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I will explain my meaning still more clearly.</div><div class="sentence"> They say that fire and water, and earth and air, all exist by nature and chance, and none of them by art, and that as to the bodies which come next in order—earth, and sun, and moon, and stars—they have been created by means of these absolutely inanimate existences.</div><div class="sentence"> The elements are severally moved by chance and some inherent force according to certain affinities among them—of hot with cold, or of dry with moist, or of soft with hard, and according to all the other accidental admixtures of opposites which have been formed by necessity.</div><div class="sentence"> After this fashion and in this manner the whole heaven has been created, and all that is in the heaven, as well as animals and all plants, and all the seasons come from these elements, not by the action of mind, as they say, or of any God, or from art, but as I was saying, by nature and chance only.</div><div class="sentence"> Art sprang up afterwards and out of these, mortal and of mortal birth, and produced in play certain images and very partial imitations of the truth, having an affinity to one another, such as music and painting create and their companion arts.</div><div class="sentence"> And there are other arts which have a serious purpose, and these co-operate with nature, such, for example, as medicine, and husbandry, and gymnastic.</div><div class="sentence"> And they say that politics co-operate with nature, but in a less degree, and have more of art; also that legislation is entirely a work of art, and is based on assumptions which are not true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">032</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">033</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In the first place, my dear friend, these people would say that the Gods exist not by nature, but by art, and by the laws of states, which are different in different places, according to the agreement of those who make them; and that the honourable is one thing by nature and another thing by law, and that the principles of justice have no existence at all in nature, but that mankind are always disputing about them and altering them; and that the alterations which are made by art and by law have no basis in nature, but are of authority for the moment and at the time at which they are made.</div><div class="sentence"> These, my friends, are the sayings of wise men, poets and prose writers, which find a way into the minds of youth.</div><div class="sentence"> They are told by them that the highest right is might, and in this way the young fall into impieties, under the idea that the Gods are not such as the law bids them imagine; and hence arise factions, these philosophers inviting them to lead a true life according to nature, that is, to live in real dominion over others, and not in legal subjection to them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">034</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What a dreadful picture, Stranger, have you given, and how great is the injury which is thus inflicted on young men to the ruin both of states and families!</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">035</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  True, Cleinias; but then what should the lawgiver do when this evil is of long standing?</div><div class="sentence"> should he only rise up in the state and threaten all mankind, proclaiming that if they will not say and think that the Gods are such as the law ordains (and this may be extended generally to the honourable, the just, and to all the highest things, and to all that relates to virtue and vice), and if they will not make their actions conform to the copy which the law gives them, then he who refuses to obey the law shall die, or suffer stripes and bonds, or privation of citizenship, or in some cases be punished by loss of property and exile?</div><div class="sentence"> Should he not rather, when he is making laws for men, at the same time infuse the spirit of persuasion into his words, and mitigate the severity of them as far as he can?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">036</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Why, Stranger, if such persuasion be at all possible, then a legislator who has anything in him ought never to weary of persuading men; he ought to leave nothing unsaid in support of the ancient opinion that there are Gods, and of all those other truths which you were just now mentioning; he ought to support the law and also art, and acknowledge that both alike exist by nature, and no less than nature, if they are the creations of mind in accordance with right reason, as you appear to me to maintain, and I am disposed to agree with you in thinking.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">037</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, my enthusiastic Cleinias; but are not these things when spoken to a multitude hard to be understood, not to mention that they take up a dismal length of time?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">038</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Why, Stranger, shall we, whose patience failed not when drinking or music were the themes of discourse, weary now of discoursing about the Gods, and about divine things?</div><div class="sentence"> And the greatest help to rational legislation is that the laws when once written down are always at rest; they can be put to the test at any future time, and therefore, if on first hearing they seem difficult, there is no reason for apprehension about them, because any man however dull can go over them and consider them again and again; nor if they are tedious but useful, is there any reason or religion, as it seems to me, in any man refusing to maintain the principles of them to the utmost of his power.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">039</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Stranger, I like what Cleinias is saying.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">040</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, Megillus, and we should do as he proposes; for if impious discourses were not scattered, as I may say, throughout the world, there would have been no need for any vindication of the existence of the Gods—but seeing that they are spread far and wide, such arguments are needed; and who should come to the rescue of the greatest laws, when they are being undermined by bad men, but the legislator himself?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">041</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  There is no more proper champion of them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">042</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, then, tell me, Cleinias—for I must ask you to be my partner—does not he who talks in this way conceive fire and water and earth and air to be the first elements of all things?</div><div class="sentence"> these he calls nature, and out of these he supposes the soul to be formed afterwards; and this is not a mere conjecture of ours about his meaning, but is what he really means.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">043</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">044</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then, by Heaven, we have discovered the source of this vain opinion of all those physical investigators; and I would have you examine their arguments with the utmost care, for their impiety is a very serious matter; they not only make a bad and mistaken use of argument, but they lead away the minds of others:  that is my opinion of them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">045</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You are right; but I should like to know how this happens.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">046</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I fear that the argument may seem singular.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">047</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Do not hesitate, Stranger; I see that you are afraid of such a discussion carrying you beyond the limits of legislation.</div><div class="sentence"> But if there be no other way of showing our agreement in the belief that there are Gods, of whom the law is said now to approve, let us take this way, my good sir.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">048</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then I suppose that I must repeat the singular argument of those who manufacture the soul according to their own impious notions; they affirm that which is the first cause of the generation and destruction of all things, to be not first, but last, and that which is last to be first, and hence they have fallen into error about the true nature of the Gods.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">049</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Still I do not understand you.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">050</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Nearly all of them, my friends, seem to be ignorant of the nature and power of the soul, especially in what relates to her origin:  they do not know that she is among the first of things, and before all bodies, and is the chief author of their changes and transpositions.</div><div class="sentence"> And if this is true, and if the soul is older than the body, must not the things which are of the soul's kindred be of necessity prior to those which appertain to the body?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">051</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">052</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then thought and attention and mind and art and law will be prior to that which is hard and soft and heavy and light; and the great and primitive works and actions will be works of art; they will be the first, and after them will come nature and works of nature, which however is a wrong term for men to apply to them; these will follow, and will be under the government of art and mind.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">053</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  But why is the word 'nature' wrong?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">054</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Because those who use the term mean to say that nature is the first creative power; but if the soul turn out to be the primeval element, and not fire or air, then in the truest sense and beyond other things the soul may be said to exist by nature; and this would be true if you proved that the soul is older than the body, but not otherwise.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">055</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You are quite right.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">056</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Shall we, then, take this as the next point to which our attention should be directed?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">057</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  By all means.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">058</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us be on our guard lest this most deceptive argument with its youthful looks, beguiling us old men, give us the slip and make a laughing-stock of us.</div><div class="sentence"> Who knows but we may be aiming at the greater, and fail of attaining the lesser?</div><div class="sentence"> Suppose that we three have to pass a rapid river, and I, being the youngest of the three and experienced in rivers, take upon me the duty of making the attempt first by myself; leaving you in safety on the bank, I am to examine whether the river is passable by older men like yourselves, and if such appears to be the case then I shall invite you to follow, and my experience will help to convey you across; but if the river is impassable by you, then there will have been no danger to anybody but myself—would not that seem to be a very fair proposal?</div><div class="sentence"> I mean to say that the argument in prospect is likely to be too much for you, out of your depth and beyond your strength, and I should be afraid that the stream of my questions might create in you who are not in the habit of answering, giddiness and confusion of mind, and hence a feeling of unpleasantness and unsuitableness might arise.</div><div class="sentence"> I think therefore that I had better first ask the questions and then answer them myself while you listen in safety; in that way I can carry on the argument until I have completed the proof that the soul is prior to the body.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">059</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Excellent, Stranger, and I hope that you will do as you propose.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">060</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Come, then, and if ever we are to call upon the Gods, let us call upon them now in all seriousness to come to the demonstration of their own existence.</div><div class="sentence"> And so holding fast to the rope we will venture upon the depths of the argument.</div><div class="sentence"> When questions of this sort are asked of me, my safest answer would appear to be as follows:  Some one says to me, 'O Stranger, are all things at rest and nothing in motion, or is the exact opposite of this true, or are some things in motion and others at rest?'</div><div class="sentence"> To this I shall reply that some things are in motion and others at rest.</div><div class="sentence"> 'And do not things which move move in a place, and are not the things which are at rest at rest in a place?'</div><div class="sentence"> Certainly.</div><div class="sentence"> 'And some move or rest in one place and some in more places than one?'</div><div class="sentence"> You mean to say, we shall rejoin, that those things which rest at the centre move in one place, just as the circumference goes round of globes which are said to be at rest?</div><div class="sentence"> 'Yes.'</div><div class="sentence"> And we observe that, in the revolution, the motion which carries round the larger and the lesser circle at the same time is proportionally distributed to greater and smaller, and is greater and smaller in a certain proportion.</div><div class="sentence"> Here is a wonder which might be thought an impossibility, that the same motion should impart swiftness and slowness in due proportion to larger and lesser circles.</div><div class="sentence"> 'Very true.'</div><div class="sentence"> And when you speak of bodies moving in many places, you seem to me to mean those which move from one place to another, and sometimes have one centre of motion and sometimes more than one because they turn upon their axis; and whenever they meet anything, if it be stationary, they are divided by it; but if they get in the midst between bodies which are approaching and moving towards the same spot from opposite directions, they unite with them.</div><div class="sentence"> 'I admit the truth of what you are saying.'</div><div class="sentence"> Also when they unite they grow, and when they are divided they waste away—that is, supposing the constitution of each to remain, or if that fails, then there is a second reason of their dissolution.</div><div class="sentence"> 'And when are all things created and how?'</div><div class="sentence"> Clearly, they are created when the first principle receives increase and attains to the second dimension, and from this arrives at the one which is neighbour to this, and after reaching the third becomes perceptible to sense.</div><div class="sentence"> Everything which is thus changing and moving is in process of generation; only when at rest has it real existence, but when passing into another state it is destroyed utterly.</div><div class="sentence"> Have we not mentioned all motions that there are, and comprehended them under their kinds and numbered them with the exception, my friends, of two?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">061</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Which are they?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">062</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Just the two, with which our present enquiry is concerned.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">063</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Speak plainer.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">064</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I suppose that our enquiry has reference to the soul?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">065</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">066</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us assume that there is a motion able to move other things, but not to move itself; that is one kind; and there is another kind which can move itself as well as other things, working in composition and decomposition, by increase and diminution and generation and destruction—that is also one of the many kinds of motion.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">067</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Granted.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">068</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And we will assume that which moves other, and is changed by other, to be the ninth, and that which changes itself and others, and is coincident with every action and every passion, and is the true principle of change and motion in all that is—that we shall be inclined to call the tenth.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">069</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">070</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And which of these ten motions ought we to prefer as being the mightiest and most efficient?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">071</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I must say that the motion which is able to move itself is ten thousand times superior to all the others.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">072</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Very good; but may I make one or two corrections in what I have been saying?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">073</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What are they?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">074</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  When I spoke of the tenth sort of motion, that was not quite correct.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">075</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What was the error?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">076</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  According to the true order, the tenth was really the first in generation and power; then follows the second, which was strangely enough termed the ninth by us.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">077</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">078</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I mean this:  when one thing changes another, and that another, of such will there be any primary changing element?</div><div class="sentence"> How can a thing which is moved by another ever be the beginning of change?</div><div class="sentence"> Impossible.</div><div class="sentence"> But when the self-moved changes other, and that again other, and thus thousands upon tens of thousands of bodies are set in motion, must not the beginning of all this motion be the change of the self-moving principle?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">079</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true, and I quite agree.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">080</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Or, to put the question in another way, making answer to ourselves:  If, as most of these philosophers have the audacity to affirm, all things were at rest in one mass, which of the above-mentioned principles of motion would first spring up among them?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">081</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Clearly the self-moving; for there could be no change in them arising out of any external cause; the change must first take place in themselves.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">082</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then we must say that self-motion being the origin of all motions, and the first which arises among things at rest as well as among things in motion, is the eldest and mightiest principle of change, and that which is changed by another and yet moves other is second.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">083</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Quite true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">084</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  At this stage of the argument let us put a question.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">085</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What question?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">086</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  If we were to see this power existing in any earthy, watery, or fiery substance, simple or compound—how should we describe it?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">087</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You mean to ask whether we should call such a self-moving power life?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">088</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I do.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">089</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly we should.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">090</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And when we see soul in anything, must we not do the same—must we not admit that this is life?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">091</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  We must.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">092</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And now, I beseech you, reflect—you would admit that we have a threefold knowledge of things?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">093</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">094</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I mean that we know the essence, and that we know the definition of the essence, and the name—these are the three; and there are two questions which may be raised about anything.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">095</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How two?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">096</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Sometimes a person may give the name and ask the definition; or he may give the definition and ask the name.</div><div class="sentence"> I may illustrate what I mean in this way.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">097</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">098</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Number like some other things is capable of being divided into equal parts; when thus divided, number is named 'even,' and the definition of the name 'even' is 'number divisible into two equal parts'?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">099</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">100</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I mean, that when we are asked about the definition and give the name, or when we are asked about the name and give the definition—in either case, whether we give name or definition, we speak of the same thing, calling 'even' the number which is divided into two equal parts.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">101</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Quite true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">102</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And what is the definition of that which is named 'soul'?</div><div class="sentence"> Can we conceive of any other than that which has been already given—the motion which can move itself?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">103</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You mean to say that the essence which is defined as the self-moved is the same with that which has the name soul?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">104</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes; and if this is true, do we still maintain that there is anything wanting in the proof that the soul is the first origin and moving power of all that is, or has become, or will be, and their contraries, when she has been clearly shown to be the source of change and motion in all things?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">105</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly not; the soul as being the source of motion, has been most satisfactorily shown to be the oldest of all things.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">106</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And is not that motion which is produced in another, by reason of another, but never has any self-moving power at all, being in truth the change of an inanimate body, to be reckoned second, or by any lower number which you may prefer?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">107</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Exactly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">108</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then we are right, and speak the most perfect and absolute truth, when we say that the soul is prior to the body, and that the body is second and comes afterwards, and is born to obey the soul, which is the ruler?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">109</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Nothing can be more true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">110</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Do you remember our old admission, that if the soul was prior to the body the things of the soul were also prior to those of the body?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">111</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">112</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then characters and manners, and wishes and reasonings, and true opinions, and reflections, and recollections are prior to length and breadth and depth and strength of bodies, if the soul is prior to the body.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">113</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To be sure.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">114</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In the next place, we must not of necessity admit that the soul is the cause of good and evil, base and honourable, just and unjust, and of all other opposites, if we suppose her to be the cause of all things?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">115</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  We must.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">116</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And as the soul orders and inhabits all things that move, however moving, must we not say that she orders also the heavens?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">117</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Of course.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">118</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  One soul or more?</div><div class="sentence"> More than one—I will answer for you; at any rate, we must not suppose that there are less than two—one the author of good, and the other of evil.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">119</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">120</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, very true; the soul then directs all things in heaven, and earth, and sea by her movements, and these are described by the terms—will, consideration, attention, deliberation, opinion true and false, joy and sorrow, confidence, fear, hatred, love, and other primary motions akin to these; which again receive the secondary motions of corporeal substances, and guide all things to growth and decay, to composition and decomposition, and to the qualities which accompany them, such as heat and cold, heaviness and lightness, hardness and softness, blackness and whiteness, bitterness and sweetness, and all those other qualities which the soul uses, herself a goddess, when truly receiving the divine mind she disciplines all things rightly to their happiness; but when she is the companion of folly, she does the very contrary of all this.</div><div class="sentence"> Shall we assume so much, or do we still entertain doubts?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">121</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  There is no room at all for doubt.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">122</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Shall we say then that it is the soul which controls heaven and earth, and the whole world?</div><div class="sentence"> that it is a principle of wisdom and virtue, or a principle which has neither wisdom nor virtue?</div><div class="sentence"> Suppose that we make answer as follows:</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">123</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How would you answer?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">124</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  If, my friend, we say that the whole path and movement of heaven, and of all that is therein, is by nature akin to the movement and revolution and calculation of mind, and proceeds by kindred laws, then, as is plain, we must say that the best soul takes care of the world and guides it along the good path.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">125</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">126</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But if the world moves wildly and irregularly, then the evil soul guides it.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">127</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True again.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">128</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Of what nature is the movement of mind?</div><div class="sentence"> To this question it is not easy to give an intelligent answer; and therefore I ought to assist you in framing one.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">129</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very good.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">130</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then let us not answer as if we would look straight at the sun, making ourselves darkness at midday—I mean as if we were under the impression that we could see with mortal eyes, or know adequately the nature of mind—it will be safer to look at the image only.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">131</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">132</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us select of the ten motions the one which mind chiefly resembles; this I will bring to your recollection, and will then make the answer on behalf of us all.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">133</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That will be excellent.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">134</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  You will surely remember our saying that all things were either at rest or in motion?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">135</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I do.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">136</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And that of things in motion some were moving in one place, and others in more than one?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">137</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">138</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Of these two kinds of motion, that which moves in one place must move about a centre like globes made in a lathe, and is most entirely akin and similar to the circular movement of mind.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">139</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">140</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In saying that both mind and the motion which is in one place move in the same and like manner, in and about the same, and in relation to the same, and according to one proportion and order, and are like the motion of a globe, we invented a fair image, which does no discredit to our ingenuity.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">141</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  It does us great credit.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">142</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And the motion of the other sort which is not after the same manner, nor in the same, nor about the same, nor in relation to the same, nor in one place, nor in order, nor according to any rule or proportion, may be said to be akin to senselessness and folly?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">143</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That is most true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">144</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then, after what has been said, there is no difficulty in distinctly stating, that since soul carries all things round, either the best soul or the contrary must of necessity carry round and order and arrange the revolution of the heaven.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">145</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  And judging from what has been said, Stranger, there would be impiety in asserting that any but the most perfect soul or souls carries round the heavens.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">146</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  You have understood my meaning right well, Cleinias, and now let me ask you another question.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">147</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What are you going to ask?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">148</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  If the soul carries round the sun and moon, and the other stars, does she not carry round each individual of them?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">149</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">150</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then of one of them let us speak, and the same argument will apply to all.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">151</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Which will you take?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">152</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Every one sees the body of the sun, but no one sees his soul, nor the soul of any other body living or dead; and yet there is great reason to believe that this nature, unperceived by any of our senses, is circumfused around them all, but is perceived by mind; and therefore by mind and reflection only let us apprehend the following point.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">153</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What is that?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">154</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  If the soul carries round the sun, we shall not be far wrong in supposing one of three alternatives.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">155</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What are they?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">156</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Either the soul which moves the sun this way and that, resides within the circular and visible body, like the soul which carries us about every way; or the soul provides herself with an external body of fire or air, as some affirm, and violently propels body by body; or thirdly, she is without such a body, but guides the sun by some extraordinary and wonderful power.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">157</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, certainly; the soul can only order all things in one of these three ways.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">158</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And this soul of the sun, which is therefore better than the sun, whether taking the sun about in a chariot to give light to men, or acting from without, or in whatever way, ought by every man to be deemed a God.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">159</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, by every man who has the least particle of sense.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">160</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And of the stars too, and of the moon, and of the years and months and seasons, must we not say in like manner, that since a soul or souls having every sort of excellence are the causes of all of them, those souls are Gods, whether they are living beings and reside in bodies, and in this way order the whole heaven, or whatever be the place and mode of their existence—and will any one who admits all this venture to deny that all things are full of Gods?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">161</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  No one, Stranger, would be such a madman.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">162</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And now, Megillus and Cleinias, let us offer terms to him who has hitherto denied the existence of the Gods, and leave him.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">163</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What terms?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">164</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Either he shall teach us that we were wrong in saying that the soul is the original of all things, and arguing accordingly; or, if he be not able to say anything better, then he must yield to us and live for the remainder of his life in the belief that there are Gods.</div><div class="sentence"> Let us see, then, whether we have said enough or not enough to those who deny that there are Gods.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">165</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly, quite enough, Stranger.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">166</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then to them we will say no more.</div><div class="sentence"> And now we are to address him who, believing that there are Gods, believes also that they take no heed of human affairs:  To him we say—O thou best of men, in believing that there are Gods you are led by some affinity to them, which attracts you towards your kindred and makes you honour and believe in them.</div><div class="sentence"> But the fortunes of evil and unrighteous men in private as well as public life, which, though not really happy, are wrongly counted happy in the judgment of men, and are celebrated both by poets and prose writers—these draw you aside from your natural piety.</div><div class="sentence"> Perhaps you have seen impious men growing old and leaving their children's children in high offices, and their prosperity shakes your faith—you have known or heard or been yourself an eyewitness of many monstrous impieties, and have beheld men by such criminal means from small beginnings attaining to sovereignty and the pinnacle of greatness; and considering all these things you do not like to accuse the Gods of them, because they are your relatives; and so from some want of reasoning power, and also from an unwillingness to find fault with them, you have come to believe that they exist indeed, but have no thought or care of human things.</div><div class="sentence"> Now, that your present evil opinion may not grow to still greater impiety, and that we may if possible use arguments which may conjure away the evil before it arrives, we will add another argument to that originally addressed to him who utterly denied the existence of the Gods.</div><div class="sentence"> And do you, Megillus and Cleinias, answer for the young man as you did before; and if any impediment comes in our way, I will take the word out of your mouths, and carry you over the river as I did just now.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">167</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very good; do as you say, and we will help you as well as we can.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">168</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There will probably be no difficulty in proving to him that the Gods care about the small as well as about the great.</div><div class="sentence"> For he was present and heard what was said, that they are perfectly good, and that the care of all things is most entirely natural to them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">169</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  No doubt he heard that.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">170</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us consider together in the next place what we mean by this virtue which we ascribe to them.</div><div class="sentence"> Surely we should say that to be temperate and to possess mind belongs to virtue, and the contrary to vice?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">171</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">172</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes; and courage is a part of virtue, and cowardice of vice?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">173</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">174</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And the one is honourable, and the other dishonourable?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">175</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  To be sure.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">176</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And the one, like other meaner things, is a human quality, but the Gods have no part in anything of the sort?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">177</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That again is what everybody will admit.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">178</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But do we imagine carelessness and idleness and luxury to be virtues?</div><div class="sentence"> What do you think?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">179</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Decidedly not.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">180</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  They rank under the opposite class?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">181</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">182</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And their opposites, therefore, would fall under the opposite class?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">183</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">184</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But are we to suppose that one who possesses all these good qualities will be luxurious and heedless and idle, like those whom the poet compares to stingless drones?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">185</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  And the comparison is a most just one.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">186</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Surely God must not be supposed to have a nature which He Himself hates?</div><div class="sentence"> he who dares to say this sort of thing must not be tolerated for a moment.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">187</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Of course not.</div><div class="sentence"> How could he have?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">188</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Should we not on any principle be entirely mistaken in praising any one who has some special business entrusted to him, if he have a mind which takes care of great matters and no care of small ones?</div><div class="sentence"> Reflect; he who acts in this way, whether he be God or man, must act from one of two principles.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">189</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What are they?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">190</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Either he must think that the neglect of the small matters is of no consequence to the whole, or if he knows that they are of consequence, and he neglects them, his neglect must be attributed to carelessness and indolence.</div><div class="sentence"> Is there any other way in which his neglect can be explained?</div><div class="sentence"> For surely, when it is impossible for him to take care of all, he is not negligent if he fails to attend to these things great or small, which a God or some inferior being might be wanting in strength or capacity to manage?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">191</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly not.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">192</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Now, then, let us examine the offenders, who both alike confess that there are Gods, but with a difference—the one saying that they may be appeased, and the other that they have no care of small matters:  there are three of us and two of them, and we will say to them—In the first place, you both acknowledge that the Gods hear and see and know all things, and that nothing can escape them which is matter of sense and knowledge:  do you admit this?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">193</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">194</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And do you admit also that they have all power which mortals and immortals can have?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">195</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  They will, of course, admit this also.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">196</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And surely we three and they two—five in all—have acknowledged that they are good and perfect?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">197</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Assuredly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">198</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But, if they are such as we conceive them to be, can we possibly suppose that they ever act in the spirit of carelessness and indolence?</div><div class="sentence"> For in us inactivity is the child of cowardice, and carelessness of inactivity and indolence.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">199</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Most true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">200</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then not from inactivity and carelessness is any God ever negligent; for there is no cowardice in them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">201</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That is very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">202</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then the alternative which remains is, that if the Gods neglect the lighter and lesser concerns of the universe, they neglect them because they know that they ought not to care about such matters—what other alternative is there but the opposite of their knowing?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">203</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  There is none.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">204</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And, O most excellent and best of men, do I understand you to mean that they are careless because they are ignorant, and do not know that they ought to take care, or that they know, and yet like the meanest sort of men, knowing the better, choose the worse because they are overcome by pleasures and pains?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">205</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Impossible.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">206</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Do not all human things partake of the nature of soul?</div><div class="sentence"> And is not man the most religious of all animals?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">207</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That is not to be denied.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">208</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And we acknowledge that all mortal creatures are the property of the Gods, to whom also the whole of heaven belongs?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">209</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">210</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And, therefore, whether a person says that these things are to the Gods great or small—in either case it would not be natural for the Gods who own us, and who are the most careful and the best of owners, to neglect us.</div><div class="sentence"> There is also a further consideration.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">211</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What is it?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">212</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Sensation and power are in an inverse ratio to each other in respect to their ease and difficulty.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">213</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">214</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I mean that there is greater difficulty in seeing and hearing the small than the great, but more facility in moving and controlling and taking care of small and unimportant things than of their opposites.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">215</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Far more.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">216</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Suppose the case of a physician who is willing and able to cure some living thing as a whole—how will the whole fare at his hands if he takes care only of the greater and neglects the parts which are lesser?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">217</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Decidedly not well.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">218</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  No better would be the result with pilots or generals, or householders or statesmen, or any other such class, if they neglected the small and regarded only the great—as the builders say, the larger stones do not lie well without the lesser.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">219</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Of course not.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">220</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us not, then, deem God inferior to human workmen, who, in proportion to their skill, finish and perfect their works, small as well as great, by one and the same art; or that God, the wisest of beings, who is both willing and able to take care, is like a lazy good-for-nothing, or a coward, who turns his back upon labour and gives no thought to smaller and easier matters, but to the greater only.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">221</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Never, Stranger, let us admit a supposition about the Gods which is both impious and false.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">222</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I think that we have now argued enough with him who delights to accuse the Gods of neglect.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">223</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">224</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  He has been forced to acknowledge that he is in error, but he still seems to me to need some words of consolation.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">225</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What consolation will you offer him?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">226</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us say to the youth:  The ruler of the universe has ordered all things with a view to the excellence and preservation of the whole, and each part, as far as may be, has an action and passion appropriate to it.</div><div class="sentence"> Over these, down to the least fraction of them, ministers have been appointed to preside, who have wrought out their perfection with infinitesimal exactness.</div><div class="sentence"> And one of these portions of the universe is thine own, unhappy man, which, however little, contributes to the whole; and you do not seem to be aware that this and every other creation is for the sake of the whole, and in order that the life of the whole may be blessed; and that you are created for the sake of the whole, and not the whole for the sake of you.</div><div class="sentence"> For every physician and every skilled artist does all things for the sake of the whole, directing his effort towards the common good, executing the part for the sake of the whole, and not the whole for the sake of the part.</div><div class="sentence"> And you are annoyed because you are ignorant how what is best for you happens to you and to the universe, as far as the laws of the common creation admit.</div><div class="sentence"> Now, as the soul combining first with one body and then with another undergoes all sorts of changes, either of herself, or through the influence of another soul, all that remains to the player of the game is that he should shift the pieces; sending the better nature to the better place, and the worse to the worse, and so assigning to them their proper portion.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">227</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  In what way do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">228</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In a way which may be supposed to make the care of all things easy to the Gods.</div><div class="sentence"> If any one were to form or fashion all things without any regard to the whole—if, for example, he formed a living element of water out of fire, instead of forming many things out of one or one out of many in regular order attaining to a first or second or third birth, the transmutation would have been infinite; but now the ruler of the world has a wonderfully easy task.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">229</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How so?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">230</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I will explain:  When the king saw that our actions had life, and that there was much virtue in them and much vice, and that the soul and body, although not, like the Gods of popular opinion, eternal, yet having once come into existence, were indestructible (for if either of them had been destroyed, there would have been no generation of living beings); and when he observed that the good of the soul was ever by nature designed to profit men, and the evil to harm them—he, seeing all this, contrived so to place each of the parts that their position might in the easiest and best manner procure the victory of good and the defeat of evil in the whole.</div><div class="sentence"> And he contrived a general plan by which a thing of a certain nature found a certain seat and room.</div><div class="sentence"> But the formation of qualities he left to the wills of individuals.</div><div class="sentence"> For every one of us is made pretty much what he is by the bent of his desires and the nature of his soul.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">231</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, that is probably true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">232</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then all things which have a soul change, and possess in themselves a principle of change, and in changing move according to law and to the order of destiny:  natures which have undergone a lesser change move less and on the earth's surface, but those which have suffered more change and have become more criminal sink into the abyss, that is to say, into Hades and other places in the world below, of which the very names terrify men, and which they picture to themselves as in a dream, both while alive and when released from the body.</div><div class="sentence"> And whenever the soul receives more of good or evil from her own energy and the strong influence of others—when she has communion with divine virtue and becomes divine, she is carried into another and better place, which is perfect in holiness; but when she has communion with evil, then she also changes the place of her life.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">233</span> <div class="sentence">  'This is the justice of the Gods who inhabit Olympus.'</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">234</span> <div class="sentence">  O youth or young man, who fancy that you are neglected by the Gods, know that if you become worse you shall go to the worse souls, or if better to the better, and in every succession of life and death you will do and suffer what like may fitly suffer at the hands of like.</div><div class="sentence"> This is the justice of heaven, which neither you nor any other unfortunate will ever glory in escaping, and which the ordaining powers have specially ordained; take good heed thereof, for it will be sure to take heed of you.</div><div class="sentence"> If you say: I am small and will creep into the depths of the earth, or I am high and will fly up to heaven, you are not so small or so high but that you shall pay the fitting penalty, either here or in the world below or in some still more savage place whither you shall be conveyed.</div><div class="sentence"> This is also the explanation of the fate of those whom you saw, who had done unholy and evil deeds, and from small beginnings had grown great, and you fancied that from being miserable they had become happy; and in their actions, as in a mirror, you seemed to see the universal neglect of the Gods, not knowing how they make all things work together and contribute to the great whole.</div><div class="sentence"> And thinkest thou, bold man, that thou needest not to know this?</div><div class="sentence"> he who knows it not can never form any true idea of the happiness or unhappiness of life or hold any rational discourse respecting either.</div><div class="sentence"> If Cleinias and this our reverend company succeed in proving to you that you know not what you say of the Gods, then will God help you; but should you desire to hear more, listen to what we say to the third opponent, if you have any understanding whatsoever.</div><div class="sentence"> For I think that we have sufficiently proved the existence of the Gods, and that they care for men: The other notion that they are appeased by the wicked, and take gifts, is what we must not concede to any one, and what every man should disprove to the utmost of his power.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">235</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very good; let us do as you say.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">236</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, then, by the Gods themselves I conjure you to tell me—if they are to be propitiated, how are they to be propitiated?</div><div class="sentence"> Who are they, and what is their nature?</div><div class="sentence"> Must they not be at least rulers who have to order unceasingly the whole heaven?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">237</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">238</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And to what earthly rulers can they be compared, or who to them?</div><div class="sentence"> How in the less can we find an image of the greater?</div><div class="sentence"> Are they charioteers of contending pairs of steeds, or pilots of vessels?</div><div class="sentence"> Perhaps they might be compared to the generals of armies, or they might be likened to physicians providing against the diseases which make war upon the body, or to husbandmen observing anxiously the effects of the seasons on the growth of plants; or perhaps to shepherds of flocks.</div><div class="sentence"> For as we acknowledge the world to be full of many goods and also of evils, and of more evils than goods, there is, as we affirm, an immortal conflict going on among us, which requires marvellous watchfulness; and in that conflict the Gods and demigods are our allies, and we are their property.</div><div class="sentence"> Injustice and insolence and folly are the destruction of us, and justice and temperance and wisdom are our salvation; and the place of these latter is in the life of the Gods, although some vestige of them may occasionally be discerned among mankind.</div><div class="sentence"> But upon this earth we know that there dwell souls possessing an unjust spirit, who may be compared to brute animals, which fawn upon their keepers, whether dogs or shepherds, or the best and most perfect masters; for they in like manner, as the voices of the wicked declare, prevail by flattery and prayers and incantations, and are allowed to make their gains with impunity.</div><div class="sentence"> And this sin, which is termed dishonesty, is an evil of the same kind as what is termed disease in living bodies or pestilence in years or seasons of the year, and in cities and governments has another name, which is injustice.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">239</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Quite true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">240</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  What else can he say who declares that the Gods are always lenient to the doers of unjust acts, if they divide the spoil with them?</div><div class="sentence"> As if wolves were to toss a portion of their prey to the dogs, and they, mollified by the gift, suffered them to tear the flocks.</div><div class="sentence"> Must not he who maintains that the Gods can be propitiated argue thus?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">241</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Precisely so.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">242</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And to which of the above-mentioned classes of guardians would any man compare the Gods without absurdity?</div><div class="sentence"> Will he say that they are like pilots, who are themselves turned away from their duty by 'libations of wine and the savour of fat,' and at last overturn both ship and sailors?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">243</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Assuredly not.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">244</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And surely they are not like charioteers who are bribed to give up the victory to other chariots?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">245</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That would be a fearful image of the Gods.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">246</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Nor are they like generals, or physicians, or husbandmen, or shepherds; and no one would compare them to dogs who have been silenced by wolves.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">247</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  A thing not to be spoken of.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">248</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And are not all the Gods the chiefest of all guardians, and do they not guard our highest interests?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">249</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes; the chiefest.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">250</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And shall we say that those who guard our noblest interests, and are the best of guardians, are inferior in virtue to dogs, and to men even of moderate excellence, who would never betray justice for the sake of gifts which unjust men impiously offer them?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">251</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly not; nor is such a notion to be endured, and he who holds this opinion may be fairly singled out and characterized as of all impious men the wickedest and most impious.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">252</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then are the three assertions—that the Gods exist, and that they take care of men, and that they can never be persuaded to do injustice, now sufficiently demonstrated?</div><div class="sentence"> May we say that they are?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">253</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  You have our entire assent to your words.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">254</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I have spoken with vehemence because I am zealous against evil men; and I will tell you, dear Cleinias, why I am so.</div><div class="sentence"> I would not have the wicked think that, having the superiority in argument, they may do as they please and act according to their various imaginations about the Gods; and this zeal has led me to speak too vehemently; but if we have at all succeeded in persuading the men to hate themselves and love their opposites, the prelude of our laws about impiety will not have been spoken in vain.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">255</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  So let us hope; and even if we have failed, the style of our argument will not discredit the lawgiver.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">256</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  After the prelude shall follow a discourse, which will be the interpreter of the law; this shall proclaim to all impious persons that they must depart from their ways and go over to the pious.</div><div class="sentence"> And to those who disobey, let the law about impiety be as follows:  If a man is guilty of any impiety in word or deed, any one who happens to be present shall give information to the magistrates, in aid of the law; and let the magistrates who first receive the information bring him before the appointed court according to the law; and if a magistrate, after receiving information, refuses to act, he shall be tried for impiety at the instance of any one who is willing to vindicate the laws; and if any one be cast, the court shall estimate the punishment of each act of impiety; and let all such criminals be imprisoned.</div><div class="sentence"> There shall be three prisons in the state:  the first of them is to be the common prison in the neighbourhood of the agora for the safe-keeping of the generality of offenders; another is to be in the neighbourhood of the nocturnal council, and is to be called the 'House of Reformation'; another, to be situated in some wild and desolate region in the centre of the country, shall be called by some name expressive of retribution.</div><div class="sentence"> Now, men fall into impiety from three causes, which have been already mentioned, and from each of these causes arise two sorts of impiety, in all six, which are worth distinguishing, and should not all have the same punishment.</div><div class="sentence"> For he who does not believe in the Gods, and yet has a righteous nature, hates the wicked and dislikes and refuses to do injustice, and avoids unrighteous men, and loves the righteous.</div><div class="sentence"> But they who besides believing that the world is devoid of Gods are intemperate, and have at the same time good memories and quick wits, are worse; although both of them are unbelievers, much less injury is done by the one than by the other.</div><div class="sentence"> The one may talk loosely about the Gods and about sacrifices and oaths, and perhaps by laughing at other men he may make them like himself, if he be not punished.</div><div class="sentence"> But the other who holds the same opinions and is called a clever man, is full of stratagem and deceit—men of this class deal in prophecy and jugglery of all kinds, and out of their ranks sometimes come tyrants and demagogues and generals and hierophants of private mysteries and the Sophists, as they are termed, with their ingenious devices.</div><div class="sentence"> There are many kinds of unbelievers, but two only for whom legislation is required; one the hypocritical sort, whose crime is deserving of death many times over, while the other needs only bonds and admonition.</div><div class="sentence"> In like manner also the notion that the Gods take no thought of men produces two other sorts of crimes, and the notion that they may be propitiated produces two more.</div><div class="sentence"> Assuming these divisions, let those who have been made what they are only from want of understanding, and not from malice or an evil nature, be placed by the judge in the House of Reformation, and ordered to suffer imprisonment during a period of not less than five years.</div><div class="sentence"> And in the meantime let them have no intercourse with the other citizens, except with members of the nocturnal council, and with them let them converse with a view to the improvement of their soul's health.</div><div class="sentence"> And when the time of their imprisonment has expired, if any of them be of sound mind let him be restored to sane company, but if not, and if he be condemned a second time, let him be punished with death.</div><div class="sentence"> As to that class of monstrous natures who not only believe that there are no Gods, or that they are negligent, or to be propitiated, but in contempt of mankind conjure the souls of the living and say that they can conjure the dead and promise to charm the Gods with sacrifices and prayers, and will utterly overthrow individuals and whole houses and states for the sake of money—let him who is guilty of any of these things be condemned by the court to be bound according to law in the prison which is in the centre of the land, and let no freeman ever approach him, but let him receive the rations of food appointed by the guardians of the law from the hands of the public slaves;
