<div class="speech"><span class="ref">019</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That is very good, Stranger; but I wish you would tell me more clearly what you mean.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">020</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  O Cleinias, many things of old time were well said and sung; and the saying about the Fates was one of them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">021</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What is it?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">022</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The saying that Lachesis or the giver of the lots is the first of them, and that Clotho or the spinster is the second of them, and that Atropos or the unchanging one is the third of them; and that she is the preserver of the things which we have spoken, and which have been compared in a figure to things woven by fire, they both (i.e.</div><div class="sentence"> Atropos and the fire) producing the quality of unchangeableness.</div><div class="sentence"> I am speaking of the things which in a state and government give not only health and salvation to the body, but law, or rather preservation of the law, in the soul; and, if I am not mistaken, this seems to be still wanting in our laws:  we have still to see how we can implant in them this irreversible nature.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">023</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  It will be no small matter if we can only discover how such a nature can be implanted in anything.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">024</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  But it certainly can be; so much I clearly see.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">025</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Then let us not think of desisting until we have imparted this quality to our laws; for it is ridiculous, after a great deal of labour has been spent, to place a thing at last on an insecure foundation.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">026</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I approve of your suggestion, and am quite of the same mind with you.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">027</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very good:  And now what, according to you, is to be the salvation of our government and of our laws, and how is it to be effected?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">028</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Were we not saying that there must be in our city a council which was to be of this sort:  The ten oldest guardians of the law, and all those who have obtained prizes of virtue, were to meet in the same assembly, and the council was also to include those who had visited foreign countries in the hope of hearing something that might be of use in the preservation of the laws, and who, having come safely home, and having been tested in these same matters, had proved themselves to be worthy to take part in the assembly—each of the members was to select some young man of not less than thirty years of age, he himself judging in the first instance whether the young man was worthy by nature and education, and then suggesting him to the others, and if he seemed to them also to be worthy they were to adopt him; but if not, the decision at which they arrived was to be kept a secret from the citizens at large, and, more especially, from the rejected candidate.</div><div class="sentence"> The meeting of the council was to be held early in the morning, when everybody was most at leisure from all other business, whether public or private—was not something of this sort said by us before?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">029</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">030</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then, returning to the council, I would say further, that if we let it down to be the anchor of the state, our city, having everything which is suitable to her, will preserve all that we wish to preserve.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">031</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">032</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Now is the time for me to speak the truth in all earnestness.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">033</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Well said, and I hope that you will fulfil your intention.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">034</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Know, Cleinias, that everything, in all that it does, has a natural saviour, as of an animal the soul and the head are the chief saviours.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">035</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Once more, what do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">036</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The well-being of those two is obviously the preservation of every living thing.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">037</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How is that?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">038</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  The soul, besides other things, contains mind, and the head, besides other things, contains sight and hearing; and the mind, mingling with the noblest of the senses, and becoming one with them, may be truly called the salvation of all.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">039</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, quite so.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">040</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes, indeed; but with what is that intellect concerned which, mingling with the senses, is the salvation of ships in storms as well as in fair weather?</div><div class="sentence"> In a ship, when the pilot and the sailors unite their perceptions with the piloting mind, do they not save both themselves and their craft?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">041</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">042</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  We do not want many illustrations about such matters:  What aim would the general of an army, or what aim would a physician propose to himself, if he were seeking to attain salvation?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">043</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very good.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">044</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Does not the general aim at victory and superiority in war, and do not the physician and his assistants aim at producing health in the body?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">045</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">046</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And a physician who is ignorant about the body, that is to say, who knows not that which we just now called health, or a general who knows not victory, or any others who are ignorant of the particulars of the arts which we mentioned, cannot be said to have understanding about any of these matters.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">047</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  They cannot.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">048</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And what would you say of the state?</div><div class="sentence"> If a person proves to be ignorant of the aim to which the statesman should look, ought he, in the first place, to be called a ruler at all; and further, will he ever be able to preserve that of which he does not even know the aim?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">049</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Impossible.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">050</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And therefore, if our settlement of the country is to be perfect, we ought to have some institution, which, as I was saying, will tell what is the aim of the state, and will inform us how we are to attain this, and what law or what man will advise us to that end.</div><div class="sentence"> Any state which has no such institution is likely to be devoid of mind and sense, and in all her actions will proceed by mere chance.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">051</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">052</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In which, then, of the parts or institutions of the state is any such guardian power to be found?</div><div class="sentence"> Can we say?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">053</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I am not quite certain, Stranger; but I have a suspicion that you are referring to the assembly which you just now said was to meet at night.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">054</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  You understand me perfectly, Cleinias; and we must assume, as the argument implies, that this council possesses all virtue; and the beginning of virtue is not to make mistakes by guessing many things, but to look steadily at one thing, and on this to fix all our aims.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">055</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Quite true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">056</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then now we shall see why there is nothing wonderful in states going astray—the reason is that their legislators have such different aims; nor is there anything wonderful in some laying down as their rule of justice, that certain individuals should bear rule in the state, whether they be good or bad, and others that the citizens should be rich, not caring whether they are the slaves of other men or not.</div><div class="sentence"> The tendency of others, again, is towards freedom; and some legislate with a view to two things at once—they want to be at the same time free and the lords of other states; but the wisest men, as they deem themselves to be, look to all these and similar aims, and there is no one of them which they exclusively honour, and to which they would have all things look.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">057</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Then, Stranger, our former assertion will hold; for we were saying that laws generally should look to one thing only; and this, as we admitted, was rightly said to be virtue.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">058</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Yes.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">059</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  And we said that virtue was of four kinds?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">060</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Quite true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">061</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  And that mind was the leader of the four, and that to her the three other virtues and all other things ought to have regard?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">062</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  You follow me capitally, Cleinias, and I would ask you to follow me to the end, for we have already said that the mind of the pilot, the mind of the physician and of the general look to that one thing to which they ought to look; and now we may turn to mind political, of which, as of a human creature, we will ask a question:  O wonderful being, and to what are you looking?</div><div class="sentence"> The physician is able to tell his single aim in life, but you, the superior, as you declare yourself to be, of all intelligent beings, when you are asked are not able to tell.</div><div class="sentence"> Can you, Megillus, and you, Cleinias, say distinctly what is the aim of mind political, in return for the many explanations of things which I have given you?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">063</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  We cannot, Stranger.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">064</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, but ought we not to desire to see it, and to see where it is to be found?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">065</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  For example, where?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">066</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  For example, we were saying that there are four kinds of virtue, and as there are four of them, each of them must be one.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">067</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">068</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And further, all four of them we call one; for we say that courage is virtue, and that prudence is virtue, and the same of the two others, as if they were in reality not many but one, that is, virtue.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">069</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Quite so.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">070</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  There is no difficulty in seeing in what way the two differ from one another, and have received two names, and so of the rest.</div><div class="sentence"> But there is more difficulty in explaining why we call these two and the rest of them by the single name of virtue.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">071</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">072</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I have no difficulty in explaining what I mean.</div><div class="sentence"> Let us distribute the subject into questions and answers.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">073</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Once more, what do you mean?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">074</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Ask me what is that one thing which I call virtue, and then again speak of as two, one part being courage and the other wisdom.</div><div class="sentence"> I will tell you how that occurs:  One of them has to do with fear; in this the beasts also participate, and quite young children—I mean courage; for a courageous temper is a gift of nature and not of reason.</div><div class="sentence"> But without reason there never has been, or is, or will be a wise and understanding soul; it is of a different nature.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">075</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That is true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">076</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  I have now told you in what way the two are different, and do you in return tell me in what way they are one and the same.</div><div class="sentence"> Suppose that I ask you in what way the four are one, and when you have answered me, you will have a right to ask of me in return in what way they are four; and then let us proceed to enquire whether in the case of things which have a name and also a definition to them, true knowledge consists in knowing the name only and not the definition.</div><div class="sentence"> Can he who is good for anything be ignorant of all this without discredit where great and glorious truths are concerned?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">077</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I suppose not.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">078</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And is there anything greater to the legislator and the guardian of the law, and to him who thinks that he excels all other men in virtue, and has won the palm of excellence, than these very qualities of which we are now speaking—courage, temperance, wisdom, justice?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">079</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How can there be anything greater?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">080</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And ought not the interpreters, the teachers, the lawgivers, the guardians of the other citizens, to excel the rest of mankind, and perfectly to show him who desires to learn and know or whose evil actions require to be punished and reproved, what is the nature of virtue and vice?</div><div class="sentence"> Or shall some poet who has found his way into the city, or some chance person who pretends to be an instructor of youth, show himself to be better than him who has won the prize for every virtue?</div><div class="sentence"> And can we wonder that when the guardians are not adequate in speech or action, and have no adequate knowledge of virtue, the city being unguarded should experience the common fate of cities in our day?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">081</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Wonder!</div><div class="sentence"> no.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">082</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, then, must we do as we said?</div><div class="sentence"> Or can we give our guardians a more precise knowledge of virtue in speech and action than the many have?</div><div class="sentence"> or is there any way in which our city can be made to resemble the head and senses of rational beings because possessing such a guardian power?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">083</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What, Stranger, is the drift of your comparison?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">084</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Do we not see that the city is the trunk, and are not the younger guardians, who are chosen for their natural gifts, placed in the head of the state, having their souls all full of eyes, with which they look about the whole city?</div><div class="sentence"> They keep watch and hand over their perceptions to the memory, and inform the elders of all that happens in the city; and those whom we compared to the mind, because they have many wise thoughts—that is to say, the old men—take counsel, and making use of the younger men as their ministers, and advising with them—in this way both together truly preserve the whole state:  Shall this or some other be the order of our state?</div><div class="sentence"> Are all our citizens to be equal in acquirements, or shall there be special persons among them who have received a more careful training and education?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">085</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  That they should be equal, my good sir, is impossible.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">086</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then we ought to proceed to some more exact training than any which has preceded.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">087</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">088</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And must not that of which we are in need be the one to which we were just now alluding?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">089</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">090</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Did we not say that the workman or guardian, if he be perfect in every respect, ought not only to be able to see the many aims, but he should press onward to the one?</div><div class="sentence"> This he should know, and knowing, order all things with a view to it.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">091</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  True.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">092</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And can any one have a more exact way of considering or contemplating anything, than the being able to look at one idea gathered from many different things?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">093</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Perhaps not.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">094</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Not 'Perhaps not,' but 'Certainly not,' my good sir, is the right answer.</div><div class="sentence"> There never has been a truer method than this discovered by any man.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">095</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I bow to your authority, Stranger; let us proceed in the way which you propose.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">096</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Then, as would appear, we must compel the guardians of our divine state to perceive, in the first place, what that principle is which is the same in all the four—the same, as we affirm, in courage and in temperance, and in justice and in prudence, and which, being one, we call as we ought, by the single name of virtue.</div><div class="sentence"> To this, my friends, we will, if you please, hold fast, and not let go until we have sufficiently explained what that is to which we are to look, whether to be regarded as one, or as a whole, or as both, or in whatever way.</div><div class="sentence"> Are we likely ever to be in a virtuous condition, if we cannot tell whether virtue is many, or four, or one?</div><div class="sentence"> Certainly, if we take counsel among ourselves, we shall in some way contrive that this principle has a place amongst us; but if you have made up your mind that we should let the matter alone, we will.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">097</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  We must not, Stranger, by the God of strangers I swear that we must not, for in our opinion you speak most truly; but we should like to know how you will accomplish your purpose.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">098</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Wait a little before you ask; and let us, first of all, be quite agreed with one another that the purpose has to be accomplished.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">099</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly, it ought to be, if it can be.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">100</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Well, and about the good and the honourable, are we to take the same view?</div><div class="sentence"> Are our guardians only to know that each of them is many, or also how and in what way they are one?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">101</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  They must consider also in what sense they are one.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">102</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And are they to consider only, and to be unable to set forth what they think?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">103</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly not; that would be the state of a slave.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">104</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  And may not the same be said of all good things—that the true guardians of the laws ought to know the truth about them, and to be able to interpret them in words, and carry them out in action, judging of what is and of what is not well, according to nature?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">105</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">106</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Is not the knowledge of the Gods which we have set forth with so much zeal one of the noblest sorts of knowledge—to know that they are, and know how great is their power, as far as in man lies?</div><div class="sentence"> We do indeed excuse the mass of the citizens, who only follow the voice of the laws, but we refuse to admit as guardians any who do not labour to obtain every possible evidence that there is respecting the Gods; our city is forbidden and not allowed to choose as a guardian of the law, or to place in the select order of virtue, him who is not an inspired man, and has not laboured at these things.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">107</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  It is certainly just, as you say, that he who is indolent about such matters or incapable should be rejected, and that things honourable should be put away from him.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">108</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Are we assured that there are two things which lead men to believe in the Gods, as we have already stated?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">109</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What are they?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">110</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  One is the argument about the soul, which has been already mentioned—that it is the eldest and most divine of all things, to which motion attaining generation gives perpetual existence; the other was an argument from the order of the motion of the stars, and of all things under the dominion of the mind which ordered the universe.</div><div class="sentence"> If a man look upon the world not lightly or ignorantly, there was never any one so godless who did not experience an effect opposite to that which the many imagine.</div><div class="sentence"> For they think that those who handle these matters by the help of astronomy, and the accompanying arts of demonstration, may become godless, because they see, as far as they can see, things happening by necessity, and not by an intelligent will accomplishing good.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">111</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  But what is the fact?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">112</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Just the opposite, as I said, of the opinion which once prevailed among men, that the sun and stars are without soul.</div><div class="sentence"> Even in those days men wondered about them, and that which is now ascertained was then conjectured by some who had a more exact knowledge of them—that if they had been things without soul, and had no mind, they could never have moved with numerical exactness so wonderful; and even at that time some ventured to hazard the conjecture that mind was the orderer of the universe.</div><div class="sentence"> But these same persons again mistaking the nature of the soul, which they conceived to be younger and not older than the body, once more overturned the world, or rather, I should say, themselves; for the bodies which they saw moving in heaven all appeared to be full of stones, and earth, and many other lifeless substances, and to these they assigned the causes of all things.</div><div class="sentence"> Such studies gave rise to much atheism and perplexity, and the poets took occasion to be abusive—comparing the philosophers to she-dogs uttering vain howlings, and talking other nonsense of the same sort.</div><div class="sentence"> But now, as I said, the case is reversed.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">113</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  How so?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">114</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  No man can be a true worshipper of the Gods who does not know these two principles—that the soul is the eldest of all things which are born, and is immortal and rules over all bodies; moreover, as I have now said several times, he who has not contemplated the mind of nature which is said to exist in the stars, and gone through the previous training, and seen the connexion of music with these things, and harmonized them all with laws and institutions, is not able to give a reason of such things as have a reason.</div><div class="sentence"> And he who is unable to acquire this in addition to the ordinary virtues of a citizen, can hardly be a good ruler of a whole state; but he should be the subordinate of other rulers.</div><div class="sentence"> Wherefore, Cleinias and Megillus, let us consider whether we may not add to all the other laws which we have discussed this further one—that the nocturnal assembly of the magistrates, which has also shared in the whole scheme of education proposed by us, shall be a guard set according to law for the salvation of the state.</div><div class="sentence"> Shall we propose this?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">115</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Certainly, my good friend, we will if the thing is in any degree possible.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">116</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  Let us make a common effort to gain such an object; for I too will gladly share in the attempt.</div><div class="sentence"> Of these matters I have had much experience, and have often considered them, and I dare say that I shall be able to find others who will also help.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">117</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  I agree, Stranger, that we should proceed along the road in which God is guiding us; and how we can proceed rightly has now to be investigated and explained.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">118</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  O Megillus and Cleinias, about these matters we cannot legislate further until the council is constituted; when that is done, then we will determine what authority they shall have of their own; but the explanation of how this is all to be ordered would only be given rightly in a long discourse.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">119</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What do you mean, and what new thing is this?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">120</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  In the first place, a list would have to be made out of those who by their ages and studies and dispositions and habits are well fitted for the duty of a guardian.</div><div class="sentence"> In the next place, it will not be easy for them to discover themselves what they ought to learn, or become the disciple of one who has already made the discovery.</div><div class="sentence"> Furthermore, to write down the times at which, and during which, they ought to receive the several kinds of instruction, would be a vain thing; for the learners themselves do not know what is learned to advantage until the knowledge which is the result of learning has found a place in the soul of each.</div><div class="sentence"> And so these details, although they could not be truly said to be secret, might be said to be incapable of being stated beforehand, because when stated they would have no meaning.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">121</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  What then are we to do, Stranger, under these circumstances?</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">122</span><div class="speaker">ATHENIAN</div><div class="sentence">  As the proverb says, the answer is no secret, but open to all of us:  We must risk the whole on the chance of throwing, as they say, thrice six or thrice ace, and I am willing to share with you the danger by stating and explaining to you my views about education and nurture, which is the question coming to the surface again.</div><div class="sentence"> The danger is not a slight or ordinary one, and I would advise you, Cleinias, in particular, to see to the matter; for if you order rightly the city of the Magnetes, or whatever name God may give it, you will obtain the greatest glory; or at any rate you will be thought the most courageous of men in the estimation of posterity.</div><div class="sentence"> Dear companions, if this our divine assembly can only be established, to them we will hand over the city; none of the present company of legislators, as I may call them, would hesitate about that.</div><div class="sentence"> And the state will be perfected and become a waking reality, which a little while ago we attempted to create as a dream and in idea only, mingling together reason and mind in one image, in the hope that our citizens might be duly mingled and rightly educated; and being educated, and dwelling in the citadel of the land, might become perfect guardians, such as we have never seen in all our previous life, by reason of the saving virtue which is in them.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">123</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  Dear Cleinias, after all that has been said, either we must detain the Stranger, and by supplications and in all manner of ways make him share in the foundation of the city, or we must give up the undertaking.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">124</span><div class="speaker">CLEINIAS</div><div class="sentence">  Very true, Megillus; and you must join with me in detaining him.</div></div>
<div class="speech"><span class="ref">125</span><div class="speaker">MEGILLUS</div><div class="sentence">  I will.</div></div>

</div>
</div>
